rationale:
Palea steindachneri is considered Critically Endangered in its range states as it is a highly valuable species in the food trade. The future security of introduced subpopulations in Mauritius, Hong Kong, and the United States may be critical for the survival of the species.

Palea steindachneri is under significant pressure from targeted exploitation for local consumption and trade, including supply to commercial farms. While a quantitative assessment is challenging, an overall reduction of the total population has occurred by at least 50%, and likely well over 80%, over the past 3–5 decades (three generations), and these pressures are likely to continue for the foreseeable future, qualifying the species for CR A2cd+A4cd.
habitat:
Palea steindachneri inhabits clear flowing streams and lakes in relatively intact evergreen forest areas at foothill and middle altitudes, up to at least 436 m asl. 
Females in farms are said to mature at about 28 cm carapace length and 2.5 kg size at the age of five years, and produce clutches of 15–20 eggs (ATCN unpublished report 2004). No corresponding data from the wild appear available. Generation length is estimated at about 15 to 20 years, with old animals estimated to be about 40 to 50 years. Zhou and Li (2013) report age at maturity for females is 3–6 years, and 2–4 years for males in captivity.
threats: Palea steindachneri is highly valuable in food trade; some populations may also be affected by forest loss and hydropower development. The species is captured with hooks, traps, electrofishing, explosives, probing and noodling in streams. There are multiple registered commercial farms breeding the species, and alongside the legal captive production there are indications of trade in wild-caught animals to supply farms or laundered through them.
population:
Virtually no population information has been recorded for Palea steindachneri. Participants of the Singapore 2011 and 2018 workshops (Fong, Ha, McCormack and Timmins) reported that P. steindachneri still occurs in the wild in China in small fragmented populations, and occurs in or near some protected areas in Viet Nam. Observations throughout the range indicate substantial, but unquantified, declines over the past few decades. While in decline, populations in remote forest areas of Viet Nam, some of which include protected areas, are known to continue successful reproduction and presumably recruitment. Very few, if any, reliable records from the wild have emerged from China in recent years (B. Horne pers. comm. 2018).

A very rough estimate is that the species has disappeared from parts of its original distribution range (EOO) and remaining populations are understood to have been severely depleted over the past decades, with a total reduction estimated at well over 80% of total mature animals over the past half century, and the decline continuing.
range: Palea steindachneri occurs in southern China (Guangdong, Guizhou, Yunnan and Hainan), and in east-draining river systems of northern and central Viet Nam and adjacent Lao PDR. Introduced subpopulations are known from Mauritius, Hong Kong (China) and Hawaii (USA).
useTrade: Palea steindachneri is collected for subsistence consumption and trade, often as part of fisheries bycatch. It is also farmed commercially in substantial quantities in farms in China and Viet Nam.
conservationActions:
Palea steindachneri has been listed on CITES Appendix II since 2013. It was declared a National Protected Wild Animal Category II in China’s Wild Animals Protection Law. It is not specifically protected under Vietnamese legislation, although the Forest Protection Law should offer a modicum of habitat protection. The species likely survives within suitable habitat in protected areas in Viet Nam.

The primary conservation measure needed for P. steindachneri (and many other species and their ecosystem) is the creation of secure, adequately managed protected areas with suitable habitat. Surveys to evaluate the status and occurrence of populations can be integrated into broader biodiversity surveys. Research on natural history and ecology, and evaluation of genetic and morphological variability, are desirable.

rationale: The total population of Cyclemys gemeli is estimated to have least halved in the past three generations (30 years) through ongoing habitat loss and collection in remaining habitat. This decline is expected to continue. Thus, the species qualifies for listing as Endangered A2cd+A4cd.
habitat: Cyclemys oldhamii inhabits mainly streams and adjoining stream valley areas in subtropical monsoon hill forest areas, up to an altitude of 1,000 m but usually lower (Das 1991, van Dijk 1998). Cyclemys oldhamii feed on a variety of fruits, small animal prey, and scavenge when an opportunity presents itself (van Dijk 1998). Turtles of the Cyclemys oldhamii group can attain up to 26 cm carapace length (Das 1991). Age at maturity has been reported as 10–12 years, and generation time as three times that, at 30 years (Nutphand 1979). Females can produce up to 5 clutches of 2–4 eggs annually.
threats: Adult Cyclemys oldhamii have historically been extensively collected in the hill ranges of Thailand for subsistence consumption and some local trade. In recent years, exploitation has intensified to supply East Asian consumption markets, where C. oldhamii is one of the more commonly traded species. The species group does not adapt to human-dominated agricultural landscapes, but can tolerate modest habitat impacts such as selective logging.
population: In western Thailand, Cyclemys oldhamii is one of the more common turtle species, with densities estimated on the order of one animal per several kilometres of stream (Thirakhupt and van Dijk 1995). The population structure in western Thailand is noteworthy, which is dominated by juvenile animals, indicating ongoing effective recruitment (van Dijk 1998). Little status data is available for Thailand since then. Data for the Cambodian population is insufficient to determine population trend. Total population is estimated to have at least halved in the past half century through habitat loss and collection in remaining habitat, and this is predicted to continue.
range: While recent taxonomic changes make it challenging to define the range of Cyclemys oldhamii precisely, it is understood to range from eastern Myanmar through much of Thailand and Lao PDR, central and southern Viet Nam, and northern Cambodia; part of its range might be in broad sympatry with C. atripons and C. pulchristriata. It occurs below 1,000 m asl. Previous records from Peninsular Malaysia, Sumatra, Java and Borneo are now attributed to C. enigmatica (Fritz et al. 2008). Records from southern Yunnan (China) likely were based on trade specimens.
useTrade: Pet trade of Cyclemys oldhamii is insignificant compared to exploitation for human consumption. Cyclemys oldhamii has been common in the Asian consumption trade of turtles (at local, national and international levels) since the 1990s.
conservationActions: The genus Cyclemys was included in CITES Appendix II in 2013. Cyclemys oldhamii has been recorded from various protected areas in Thailand, including the Western Forest Complex, Khao Yai, Phu Luang and Doi Chiang Dao. Provided existing protected areas across the range of this species are effectively protected from collection and habitat damage, the species would probably not need additional conservation action beyond population monitoring. Taxonomic resolution is urgently needed.

rationale: Cyclemys atripons is assessed as Endangered due to an inferred population decline arising from over-collection and habitat loss amounting to half the total population of adult animals over the past half century (less than three generations, with a generation length estimated to be 25 years) which is expected to continue into the future. This species is exploited for both food and pets, with its international trade not currently managed under CITES. Deforestation in the region may pose a further threat due to the loss of terrestrial habitat and the degradation of aquatic habitat. Research on the population and harvest levels is recommended to identify the rate of decline and any appropriate conservation measures.
habitat:
This semi-aquatic species inhabits calm watercourses in evergreen forested hills up to 1,000 m elevation (Bonin et al. 2006). In Cambodia, Cyclemys atripons has been recorded in seasonally inundated coastal forests, slow-moving rivers, ponds and lakes, and hill streams in evergreen forest.

Age at sexual maturity estimated at 11 years, and adult life is approximately 25 years (e.g., Cyclemys dentata is known to have lived 15 years in captivity as an adult). Therefore generation time is estimated to be between 20 and 25 years (using age of maturity + 0.5*(length of reproductive period in life cycle) and the upper estimate is used here).
threats: Cyclemys atripons is threatened by overcollection and habitat loss. It is consumed locally (van Dijk et al. 1999) and is traded as food and pets (Bonin et al. 2006). Documented trade numbers of C. atripons increased in China in the 1990s and 2000s, although visible trade remained low in Cambodia and Thailand.  As C. atripons is semi-terrestrial and generally associated with closed-canopy forest, loss of forest is seen as a major threat. The annual deforestation rate in Thailand has been estimated at around 2.6% for the period 1990–1997 (FAO 1997), with forest area declining from 53.3% of the total land area in 1961 to 22.8% in 1999 (FAO 1999 in Sharp and Nakagoshi 2006). The main causes of this deforestation have been identified as legal and illegal logging, land encroachment, and shifting agriculture (Sharp and Nakagoshi 2006).
population:
Cyclemys atripons has been found during the last four years of surveys to be fairly locally common in the coastal region of southwest Cambodia and in the Central Cardamoms Protected Forest, Bokor National Park, and the southern Cardamoms (D. Emmett pers. comm.). It is considered fairly common, with stable populations in protected areas in southeastern Thailand.

However, there has been an inferred population decline arising from over-collection and habitat loss amounting to half the total population of adult animals over the past half century (less than three generations, with generation length estimated to be 26 years).
range: The range of Cyclemys atripons is limited to the hills of southeastern Thailand and the Cardamon Mountains region of southwestern Cambodia (Bonin et al. 2006). It possibly occurs in southern Viet Nam.
useTrade: It is consumed locally (van Dijk et al. 1999) and is traded as food and pets (Bonin et al. 2006). Documented trade numbers of Cyclemys atripons increased in China in the 1990s and 2000s, although visible trade remained low in Cambodia and Thailand.
conservationActions:
Cyclemys atripons is protected under domestic legislation in Thailand (as Cyclemys dentata).

All Cyclemys species are included in CITES Appendix II.

The species occurs in a number of protected areas, including the Central Cardamoms Protected Forest and Bokor National Park in Cambodia, and Khao Soi Dao WS and presumably Khao Yai NP in Thailand.

Further research on the population and harvest levels is recommended to identify the rate of decline and appropriate conservation measures.

rationale: The total population of Cyclemys pulchristriata has at least halved in the past half century (less than three generations) through ongoing habitat loss and collection in remaining habitat. It is believed that this decline will continue. Therefore this species qualifies for listing as Endangered under criteria A2cd+A4cd.
habitat: Cyclemys pulchristiata inhabits forest streams, mainly in small streams, and ranges widely into adjoining forest, including in disturbed forest areas. It is recorded up to at least 700 metres altitude, but is likely to range higher. The species reaches maturity at about 5–7 years, and longevity likely exceeds 50 years. Generation time is estimated at 26 years.
threats: Cyclemys pulchristriata is collected for trade, as well as some subsistence consumption, particularly among minorities in hill areas. Much collection of the species remains opportunistic, but ‘subsidised’ by search effort for more valuable sympatric species. Cyclemys pulchristiata is potentially affected by forest loss and degradation, as well as hydropower and reservoir projects.
population: No population data are available for Cyclemys pulchristiata; it used to be frequently encountered, but is currently considered uncommon to rare, and is understood to have declined significantly in recent years/decades. The total population is suspected to have at least halved in the past half century through habitat loss and collection in remaining habitat, and this is predicted to continue.
range: Cyclemys pulchristriata inhabits the Annamite foothills of southern Viet Nam and adjacent eastern Cambodia; it is likely absent from Lao PDR. It ranges up to 700 m asl, perhaps higher.
useTrade: Cyclemys pulchristriata was historically common in the trade, but has generally disappeared from trade seizures in Viet Nam (possibly related to its non-protected status).
conservationActions: The genus Cyclemys was included in CITES Appendix II in 2013. It is not protected in Viet Nam. It is likely to occur in several protected areas. No conservation actions are underway at present, due to low perceived value (monetary and conservation). As many specimens are confiscated from illegal trade, solutions need to be found for separating specimens from different source areas and suitable repatriation or other disposal solutions. Further work is needed to clarify the taxonomy and species boundaries of Cyclemys. Further survey work on its distribution and population status is warranted. Ensuring the occurrence of viable populations inside secure protected areas is important.

rationale: Listed as Endangered on the basis that this species has a known area of occupancy in India (20 km<sup>2</sup> based on records of subpopulations known to be extant) and due to its specific restriction to a highly threatened habitat that survives mainly due to efforts to conserve the Black Buck, it is not likely to have a much more extensive area of occupancy in India, and very small areas of remnant habitat remain at each locality, with more than half of the historically known localities having been lost over the last century, it occurs as a severely fragmented population, and there is a continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat at each remaining Indian locality and in at least part of the presumed Sri Lankan range. This assessment is based on Indian records, and may consequently be precautionary, pending clarification that recently discovered Sri Lankan subpopulations correspond to this species, since while this is thought likely to be the case this assignment is in need of validation.
habitat: This species has been recorded from species of dry, sandy scrub-clad lowlands (Ganesh and Chandramouli 2010) devoid of rocky outcrops, including areas close to the seashore (Ganesh et al. 2017). Srikanthan et al. (2018) recorded it from both grassland and dry thorn scrub, as well as in coconut groves and paddy fields. The historic record of this species in Sri Lanka is from coastal sand flats (A. Bauer pers. comm. March 2011). Species distribution modelling suggests a preference for low-elevation areas with a mean annual temperature of around 28.5 °C, rainfall below 1,000 mm a year, and relatively little difference between maximum and minimum temperatures (Srikanthan et al. 2018). It is strictly terrestrial and nocturnal, and shelters beneath rocks during the day (Srikanthan et al. 2018). In Sri Lanka it occurs in the arid zone, where it has been found beneath stones and logs in sparsely-vegetated scrub on sandy soils, and has been found in retreat sites by day (D. Jayesekara pers. comm. 2019). It exhibits strong evidence of territoriality and intraspecific aggression, with individuals separated from one another by 15-20 m (Srikanthan et al. 2018). Ganesh et al. (2017) reported that gravid females were active both in July, in the pre-monsoon season, and following the monsoon in December an February.
threats: Habitat loss in the form of burning of grasslands and conversion into real estate, grazing and tapioca plantations, and multiple invasive plant species that increase fire risk and shade its sandy habitats. Prosopis is the most widespread of these, affecting most formerly suitable open habitat within its range. Sand quarrying in and around river beds and coastal dunes are causing population decline. The known distribution is almost entirely human-modified. This species only survives at all because of efforts to conserve the Black Buck along the Coromandel coastal plains, a species which is dependent on similar grassland habitat. Urban development and rural settlement threaten the species in Sri Lanka, although it occurs in habitat in this country that is not generally subject to major threats; on Mannar Island there are multiple widespread threats including wind power and tourist industry development.
population: This species is poorly-sampled and underrepresented in collections (Bauer et al. 2010). Ganesh and Chandramouti (2010) reported the first record in over a century; other literature reports had previously been overlooked as they misidentified the species as the similar Hemidactylus reticulatus (Ganesh et al. 2017). It is an apparently rare species (Srikanthan et al. 2018), however in Tuticorin these geckos are reasonably common under boulders in fallow land at the three known sites (S. Sondhi pers. comm. March 2011). Ganesh et al. (2017) recorded 14 individuals in 55 man-hours of fieldwork across six localities. Declines have been observed in Coimbatore and Tuticorin (Srikanthan et al. 2018).  Five of the nine Indian localities are known to have been lost over a period of about a century. Near Trichy, all original habitat has been lost and the species no longer survives here. The species can no longer be found at a historical locality, Adayar, following urbanisation in Chennai (S.R. Ganesh pers. comm. 2019). The Coimbatore locality was destroyed in 2018, and if the lizard survives here at all it is thought to be confined to a 17 acre temple complex (N. Achyuthan pers. comm. 2019). Recent records from Sri Lanka have been of small numbers of individuals: three within one hectare at Mantai, and three in Chundikulam.
range: This species is found in Tamil Nadu in India, and in Sri Lanka. In Tamil Nadu this species is known from Adyar, near Chennai (Chennai District), Ramanthapuram (Ramanathapuram District), Mannampandal (Nagapattinam District) (Ganesh and Chandramouli 2010) and Tuticorin (Tuticorin district) (S. Sondhi pers. comm. March 2011, Ganesh et al. 2017). Ganesh et al. (2017) and Srikanthan et al. (2018) report multiple new localities across the south of the Indian peninsula ranging from the coast to the foothills of the Western Ghats and the Coimbatore Plateau. Species distribution modelling suggests that the species could range more widely in dry areas of Tamil Nadu and Kerala (Srikanthan et al. 2018). The gecko was historically recorded from Mariccukatte (=Marichchukkaddi) in the Northern Province of Sri Lanka, based on a record of three specimens (Smith and Deraniyagala 1934). Taylor (1953) reported that he did not find this species, it has not been found in a survey of Sri Lanka's northern islands (De Silva 1957), and the only recent published report of its occurrence in Sri Lanka (in the northernmost tip of the Eastern Province) is not accompanied by any exact locality data, known specimens, photographs or ecological information (Somaweera and Somaweera 2009). Srikanthan et al. (2018) report that no recent records exist from this country, however, recent unpublished records have been taken in 2016 from Chundikulam National Park (D. Jayesekara and M. Wickramasinghe unpubl. data) and in 2018 from Mannar Island and Uramalai (Dulan Vidanapathiratna and S. Kannishka pers. comm. 2019). Photographs taken by D. Madhavi in 2018 Giant's Tank, close to Mannar, are likely to represent this species (S.R. Ganesh pers. comm. 2019). It has been recorded from 10 to 385 m asl in Tamil Nadu (Srikanthan et al. 2018).
useTrade: The species is not in use.
conservationActions: There are no known conservation measures in place for this species, which is not known to occur in protected areas in India other than a single, 14 km<sup>2</sup> protected area Vallanadu Wildlife Sanctuary near Tuticorin. In Sri Lanka it appears to occur in the Giant's Tank Sanctuary. Further research into the taxonomy and distribution and biology of this gecko is needed, and into its exposure to threats. Recognition of grasslands and shrublands as important wildlife habitats maintained without afforestation is recommended (N. Achyuthan and S.R. Ganesh pers. comm. 2019). Field surveys in Pt. Calimere Sanctuary are recommended to try to identify whether it occurs here. Mostly unprotected in Sri Lanka.  It is entirely dependent on continued management of known sites for its survival in India. Taxonomic research is underway (M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. 2019) to clarify whether recently rediscovered subpopulations in India and Sri Lanka are conspecific. Thorough evaluation of Sri Lankan records, including collection of specimens, is needed, and clarification of its distribution in this country and the extent of threats.

rationale: Pangio anguillaris is found in the Mekong and Chao Phraya basins, smaller drainages in Thailand, the Malay Peninsula, Sumatra and Borneo. This species is widespread and, while it is possibly declining in parts of its range from the impacts of urbanisation, dam constructions and large scale palm oil plantations, leading to sedimentations, increased water abstractions and pollution, it is not thought that any global population decline is likely to meet (or be close to meeting) the threshold for Vulnerable. Therefore, the species is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: This freshwater species is found in medium to large-sized rivers (Taki 1978). It inhabits sand, hailstone or peat canals, with leaf-litter in river stretches with slow current (Vidthayanon 2002, Kottelat 1998). This species occurs near the bottom over sand or silt substrates, in both debris and decaying vegetation, and spends much of its time buried in the sand or slowly foraging across the surface. It migrates to breed in very shallow water areas with a lot of vegetation, most commonly in flooded forests or grasslands along the water edge. It mostly feeds on benthic invertebrates.
threats:
Pangio anguillaris most likely faces the threats of deforestation for agriculture, palm oil plantations and illegal logging across its range, leading to pollution from oil and pesticides, in addition to increased nutrient loads, sedimentation, waste disposal, large scale industrialisation and settlement-urbanisation (Chong et al. 2010). This causes ongoing peat drainage that results in peat subsidence and a heightened dry-season fire risk (Harrison et al. 2009, Chisholm et al. 2016), which has led to the loss of 1.8 Mha of peatland swamp forests (PSFs) in Kalimantan, Sumatra and Peninsular Malaysia from 2007 to 2015; equivalent to an annual deforestation rate of 4.1 % (Miettinen et al. 2016).

Existing and planned dams in the the Mekong, Malay Peninsula, Sumatra and Borneo have had large scale effects on water systems (Tang et al. 2019), with land conversion and habitat degradation caused by their affects of intensity of water flow. There are no data available on the number of fish caught for the ornamental fish trade or for local consumption, but it could be at risk of over-exploitation (Vidthayanon 2002).
population: There are no data on the population size of this species and more research is required.
range:
Pangio anguillaris is found in the Mekong and Chao Phraya basins, smaller drainages in Thailand, the Malay Peninsula, Sumatra and Borneo. In the Mekong basin it is found from Vientiane province in Lao PDR, to the lower parts of the river in Viet Nam (Kottelat and Lim 1993), including the Mun basin and the Tonlé Sap river and lake.

In Peninsular Malaysia, it has been recorded from the Pahang and Perak drainages (Kottelat and Lim 1993). In Borneo, it is found in the Kapuas Lakes area in western Kalimantan (Kottelat and Widjanarti 2005) and the Rajang Basin in Sarawak, Borneo (Parenti and Lim 2005). It has also been recorded from the Batang Hari River system in Sumatra (Kottelat and Lim 1993).
useTrade: This species is occasionally seen in the aquarium trade (Rainboth 1996), and is not known to have been bred in captivity (Seriously Fish 2012). It is not fished commercially, however, it is a highly esteemed food fish in northern central Thailand (Vidthayanon 2002).
conservationActions: This species is found in several National Parks in Cambodia, Thailand, Malaysia and Indonesia. There is no further information regarding conservation actions for this species. However, this species is known to occur within the regions relevant to the carbon payment scheme known as REDD+ (Reduced Emissions from Deforestation and Forest Degradation plus conservation, sustainable management of forests, and enhancement of forest carbon; UNFCCC 2010), which may help offset the opportunity costs of conserving peatland swamp forests (PSFs) within the Malaysian/ Indonesian region, thereby safeguarding its unique fish biota and carbon stocks. In May 2011, the president of the Republic of Indonesia decreed a 2-year moratorium on new permits for converting PSFs as part of a bilateral REDD+ agreement with Norway. It is recommended that more research is conducted in regards to this species population size and trends, as well as monitoring of wild population harvest.

rationale: Conorhynchos conirostris apresentava distribuição em toda a bacia do rio São Francisco. Atualmente ocorre de forma mais representativa na região do alto-médio São Francisco, na calha e baixo curso de afluentes maiores, no trecho considerado entre a jusante da barragem da UHE Três Marias e o remanso do reservatório da UHE Sobradinho. Apresenta claro declínio populacional em decorrência das alterações ambientais das drenagens, pressão de pesca e principalmente a construção de barragens. Considerando que, atualmente, a espécie se encontra em apenas 50% de sua área de ocupação (AOO) e extensão de ocorrência (EOO) originais, estima-se que a população tenha declinado pelo menos 50% em tamanho ao longo dos últimos 30 anos ou três gerações. Esse período coincide com a construção das grandes hidrelétricas do baixo rio São Francisco. Portanto, a espécie foi categorizada como Em Perigo (EN).
habitat: É um peixe de grande porte, chegando a mais de 1 m de comprimento e 13 kg. Realiza migrações reprodutivas, não mantém cuidado parental e apresenta desova total e ovos pelágicos livres. Em cada desova uma fêmea pode produzir de 0,5 a 1 milhão de ovos (Melo et al. 2011). Dado seu grande porte, supõe-se que sua longevidade ultrapasse dez anos e sua primeira maturação ocorra com mais de três anos. Portanto, o tempo geracional deve estar entre 20 e 30 anos (oficina de avaliação, 2011). Características anatômicas da cavidade bucofaringiana de C. conirostris representam adaptações ao hábito alimentar bentófago, com ingestão de organismos diversos que vivem no substrato. É uma espécie passível de uso na piscicultura, com reprodução e alevinagem efetiva em ambiente de cativeiro (O.A. Cantelmo com. pess. 2011).
threats:
Por ser uma espécie migradora é amplamente afetada pelos barramentos existentes na bacia do rio São Francisco e não estabelece populações em reservatórios.

Na região do médio-alto São Francisco é alvo de pesca intensiva principalmente durante o período de reprodução (Oficina de avaliação 2011).
population: Existem registros e relatos de declínio populacional em diversos trechos da bacia, especialmente no baixo rio São Francisco, em função da construção das grandes barragens. Considerando que, atualmente, a espécie se encontra em apenas 50% de sua AOO e EOO originais, estima-se que a população tenha declinado pelo menos 50% em tamanho ao longo dos últimos 30 anos ou três gerações (Oficina de avaliação 2011).
range: Conorhynchos conirostris é endêmica da bacia do rio São Francisco. Registros recentes e mais significativos provêm do médio-alto São Francisco, desde a jusante da barragem da UHE Três Marias até o remanso da UHE Sobradinho. Ocorre em certa abundância no baixo curso dos rios Paracatu e Urucuia, onde é capturada com mais frequência durante o período reprodutivo. Brasil-Sato e dos Santos (2005), em trabalho para a investigação de parasitofauna da espécie, informam espécimes coletadas no alto rio São Francisco, município de Três Marias, Minas Gerais. Em 2010, a equipe técnica do Centro Nacional de Pesquisa e Conservação da Biodiversidade Aquática Continental (CEPTA/ICMBio), em expedição ao rio Paracatu, coletou cerca de 30 indivíduos, que estão sendo mantidos nas dependências do CEPTA, em Pirassununga (SP). Exemplares de C. conirostris não são mais capturados em coletas do alto rio São Francisco, acima da barragem da UHE Três Marias (CEMIG 2011). Na região do baixo São Francisco não existem registros há mais de 20 anos (Costa 2003). Desde 1999, não existem registros de exemplares da espécie em amplas coletas no rio das Velhas, assim como nas frequentes mortandades que ocorrem nessa drenagem (C.B.M. Alves com. pess. 2011).
useTrade: Na região do médio-alto São Francisco é alvo de pesca intensiva principalmente durante o período de reprodução (Oficina de avaliação 2011).
conservationActions:
Indivíduos de C. conirostris foram mantidos em cativeiro pela Companhia de Desenvolvimento do Vale do São Francisco (CODEVASF), onde foram realizadas reproduções induzidas. Exemplares oriundos da reprodução em cativeiro foram usados em reintroduções (peixamentos) em diversas áreas da bacia, mas sem acompanhamento posterior. Há necessidade de monitorar a pesca sobre a espécie e usar os dados obtidos para manejo, como cotas de captura, tamanhos mínimos e máximos e conservação efetiva (Oficina de avaliação 2011). Conorhynchos conirostris é listada como espécie-alvo do Plano de Ação Nacional para a Conservação das Espécies Ameaçadas de Extinção da Fauna Aquática da Bacia do Rio São Francisco - PAN São Francisco (ICMBio 2015). Não há registros de presença em unidades de conservação. São necessárias pesquisas que incluem a elucidação da distribuição atual, avaliações populacionais e a identificação das áreas de desova com vistas à conservação (Oficina de avaliação 2011).

Esta avaliação da Lista Vermelha de Espécies Ameaçadas de Extinção global foi originalmente concluída como parte do processo de avaliação do Livro Vermelho da Fauna Brasileira Ameaçada de Extinção (Instituto Chico Mendes de Conservação da Biodiversidade (ICMBio) 2018).

rationale:
Xenotoca variata is an endemic freshwater species that occurs throughout the highland waters of central Mexico, encompassing habitats over a range from 250km from W to E and 500km from N to S. However, it disappeared from many habitats due to water pollution and predatory Largemouth Bass and nowadays mainly persists in clear springs, creeks, dams and lakes. Again, the Jeweled Splitfin encompasses a second to be described species from the Río Grande de Morelia drainage.


Even when taking in consideration the given threats, declines in AOO, EOO, locations, habitats and even subpopulations, and taking Xenotoca cf. variata out from the calculations, the remaining AOO encompasses about 4,800km², the remaining EOO about 100,000km², including at least 25 locations. Including Xenotoca cf. variata, the AOO encompassess about 5,600km², the EOO about 112, 000km². Therefore, as no threat tresholds are met, the Jeweled Splitfin is assessed of Least Concern.


A separate assessment for the Lake Cuitzeo Jeweled Splitfin would lead to an AOO of about 800km² and an EOO of about 2,200km². Taking in consideration less than 10 locations, it would be assessed Vulnerable. Therefore, a quick valid description would be preferable.
habitat:
The Jeweled Splitfin prefers habitats like clear to murky rivers and lakes with currents of moderate to absent. It can be detected in shallow water (less than 1m deep) over substrates from deep mud to rocks. Usually, vegetation is abundant. Plant genera have been (besides much floating or attached green algae) Potamogeton, Eichhornia, Nasturtium and Myriophyllum (Miller, 2005). It is an omnivorous species and males show bright and colourful spots (speckles) on their flanks, which vary in number based one their geographical location. It is known to mainly be predated by Thamnophis melanogaster. The risk of predation by this snake species is thought to potentially influence the selection against speckles and produce population differentiation (Moyaho, Macias Garcia and Manjarrez, 2004).

The Lagos Los Negritos is an irregular shaped pond with a diameter between 570 and 830m. The N corner is surrounded by reed, the rest partly shaded by pine trees. On a survey by Köck et al. in 2016, Xenotoca variata could be found along the pebbly shore and was caught with a seine. Other fish occuring in this habitat were Chapalichthys encaustus, Zoogoneticus purhepechus, Goodea atripinnis, Alloophorus robustus, Poeciliopsis infans and exotics (Tilapia, Sunfish, Gambusia sp.). Some smaller ponds and spring fields have not been surveyed.

The Lago Zacapú is an irregular shaped small lagoon with an extension from the NW to the SW, length about 670, width about 470m. In the SW corner of the lake begins the dammed outlet, extending ENE upward over a length of about 800m and 60m wide over the whole length. The outlet ends with a southwards bended hook with an extension of 150x90m. After the dam, the affluent of the Canal or Río Angulo begins and merges into it after about 6.5km. Köck et al. (2014, 2015, 2016 and 2017) found the species in good numbers on two sites of the lagoon in shallow water in the free water column. The water was on one place greenish brown but clear with little current and partly shaded by trees, on the other place brownish clear, current none as well. Other species found at the first spot were Skiffia lermae, Zoogoneticus quitzeoensis, Goodea atripinnis, Allotoca zacapuensis and Hubbsina turneri, at the second site the same species except the Zacapú Allotoca. 

The Lago Zacapú is fed by approximately 20 cold water springs (19°C), which emerge at the southwestern end of the valley of Zacapú, some of which are used for human consumption and recreation (Ramsar Secretariat, Site No.1465, 2004). Also, with the confluence of fish species, migratory birds, plants and endemic amphibians (Ambystoma andersoni), it can be considered as a broad transitional zone, giving it great ecological importance. Two main sections of Lago Zacapú differ, with one of depths between 4 to 6m, and the other region from 12 to 90m deep, bedded by soils and alluvium (Ramsar Secretariat, Site No.1465, 2004).

The spring habitat near Sain Alto encompassed on a survey by Köck et al. in 2015 several shallow ditches with moderate current, not deeper than 20cm, wide about 30cm. On some places, the ditches opened to larger pools of several metres in diameter, still being very shallow. The spring itself had a temperature of about 38°C. Fish were seen as soon as the temperature reached convenient temperature below 28°C. The Jeweled Splitfin was the only species in these ditches.

The species was seen on several places by Köck et al. on two surveys in 2017 along the ríos Turbio, Guanajuato and Laja, encompassing moderate flowing parts of fast flowing creeks. The habitats were usually composed of grounds with sand, gravel and rocks, abundant green algae where the fish used to hide below. Along the Río Turbio, it was even found directly in a man-made spring near the Arroyo Cerro la Cruz and in the following dam. Both stocks looked different in colouration due to different habitats. The fish in the clear spring were beautifully coloured while the fish from the turbid dam looked more dull.

La Mintzita, habitat of the related Xenotoca cf. variata, is a marshy spring–fed lake of about 80m diameter that drains into the Río Grande de Morelia and hence into the Lago Cuitzeo. The Río Grande de Morelia/Cuitzeo basin is endorheic, although its fauna indicates that it was once connected to the adjacent Río Lerma basin. Most of the Río Grande de Morelia/Cuitzeo system has been greatly degraded, and La Mintzita is one of the last remaining high-quality sites in the basin. A few hundred metres below the lake the outlet canal receives wastes from a large paper mill (Bio Papel Scribe S.A. de C.V.) and no longer has the capability to support fish life, so La Mintzita is isolated from other fish populations in the basin. Lyons et al. (2004) sampled the outlet canal just below the lake with a backpack electroshocker and the lake itself just above the outlet with a seine. The canal was about 8m wide and 0.5-1m deep with a fast strong current and gravel bottom. In 80m of sampling, they collected the following Goodeids: 3 Alloophrous robustus, 30 Goodea atripinnis, about 100 Xenotoca cf. variata, 5 Skiffia lermae, and about 15 Zoogoneticus quitzeoensis. They also caught 10 Poeciliopsis infans (Poeciliidae; native) and about 25 Xiphophorus helleri (an exotic Poeciliid), plus 10 Yuriria alta (Cyprinidae; native) and 10 Scartomyzon austrinus. They then pulled the seine over about 300m2 in the lake, which averaged about 1m deep with a sand and clay bottom and clear water at 15-19°C temperature. They captured 3 A. robustus, 5 G. atripinnis, 30 X. cf. variata, about 100 S. lermae, 3 Z. quitzeoensis, plus at least 1,000 P. infans, 5 X. helleri, and 30 Y. alta (Lyons, 2004).

This species can be found also in the Cuitzeo lake, the oldest and second largest Mexican lake that covers an area of about 500km² including the marshy grass surrounding it. It is irregular shaped with northern, western an eastern sections, connected by marshland in the middle. The W-section is divided into an E- and a W-part by two N-S dams, built for HW's 43 and 43B. The lake is astatic and very shallow (about 0.5m deep), of muddy ground with murky water. In dry years, the W-part of the W section is being isolated completely from the E-part by closing the passages under the roads to save the W-section from drying up completely. With this method, at least the E-part of the W-section keeps water. The lake is surrounded by partly dense and large reed areas. In open water areas directly at the HW43B dam, Köck et al. were able to find many specimens on a survey in November 2014, but fewer in January 2015.


Pictures of habitats attached.
threats: Though the Jeweled Splitfin is a robust fish species, it has been eliminated from many habitats by water pollution and is still threatened by it. It is able to compete with most of the introduced exotic fish species, but is predated by Largemouth Bass and disappeared from habitats where this species has been introduced. The centre of the species, the Río Lerma basin and its affluents from Guanajuato is the centre of agriculture and heavily modified and destroyed. Most of the bigger rivers are biologically dead and the species is only able to survive in its headwaters, even here threatened by pollution or introduced Sunfish and Largemouth Bass. Guanajuato is also boasting some of the biggest cities in Mexico, all of them fast growing with industrial areas on its borders. Some of the known habitats are simply overgrown by the cities. A channel, connecting the Laguna Yuriría with the Lago Cuitzeo lake was built to provide the lagoon with water. At this time (1957) it was not expected to find two species of Xenotoca within these two water bodies. It is not sure if this connection led to any hybrids, however, Xenotoca variata from the Yuriría disappared due to water pollution which means a certain degree of safety for the remaining related species in the Cuitzeo lake.
population:
As the Jeweled Splitfin is distributed over a wide range and does occur in many different subpopulations with different status, it becomes necessary to estimate the situation of each of these subpopulations separately. Taking in consideration, that two species and different lineages are encompassed within Xenotoca variata, the taxonomic concept is the following here.

Xenotoca variata (with an EOOmax of about 100,000km² and an AOOmax of 4,800km²):

Clade A
Río Grande de Santiago/ Laguna Chapala subpopulation: This subpopulation has gone from a huge part of its original range and is now restricted to the Lagos Los Negritos ponds about 25km SE of the Chapala lake. A habitat range below 0.5km² and a single location lead to an assessment as Critically Endangered.    
Clade B
Río Aguanaval subpopulation: This subpopulation is known from two spring areas. One is in the village of La Valenciana only about 20km from the border to Durango, the second one close to Sain Alto, about 60km NW of Fresnillo, both within the federal state of Zacatecas. Restricted to two spring areas, this subpopulation is regarded Endangered.    
Clade C
Río Angulo subpopulation: It is still numerous within the Lago Zacapú and in springs and creeks located along the Río Angulo and the Canal La Patera. It is regarded Vulnerable.    
Clade D
Río Santa María subpopulation: It only occurs in a restricted range along the Río Santa María, being threatened by droughts. It is regarded Endangered.
Middle Río Lerma subpopulation: on surveys by Köck et al. in 2017, it was found in several spring areas within the ríos Laja, Turbio and Guanajuato drainages, but all of them small or moderate. Being fragmented due to heavily polluted rivers downstream. it is regarded Vulnerable.
Río Verde subpopulation: It is still known from a few spring areas, dams and creeks in the headwaters of the ríos San Juan de Los Lagos and Verde. Due to heavy declines within the last decades, it is regarded Endangered
Lower Río Lerma subppulation: no collection sites of this subpopulatio are known, so it is regarded possibly Extinct.
Laguna Yuriría subpopulation: The species is no more mentioned from this lagoon (Estrada-Cortés, 2016), so it has to be regarded possibly Extinct.

Xenotoca cf. variata (with an EOOmax of 2,200km² and AOOmax of 800km²):

Río Grande de Morelia subpopulation: This to be described species occurs in the Lago Cuitzeo, the Presa Cointzio and several spring habitats close to the river or the lake (manantiales La Mintzita, Borbollon, San Cristobal). Due to sveral locations and different threat status, it is regarded Vulnerable.
range:
The Jeweled Splitfin is a freshwater fish endemic to the Mexican federal states of San Luis Potosí, Querétaro, Michoacán, Jalisco, Aguascalientes, Guanajuato and Zacatecas. It historically occured in the Middle Río Lerma drainage including all affluents like the bigger rivers (ríos Laja, Guanajuato and Turbio), in the Laguna Yuriría, in the Río Angulo drainage (including the Lago Zacapú) and in  headwaters of the ríos Santa María (Río Panuco drainage) and Verde (affluent of the lower Río Lerma). Vouchers indicate that this species also populated the lower Rio Lerma basin including the Río Duero and the Río Grande de Santiago/ Laguna Chapala basin (where it still can be found in the Lagos Los Negritos ponds), but it seems to be completely extirpated from these areas except for the Lagos Los Negritos. It is additionally known from springs within the ríos El Muerto and Frío drainages, affluents of the endorheic Río Aguanaval in Zacatecas. Specimens from the endorheic Río Grande de Morelia basin (including the Lago Cuitzeo and the Presa Cointzio) belong to a distinct species, that is not yet described validly (only in a Mexican thesis by Domínguez-Domínguez, 2008, which officially doesn't count as publication due to Mexican law).

It is highly tolerant of pollution and habitat modifications and, along with Goodea atripinnis, still persists in areas where other Goodeid species have been eliminated. Xenotoca variata is currently found at more than 30 sites throughout its historic range. Nonetheless, the species has declined in recent years, disappearing from heavily polluted areas of the Santiago and Lerma basins and from reservoir and lake habitats where the non-native largemouth black bass has become established (Lyons et al., 1998; Soto-Galera et al., 1998, 1999; Domínguez-Domínguez et al., 2005; Mercado-Silva et al., 2006). 

In 2008, an estimation resulted in the disappearance of the Jeweled Splitfin from more than the 45% of its historical range (Domínguez-Domínguez et al., 2008).

The underlined names are the ones officially used by the Instituto Nacional de Estadística y Geografía (http://antares.inegi.org.mx); nevertheless, other ones might be more often in use or better known and therefore prefered.
useTrade: The Jeweled Splitfin is not used for consumption and not targeted for the ornamental fish trade.
conservationActions: No species targeted conservation actions for the jeweled Splifin are known, but the species occurs at two Ramsar sites: La Mintzita spring (Ramsar Archive, Site No.1919, 2009) and Lago Zacapú (Ramsar Secretariat, Site No.1465, 2004), with the restriction, that the first site concerns a distinct to be described species, actually still encompassed within Xenotoca variata.

rationale: Listed as Data Deficient on the basis that this species is known from fewer than 15 specimens collected across a wide area over more than 120 years, and while the known localities are in areas under pressure from human activities and the species may have been lost from the heavily converted island of Hainan, there is no data on rates of either historical or ongoing population decline and the species' ecology remains insufficiently known.
habitat: This aquatic species is mainly associated with forest streams and does not appear to persist in modified habitats. It is oviparous. The diet consists of fishes, frogs and tadpoles.
threats: This snake is threatened by habitat loss resulting from channelization, pollution, irrigation schemes and development of hydropower stations. Hainan has been continuously surveyed over several decades and it may be that the species is extinct here, but insufficient data is available on population trends in China as a whole (J.L. Ren pers. comm. 2019). Coal mining and cultivation is ongoing in northern Viet Nam, and presumed to represent a major threat to this species (Q.T. Nguyen pers. comm. 2019).
population: This is a rare species. Despite surveys undertaken in areas where the species had previously been recorded in both mainland China and Hainan, the only recent records of this species from China are three specimens (two from Dinghui District in Guangdong, and one from Guangxi) reported by Ren et al. (2019), and a specimen from southern Hunan province reported by Shen et al. (2014), north of the other known localities, whose identity requires confirmation (Ren et al. 2019). Reports from Hunan reported by Ye and Deng (1997) do not agree with Trimerodytes balteatus and probably represent Opisthotropis cheni (Ren et al. 2019), To date, only 11 Chinese specimens are known (J-L. Ren pers. comm. 2019). Two specimens collected in 2006-2007, both from the same locality (Nguyen et al. 2014), are the only confirmed records from Viet Nam since the species was first reported from this country by Smith (1943).
range: This species has been reported from China (Hainan, Guangdong, Guangxi and Hong Kong) (it is also known from Hunan, but the exact locality is unclear and it is not mapped here); northern Viet Nam and Cambodia (Nguyen et al. 2009). The record from Cambodia, based on three specimens reported in 1906, is far from other known localities and is considered likely to be erroneous by Ren et al. (2019) and workers in this country (N. Thy pers. comm. 2019). Vietnamese records are known from "Tong-King" (=Tonkin) and from Yen Tu Mountain in Bac Giang Province (Nguyen et al. 2014), and a questionable record from Hai Phong reported by Nguyen et al. (2009) (and accepted by Ren et al. 2019). It is found at elevations from sea level to around 450 m asl.
useTrade: There are no reports of this species being utilized.
conservationActions: No species-specific conservation measures are in place. It is present in some protected areas, including Tay Ten Tu Nature Reserve in Viet Nam (Nguyen et al. 2014). There is a need to maintain areas of suitable habitat for this species. Further studies are needed into the distribution and ecology of this species (Ren et al. 2019).

rationale: This species is listed as Near Threatened because its Extent of Occurrence is probably not much greater than 20,000 km<sup>2</sup>, and the extent and quality of its habitat are probably declining, thus making the species close to qualifying for Vulnerable under criterion B1.
habitat: This species has been recorded living near streams in both forest and open areas. It might feed on semi-aquatic annelids. There is no information on reproduction (Zhao 2006).
threats: The construction of hydroelectric plants in areas where this species occurs is a threat.
population: This is a rare species.
range: Found in its type locality: Mount Yao (Dayao Shan), Jinxiu, Guangxi Zhuang Automonous Region, China (Zhao and Adler 1993). It has also been recorded from Guangdong (Kadoorie Farm and Botanic Garden, 2004). Zhao (2006) also mentioned Hunan which has no reference and might be an error. It is found at elevations of 950 to 1,220 m asl.
useTrade: There are no reports of this species being utilised.
conservationActions: No conservation actions are currently known for this species, although it does occur in some nature reserves. More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, natural history and threats.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large overall population, it occurs in a number of protected areas, has a tolerance of a degree of habitat modification, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
habitat: It is associated with streams and can be found in habitats ranging from forest to traditional agricultural fields. It is an oviparous species. The diet includes freshwater shrimps.
threats: It may be impacted by habitat degradation such as the development of hydroelectric dams.
population: This is a fairly common species.
range: This species is distributed in China (Guangxi, Guizhou, Hunan, Hong Kong) and Viet Nam (Cao Bang [Nguyen Binh], Lang Son [Mau Son], Vinh Phuc [Tam Dao], Hoa Binh [Thuong Tien], Quang Ninh [Ban Sen, Lam Ca, Nam Son], Hai Duong [Chi Linh] [Nguyen et al., 2009]). This species is found at elevations of 100 to 800m asl.
useTrade: There are no reports of this species being utilized.
conservationActions: No species-specific conservation measures are in place. It is found in many protected areas.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
habitat: This species is often found in streams, either in water or under stones. It also inhabits ditches and rice paddies. It feeds on aquatic worms. It is oviparous, and in Fujian it has been reported to lay eggs in August (Zhao 2006).
threats: There are no major threats to this species. Small hydroelectric powerplants, and the associated dams, may represent localized threats (M. Lau pers. comm. September 2011).
population: This is a very common species.
range: This snake is widespread in southeastern China, where it has been reported from Jiugongshan Provincial Nature Reserve, Hubei Province (Yang et al. 1999) as well as from the provinces of Anhui, Chongqin, Fujian, Guangdong, Guangxi, Guizhou, Hunan, Jiangxi and Zhejiang (Zhao 2006). It also occurs in Hong Kong. It has an estimated extent of occurrence of 920,000 km2. It occurs from 600 to 1,424 m asl.
useTrade: There are no reports of this species being utilized.
conservationActions: No conservation actions are currently known for this species, although it is likely to occur in some nature reserves due to its wide distribution. More information is needed on this species' population status and natural history.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population, and occurrence within protected areas. There is considerable variation in terms of both threats to the habitat and to the species across its distribution. Thus, particular subpopulations may be of concern especially as the taxonomy is re-evaluated.
habitat:
Desert Iguana habitat most often consists of sandy arroyos or other open areas with loose soils, but sometimes the species occurs on nearby rocky hillsides (Norris 1953; Grismer 2002, 2004). In most of its range, Desert Iguanas are typically found in Creosote Bush desert with hummocks of loose sand and patches of firm ground with scattered rocks, whereas in southern Baja they occur in subtropical arid shrub habitats (Norris 1953, Stebbins 2003, Venegas-Barrera et al. 2008). These lizards seek shelter both from heat and predators in rodent burrows or rock crevices (Grismer 2002, Revell 2005), and they may climb into bushes (Stebbins 2003).

The Desert Iguana is generally active from April-September, with limited activity at other times of the year dependent on environmental temperature, with the exception of populations on Catalina Island that are active throughout the year (Grismer 2004, Revell 2005, Venegas-Barrera et al. 2008). No specific information on hibernation is available. Activity patterns also vary throughout the day; individuals tend to bask early in the morning and are more likely to enter burrows later in the day (Grismer 2004).

The mean home range size of Desert Iguanas varies greatly among individuals (201–4,244 m2), but also differs among sexes (M = 1,462 m2, F = 1,558 m2; Krekorian 1976). Conversely, there does not seem to be much sexual dimorphism in body size, including snout-vent length, head length, or head width (Dibble et al. 2008). Mean snout-vent length across the range is 115.43 mm, with a maximum of 148 mm (M. Packer et al. unpublished data). Males in Palm Springs, CA, had a mean body mass of 70.0 g with a range from 48.4 to 92.0 g (Singleton and McGarland 2018).

The Desert Iguana reproduces annually across its range (Mayhew 1971, Pianka 1971). The average size at reproduction was found to be 120 mm (females) and 127 mm (males) snout-vent length (Mayhew 1971). Clutch size can range from 3–8 eggs (Norris 1953). Once laid, the length of egg incubation ranges from 45–80 days until hatch (Krekorian 1984), and hatchlings are at least 47 mm snout-vent length before day seven (Parker 1972).

Generally an herbivore, the majority of Desert Iguanas’ diet is made up of plants, with insects contributing little overall dietary volume (Dibble et al. 2008). Examples of food items include leaves, seeds, and Cardon Cactus fruit (island populations), as well as ants, termites, and beetles (Grismer 2004, Dibble et al. 2008).

Desert Iguanas demonstrate a wariness for predators including escape behaviour into bushes and burrows, which can vary depending on the ambient temperature and also the speed of predator approach (Cooper Jr. 2003). Common predators include both birds (Revell 2005, Carbajal-Marquez et al. 2012) and snake species (e.g., Sidewinder; Avila-Villegas et al. 2007).
threats: In some areas, especially around the Tucson and Phoenix, Arizona, suburban communities, habitat has been lost or degraded as a result of conversion to human uses (agriculture, road construction, and commercial, energy production, and residential development). Populations along busy highways and newly paved byways presumably have been reduced as a result of road mortality and destruction of burrows that desert iguanas build inside the dirt berms. These threats remain in a limited, although increasingly substantial, portion of the overall range. There are added concerns for island populations including climate change-induced severe drought and temperature extremes that are likely affecting populations adversely, as has been documented in other iguana species (Sauromalus) from the islands (Case 1982).
population: The Desert Iguana is represented in museums by hundreds of collection sites throughout its range in the United States and Mexico (e.g., see Hulse 1992). The total adult population size is unknown but probably exceeds 100,000 adults. This lizard is noted as very common in northeastern Baja California (Grismer 2002) and in similar Creosote Bush desert habitats in southeastern California, southern Nevada, and western Arizona. Since then, habitat conversion due to continued development throughout their range has led to localized declines in areas of human occupancy. Population size declines have occurred where habitats have been lost or degraded due to urbanization, particularly in the southwestern US and Baja. The species is present in several protected areas in the United States and México. Little quantitative information is available on population densities; however, it is known that density across the distribution is not uniform (C. Malone pers. obs.). One study calculated juvenile densities in Arizona, which fluctuated from 11/hectare in late spring to 20/hectare in fall (Parker 1972).
range: The Desert Iguana ranges widely in the southwestern United States, northwestern mainland Mexico, and the Baja Peninsula. Its range encompasses: southern Nevada; extreme southwestern Utah along the Virgin River in the vicinity of Beaver Dam Wash; northwest, central, and southern Arizona; southern California east of the Sierra Nevada and coast mountain ranges; southward into Mexico through northeastern Baja California, all of southern Baja California (excluding most of the Vizcaíno Desert), and western Sonora to northern Sinaloa. This lizard occurs on many islands in the Gulf of California and on Magdalena and Santa Margarita islands along the Pacific coast of Baja California, occurring most densely in sand habitats (Norris 1953, Hulse 1992, Grismer 2002, Stebbins 2003). The elevational range extends from below sea level in desert sinks (~ 40 m bsl) to about 1,520 m asl (Stebbins 2003).
useTrade: There is very limited pet trade data from Mexico and the United States. There is documented international trade with unknown effects on the population size (Williams 2017).
conservationActions:
Desert Iguanas are not protected by either United States or Mexican Law. They are found in protected areas in the United States, as well as the Gulf of California. Specifically, its range extends into several national parks and monuments, and federal wilderness areas (e.g., Mojave National Park, Joshua Tree National Monument, Anza Borrego Desert State Park, Kofa National Wildlife Refuge, Organ Pipe Cactus National Monument, Cabeza Prieta Wilderness, and Ironwood Forest National Monument). In Mexico, parts of the lizard's range is in the Bahía de Loreto National Park and the Área de Protección de Flora y Fauna Islas del Golfo de California which confers federal protection. The island populations are also included in the Gulf of California regional management plan for the protection of flora and fauna (Carabias Lillo et al. 2000), as well as a management plan for the Bahia de Loreto National Park (Bermúdez-Almada et al. 2002).

More research is needed concerning population sizes and trends, as well as threat assessment throughout the range. Particular regard should be given to the two different clades within the genus, as threats and protective areas vary spatially. Conservation measures may thus be relevant for subpopulations of the Desert Iguana.

rationale: The Upland Lonjaw Galaxias (Galaxias prognathus) is a non-migratory galaxiid endemic to the South Island, New Zealand, where it occurs in the upper reaches of three Canterbury rivers (the Rakaia, Rangitata and Waitaki rivers). It was also historically present in the upper Maruia River and a tributary of the Hurunui River, but it now believed to have been extirpated from these two northern-most catchments. The extent of occurrence (EOO) is calculated as 1,626 km2. The area of occupancy (AOO) is 5.7 km2 and the distribution of this species within its current range is severely fragmented. Very little information is available on the population trends for this species. However, the sub-populations in the Waitaki and Rangitata catchment are certainly declining. This species is assessed as Nationally Vulnerable according to the New Zealand Department of Conservation's threat classification system, based on a moderate population size of between 1000-5000 mature individuals that is declining, with a predicted decline of 10-50%. This species occurs in mid-high altitude streams where the headwaters of spring-fed streams are critical habitats (potentially for spawning) for this species. These habitats are relatively rare and the loss of further critical habitat through land use changes associated with land development is the principle threat to this species. The current population declines in the Waitaki and Rangitata catchments are attributed to land use changes caused by agricultural development. Historically, hydro electric development also negatively impacted the population of this species in the Waitaki catchment. Additionally, G. prognathus is very susceptible to predation by Brown Trout (Salmo trutta), which occurs throughout much of this species' range. The protection of rare spring headwater habitats that are critical to the survival of this species is needed. Sub-populations at higher elevations may be afforded some protection due to the remoteness of their location due to limited agricultural development and the absence of salmonids from these headwater regions. This species is assessed as Critically Endangered based on an area of occupancy of 5.7 km2 and a severely fragmented population with a continuing decline in extent of occurrence, area of occupancy, quality of habitat, number of sub-populations and number of mature individuals.
habitat: G. prognathus is a non-migratory galaxiid that occurs in mid-high altitude (lower limit 450 metres above sea level) streams draining to the east coast of the South Island. The preferred habitat for this species is the quiet headwaters of spring-fed streams. These habitats are critical for this species (potentially for spawning), however they are also relatively rare habitats. The maximum total length of this species is 80 mm and it is relatively short-lived with a life span of 3 years. Adults mature at 1 year of age and the generation length is 2 years. Spawning occurs in spring, from October to November (NIWA 2013, McDowall 2000). Only about 100-300 eggs are produced.
threats: The principle threat to this species is the loss of critical spring-head habitats through land use changes associated with land development. The current population declines in the Waitaki and Rangitata catchments are attributed to land use changes caused by agricultural development. Historically, hydro electric development also negatively impacted the population of this species. Additionally, G. prognathus is very susceptible to predation by Brown Trout (Salmo trutta), which occurs throughout much of this species' range.
population: Very little information is available on the population trends for this species, however the sub-populations in the Waitaki and Rangitata catchments are certainly declining. This species is assessed as Nationally Vulnerable according to the New Zealand Department of Conservation's threat classification system, based on a moderate population size of between 1000-5000 mature individuals that is declining, with a predicted decline of 10-50% (Goodman et al. 2014).
range: The Upland Lonjaw Galaxias (Galaxias prognathus) is endemic to the South Island, New Zealand, where it occurs in the upper reaches of three Canterbury rivers (the Rakaia, Rangitata and Waitaki rivers). It was also historically present in the Marui and Hurunui rivers, but it has been extirpated from these two northern-most catchments (Department of Conservation 2004). The extent of occurrence (EOO) is calculated as 1,626 km2 (NZFFD 2011, FENZ 2010). The area of occupancy (AOO) is 5.7 km2 (NZFFD 2011, FENZ 2010) and the distribution of this species within its current range is considered severely fragmented. Area of occupancy was calculated from the sum of the lengths x the estimated stream widths of river reaches in which this species is recorded in the National New Zealand Freshwater Fish Database (NZFFD 2011). Extent of occurrence was calculated using an intersection of New Zealand Freshwater Fish database records and spatial representations (polygons) of Freshwater Ecosystems of New Zealand; 3rd-4th order river catchments (FENZ 2010, NZFFD 2011).
useTrade: This species is not utilized.
conservationActions: The protection of rare spring headwater habitats that are critical to the survival of this species is needed. Sub-populations at higher elevations may be afforded some protection due to the remoteness of their location.

rationale: The species has experienced a range-wide accelerating decline from overcollection and habitat degradation and loss amounting to an estimated 90% or more over the past two generations (25 years generation time). These impacts likely to continue for the foreseeable future, so Sacalia quadriocellata qualifies for listing as CR A2cd+A4cd.
habitat: Sacalia quadriocellata inhabits fairly large streams including waterfall plunge pools in hill forest areas at moderate altitudes. In China, it is found at elevations below 500 m asl. It is documented at elevations 160 to 700 m above sea level in Viet Nam and Hainan (Gong et al. 2005; McCormack and Hoang per. comm. 2018). This species has an estimated 6–9 years age at maturity, longevity likely 40–45 years, and generation time estimated 25 years. Clutch size ranges from one to four eggs; single clutches observed in northern Viet Nam, but multiple clutches have been indicated further south (McCormack and Hoang per. comm. 2018).
threats: Collection intensity for Sacalia quadriocellata has increased in recent years, including the use of electrofishing techniques. Habitat degradation and loss impact the species, in particular damming and hydropower development.
population: Sacalia quadriocellata is likely to remain in small numbers of scattered individuals in most of the remaining areas of suitable habitat, now nominally protected areas, throughout its range in Viet Nam and Lao PDR. They used to be relatively common in many areas around 2000, but price has gone up since about 2012 suggesting increased scarcity and/or demand. Juveniles have been recorded during surveys in Viet Nam (McCormick and Hoang pers. comm. 2018). The Hainan subpopulation is apparently almost completely depleted (Fong pers. com. 2018). Overall it appears that it has declined by 90 per cent range-wide over the past two generations (50 years) due to recently intensified collection on top of habitat degradation and destruction.
range: Sacalia quadriocellata occurs in southern mainland China (Guangdong and Guangxi), Hainan (China), eastern Lao PDR and Viet Nam. It occurs in both the east-flowing Annamite drainages as well as upper reaches of Mekong tributaries in Lao PDR. It ranges as far south in Viet Nam as Khanh Hoa.
useTrade: Traditionally Sacalia quadriocellata was not often seen in trade as demand was low because the meat is not favourable. Prices have steeply increased since about 2012, suggesting increased demand.
conservationActions: Sacalia quadriocellata has been listed on CITES Appendix II since 2013. The primary conservation measure needed for S. quadriocellata (and many other species and their ecosystem) is the creation of secure, adequately managed protected areas with suitable habitat. Surveys to evaluate the status and occurrence of populations can be integrated into broader biodiversity surveys. It is also necessary for enhanced enforcement relating to illegal trade.

rationale: This species is listed as Endangered due to its very limited distribution (with an extent of occurrence of 50 km2); occurrence in two locations; ongoing threats from grazing, persecution for the pet trade, and a planned hydroelectric facility; low population density, and ongoing population decline. A tiny population apparently persists in a protected area, but it may not be viable. This species is a candidate for ex situ conservation. The recent failure to record it at El Volcan may suggest the species has been lost from this locality; if future research confirms this, the species will warrant immediate listing as Critically Endangered.
habitat: This species is found on rocky slopes with shrubby vegetation and cypress forest patches in the Cordillera. It feeds on insects and reproduces oviparously (Lamborot and Díaz 1987, Troncoso 2010, Ministerio del Medio Ambiente 2014).
threats: This species' range is restricted to areas highly susceptible to human activity. Harvesting for the pet trade appears to have caused significant historical population declines. Other threats include overgrazing by goats, habitat destruction for tourism development, mining, and predation by domestic cats (Troncoso 2010, Ministerio del Ambiente 2014). A hydroelectric project also threatens the species.
population: This species was once  (in the 1980s) regularly recorded but rare within its small range but then declined precipitously after it was persecuted for the pet trade. The species was not found in either 2006 and 2014 in El Volcán in the habitats where it was formally found. A small population is thought to persist in the only other place where the species is known, the Rio Clarillo National Reserve. These observations suggest that the species has declined substantially in the last few decades.
range: This species is endemic to Chile where it is known from El Volcán (Maipo Valley) and the Rio Clarillo National Reserve, both in the Metropolitan Region, between 1,416 and 2,200 m asl (Troncoso 2010, Ministerio del Ambiente 2014).
useTrade: The species has been collected for the pet trade (Troncoso 2010), at least formerly "in large numbers" (IUCN SSC and TRAFFIC 1994)
conservationActions:
This species occurs in the Rio Clarillo National Reserve. Due to the intense threats to the species and very limited distribution, ex situ conservation should be considered.

The proposed classification for the species by the Chilean government is Endangered (EN) B1ab(iii)+2ab(iii) (Ministerio del Ambiente 2014).

rationale: This species is listed as Near Threatened in view of its reliance on areas of hot springs at high altitudes (a restricted area of occupancy), although its extent of occurrence is much larger than 20,000 km<sup>2</sup>, and its population is is estimated to number 13,000 individuals, the extent and quality of its habitat is potentially threatened because of the construction of geo-thermal hydro-electric stations and human disturbance. It almost qualifies for a threatened listing under criterion B2ab(iii).
habitat: Very little information is available for this species. They live in rocks, streams, marshes and meadows near hot springs of 3,000 to 4,900 m altitude. Li (2007) found that this species mainly feeds on alpine frogs (Nanorana parkeri) and fish (Schizothorax o’connon and Triplophysa spp.) The female lays around six eggs. It might be ovoviparous.
threats: The species is threatened through the potential construction of geo-thermal hydro-electric stations and human disturbance.
population: Because of construction of geo-thermal hydro-electric stations and human disturbance, the population of this species is decreasing (Guo and Chen 2000). The population was estimated as 13,000 individuals (State Forestry Administration of China 2009).
range: This species has been recorded from Jiangzi, Gongbujiangda, Dangxiong-Yangbajin, Lhasa, Mozhugongka, Shigatse of Xizang (= Tibet), China (Guo and Chen 2000). It has been recorded along the Brahmaputra River in Xizang (= Tibet). It is found at elevations of 3,000 to 4,440 m asl.
useTrade: There are no reports of this species being utilized.
conservationActions: No conservation actions are currently known for this species. More information is needed on this species' population dynamics, natural history and threats. It is not known if the species is present in any protected areas.

rationale:
The Relict Splitfin is a freshwater fish endemic to the Mexican federal state of San Luis Potosí. It was historically known from the headwaters of the Río Santa María (downstreams to just below Santa María del Río) the Río Pánuco drainage, including its main source in the mountains, in addition to the Río Altamira and the Río Villela (Río Tierra Quemada), just below Santa María del Río. It also occurrs in two affluents of the endorheic Río Matehuala at Venado and Moctezuma and the also endorheic springs at Illescas. It was extirpated from the springs at Illesacas due to water over exploitation and reduced to remnant stocks within the other populated drainages due to water pollution, water over exploitation and competition through non-native fish and droughts.

The worst case scenario for AOO (28 km2) and EOO (4,000 km2) meet the thresholds for Endangered (AOO: 500 km2; EOO: 5,000 km2). Taking into consideration the given threats, only two locations and severe declines in EOO, AOO, subpopulations, locations, habitats and the quality of the habitats, the Relict Splitfin is assessed Endangered.
habitat:
The Relict Splifin uses habitats of springs and their outflows, small streams and ditches. This species lives over substrates of silt, mud, clay, sand, gravel and rocks in clear to murky water. It prefers depths of less than 1 m with slight to moderate currents. Aquatic vegetation is typically comprised of ubiquitous green algae and Lemna, Eichhornia, Ceratophyllum, Nasturtium and Potamogeton (Miller 2005).

Köck et al. (2014) surveyed the habitats in Venado and Moctezuma. The habitat of Xenoophorus captivus in Venado is a swift flowing spring-fed shallow creek in a light forest, approximately 5 m wide and 20 cm deep (some pools up to 50 cm deep) with ground made of sand, gravel, silt and rocks. Part of the embankment is made of submerged vegetation, mainly Chara species. The Relict Splitfin was found in low numbers within the dense vegetation, together with crayfish. The creek itself showed moderate numbers of non-native green swordtails (Xiphophorus hellerii) within the deeper pools. The habitat in Moctezuma is part of a recreation area, mainly used for picnics. It is a swift flowing creek, between 0.5 and 1.2 m deep and between 0.5 and 2 m wide, and is covered with dense submerged vegetation. The Relict Splitfin was found mainly in the deeper sections, over ground of sand and silt with few rocks and plants, but within a thick system of tree roots.
threats: The Relict Splitfin occurs in spring and streams within a very arid area and therefore faces severe threats. Besides water pollution from agriculture and domestic sewage, non-native fish (especially Poeclids: Xiphophorus hellerii and Poecilia mexicana) also occur in part of its habitats. In Venado, swordtails are the main species populating the creek, with Xenoophorus captivus hiding in vegetation. Water exploitation and groundwater pumping, especially in combination with droughts caused by climate change, threatens almost all habitats and have caused populations of Illescas to disappear. In addition, the energy production is an important threat to parts of the population. For example, the Power Plant in Villa de Reyes uses water from the Río Santa María to cool itsengines, leading to river desiccation in the dry season and making the river uninhabitable across large sections.
population: The population of Xenoophorus captivus is small. All known habitats display stocks in low to moderate numbers, and the species seems to have a certain affinity to submerged vegetation. The Panuco subpopulation is severely affected by water exploitation, agriculture and droughts. Only a few localities persisted with small stocks. Additionally, large sections of the Río Santa María became uninhabitable for the species due a Power Plant in Villa de Reyes using water to cool its engines. The subpopulation in Venado and Moctezuma are under pressure of non-native Green swordtails, which compete for food and space. The habitats are also used for recreation which causes water pollution, to a degree. The population of Illescas was extirpated by over exploitation of water for agriculture.
range: The Relict Splitfin is a freshwater fish species endemic to the Mexican federal state of San Luis Potosí. It is historically known from the headwaters of the Río Santa María (Río Pánuco drainage) to about 15 km below the town of Santa María del Río, including its main source, the Río Altamira and the Río Villela (Río Tierra Quemada) that merges into the Río Santa María right below Santa María del Río. It also occurs in spring areas of an endorheic river (Río Matehuala) about 70 km north of the city of San Luis Potosí, especially in the springs in Venado and Moctezuma; it was also known to inhabit the endorheic springs at Illescas that dried up in 1996 (J. Artigas-Azas pers. comm. 2018). Domínguez-Domínguez et al. (2008) estimated a 65% reduction of most of its historical geographic range.
useTrade: The Relict Splitfin is not used for human consumption and is not targeted for the ornamental fish trade.
conservationActions: The only ongoing conservation effort is a monitoring and ex-situ breeding project run by the Laboratorio de Biología Acuatica in Michoacan University, Morelia, Mexico.

rationale: Geoemyda spengleri is considered to be Endangered based on levels of trade and scarcity, as it is impacted by collection for trade, though due to its relatively high altitude forest habitat it is likely that suitable habitat areas remain. The level of past and current decline is believed to be greater than 50% over three generations (72 years).
habitat: Geoemyda spengleri is primarily terrestrial but occasionally uses streams (Fang 1930). It inhabits closed-canopy forest at mid to high elevations (from 500 to over 1,000 m asl). No field observations of G. spengleri feeding habits exist. Faecal samples indicated consumption of snails, insects, leaves and fruits (Gaillard et al. 2017). Natural predators include wild boar and civets (Gaillard et al. 2017). In captivity, it feeds on small invertebrates, meat and fruits (Yasukawa and Ota 2010). This species is difficult to keep in captivity, and often will die within six months (Li Pipeng pers. comm. 2018). It is active during most of the year, nesting in open areas. Local people state females nest in open areas during the summer (Gaillard et al. 2017). Rudloff (1986) reported a female in captivity laying three single-egg clutches at 38 day intervals, with hatchling carapace length of 30 mm. Age at maturity is 6–8 year in captivity, but is likely to be higher in the wild, generation length is calculated as 24 years (three x age at maturity).
threats: Geoemyda spengleri is threatened by intensive collection throughout its range for trade for medicinal use.
