useTrade: There is no information on any use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions:
There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. It does not occur in any protected area.

Classified as Vulnerable in Argentina because of its restricted distribution, it is a habitat specialist. Phymaturus species are viviparous and take between seven and nine years to reach sexual maturity and have a low litter size from one to two individuals per female (Abdala et al. 2012).

rationale: Hippichthys heptagonus is a widespread freshwater and estuarine species that inhabits coastal regions throughout the Indo-West Pacific from Africa to the Solomon Islands. The species is likely collected for the aquarium and traditional medicine trades, but levels of offtake are unknown. Its freshwater habitat is threatened in both Africa and Southeast Asia by pollution, overfishing, invasive species, and flow alterations and dams. The species is however protected in part of its range and inhabits many areas with few anthropogenic stresses. Therefore H. heptagonus is listed as Least Concern.
habitat: Hippichthys heptagonus is a demersal species. It is common in the lower reaches of rivers and streams, and in estuarine habitats, such as mangrove estuaries and tidal creeks (Dawson 1985). It sometimes also occurs in large Philippine lakes (Dawson 1985). The species is known to feed on small crustaceans, especially calanoid and cyclopoid copepods and chydorid cladocerans but also dipteran and ephemopteran larvae (Jones et al. 2007). It is an ovoviviparous fish; the female deposits eggs on the ventral surface of the male's tail, where they are incubated for several weeks prior to live birth (Breder and Rosen 1966, Dawson 1985). They grow to a maximum size of 15 cm SL and males are mature at 7.5-8 cm (Dawson 1985).
threats:
Hippichthys heptagonus is likely targeted and traded for use in aquariums and traditional medicines. Levels of offtake are unknown. 
Freshwater habitats within the species' range are threatened by flow alteration from dams, overfishing, invasive species, and pollution (Thieme et al. 2005, Dudgeon 2005). The scope and severity of these threats have not been quantified across this species' range.
population: To date there have been no dedicated surveys or population estimates for Hippichthys heptagonus. Further research is needed in order to determine population size and trends in abundance for this species.
range: Hippichthys heptagonus occurs in rivers, lakes, and estuaries in the Indo-West Pacific from Kenya and South Africa to the Solomon Islands, and from southern Japan to New South Wales on the eastern Australian coast (Dawson 1985).
useTrade: This species is probably collected from the wild for the aquarium trade (Jenkins, pers. comm. 2009), and it may also be targeted for use as traditional medicine (Vincent et al. 2011). Levels of offtake are unknown.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for Hippichthys heptagonus. The species is listed along with all other syngnathids in the Australian Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act (1999), meaning it is an offence to kill, injure, take, trade, keep, or move H. heptagonus in Australian waters without a permit. It is not clear if the species occurs in any protected areas, and it is not mentioned in any international legislation or trade regulations.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Vulnerable, as this species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of [XXX] km2, it occurs in XX threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the quality of its habitat."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Vulnerable, as this species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 5,935 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in three threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat on Negros in the Philippines.
habitat: This species inhabits arboreal microhabitats in mossy lower montane and montane rainforests. Eggs are deposited on leaves, and breeding takes place by direct development. It is not tolerant of habitat disturbance.
threats: The major threat is habitat loss and degradation due to the conversion of habitat to agriculture, human settlements, wood collection. Disturbance of the remaining rainforest by explorations for geothermal energy plants in the north has ceased as the geothermal plants were recently operational, but are now being shut down as energy production is no longer economic, and there forest is starting to recover; however, exploration and plant development continues in the south of the island (Philippines Red List Assessment Workshop May 2017).
population: It is common at high elevations in moist upper elevation rainforests, but it is rare or absent in disturbed habitats. Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species occurs at high elevations (600–1,700 m asl) on the mountains of Negros and possibly Masbate Islands (see Taxonomic Note), in the Philippines. Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 5,935 km<sup>2 </sup>and it is considered to occur at three threat-defined locations. The species may have occurred between known sites, but there is little to no remaining suitable habitat there. Should any areas of suitable habitat still remain at suitable elevations, the species may occur at those sites (Philippines Red List Workshop May 2017).
useTrade: There are no records of the species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions 
This species occurs in Mount Kanlaon Natural Park and Balinsasayao Twin Lakes Natural Park.

Conservation Needed
There is a need for the improved protected of forests within protected areas, and designation of remaining rainforests of southern Negros and Masbate as protected areas. 

Research Needed
The Masbate subpopulation should be the target for population status surveys in the near future, and there is a particular need to resolve the taxonomic status of this subpopulation. Further work is required to improve the understand of the species' population size, distribution, and trends.

rationale: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"Listed as Least Concern because, although the distribution is limited (EOO of [XXX] km2), there are no current threats, the species adapts to disturbed habitats, and it occurs in a protected area."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">Listed as Least Concern because, although the distribution is limited, there are no current threats, it has a stable population, and it occurs in a well-protected area.
habitat: This species inhabits arboreal microhabitats in mossy and montane rainforests, and deposits its eggs on leaves in shrub layer vegetation. It breeds by direct development.
threats: Of the two sites at which the species occurs, Mt. Isarog is presently a generally well-protected locality where the species is not highly threatened by habitat loss. Geothermal energy is generated on the slopes Mt. Malinao, but its impact is limited and one of the plants was recently decommissioned due to decrease in steam supply (Philippines Red List Assessment Workshop May 2017). Both sites where the species is known to occur are dormant volcanoes, however it is not thought to be at risk of extinction from future volcanic activity.
population: It is common in mid- to upper-montane forests on Mount Isarog. The population appears to be stable.
range: This species was previously known only from Mount Isarog on southeastern Luzon Island, Philippines. It has now been confirmed as also occurring on Mount Malinao (Philippines Red List Assessment Workshop May 2017). Its elevational range is 650–1,800 m asl and the extent of occurrence (EOO) of this expanded range is 640 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: <span data-sheets-value="{"1":2,"2":"There are no records of this species being utilized."}" data-sheets-userformat="{"2":13245,"3":[null,0],"5":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"6":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"7":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"8":{"1":[{"1":2,"2":0,"5":[null,2,0]},{"1":0,"2":0,"3":3},{"1":1,"2":0,"4":1}]},"10":0,"11":4,"12":0,"15":"Calibri","16":11}">There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
This species occurs in Mount Isarog National Park.

Conservation Needed
The most important conservation measure needed at present is the continued management of Mount Isarog National Park.

Research Needed
There is also a need for continued monitoring of the population status of this species.

rationale: The species is widespread and, while it is declining in parts of its range such as India and in Nepal due to siltation, habitat loss and degradation, it is not thought that any global population decline is likely to meet (or be close to meeting) the threshold for Vulnerable. Therefore, this species is assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: This species inhabits freshwater and primarily rivers. In North Bengal it occurs in clear, gravelly, perennial streams and ponds of Terai and Duars. In Sri Lanka, Xenentodon cancila can be found in clear flowing water, although it prefers areas with deep pools and sand or rocky substrates (De Silva et al. 2015, Pethiyagoda 1991). It is a surface-living fish which can reach lengths of 40 cm, although the common size is 30 cm.
threats: There is habitat degradation in some parts of its range in India due to siltation caused by deforestation, in addition to habitat loss and modification due to the loss of wetlands, especially through infilling of ponds. In Sri Lanka, water pollution from prevalent human activities such as sand mining gem mining, mini-hydro dams and deforestation can result in habitat degradation which affects the survival of this species.
population: The species is fairly common in the Ganges-Brahmaputra system, however, in Nepal it is not common. No information is currently available for other parts of its range.
range: Xenentodon cancila has been recorded from Pakistan, India (Uttar Pradesh, Assam, Tripura, West Bengal, Nagaland, Meghalaya, Orissa, and Bihar), Bangladesh, Nepal, Sri Lanka, Myanmar and Thailand. In Sri Lanka it can be found in the lowland wet zone and the lowland intermediate zone (De Silva et al. 2015).
useTrade: Xenentodon cancila is utilised in commercial fisheries and by subsistence fishers. In Sri Lanka, it is known to exported in small numbers for the international aquarium trade (Gunasekara 2011).
conservationActions: Further information is required on the scale and impact of the threats (especially habitat degradation) to this species.

rationale: This species is listed as Critically Endangered because of its extremely small area of occupancy (<4 km<sup>2</sup>), ongoing decline caused by off-road vehicle use and the prior construction of a hydroelectric dam, and occurrence in a single location. The species has been searched for repeatedly over the last several decades such that it is highly unlikely that other subpopulations persist.
habitat: This species is found in Monte phytogeographic province. It is strictly arenicolous, inhabiting the peaks of the sand dunes. Individuals can burrow in the sand to escape predators (Abdala et al. 2012). It is oviparous, and eats insects.
threats: The type locality of this species was destroyed by the construction of a hydroelectric dam and the subsequent tourism infrastructure constructed around the reservoir. The habitat where the newly-discovered population is found is highly threatened by the intensive use by off-road vehicle use and competitions such as rallies (Abdala et al. 2012).
population: This species is extremely rare. It was perhaps the most sought after reptile in Argentina, with numerous herpetological expeditions taking place attempting to relocate the species. The species was rediscovered in 2010, when 18-20 individuals were found. Due to ongoing threats in the area, the population is assumed to be in continuous decline.
range: Liolaemus rabinoi is known only from the vicinity of the Nihuil reservoir, San Rafael, Mendoza province, Argentina; at 1,800 m asl (Cei 1974, Avila et al. 2009). It is a species that was thought to be extinct until it was rediscovered after 35 years in an area south of the original locality at an elevation of 1,400 m (Abdala et al. 2012, Avila et al. 2013).
useTrade: It is unknown whether there is any use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions:
The species does not occur in any protected area. In an attempt to limit the effects of off-road vehicles, the route of the Dakar Rally was altered to avoid the site of the remaining population (however, spectators of the rally still drove over the site, even if the competitors did not). Urgent measures are needed to protect the habitat of this unique and highly threatened lizard. Translocation of individuals to safer sites should also be considered.

Classified as Endangered in Argentina, due to habitat degradation caused by off-road vehicles competitions (Abdala et al. 2012).

rationale: The Kit Fox inhabits the deserts and arid lands of western North America. Generally, the species is common to rare, with population densities fluctuating with annual environmental conditions. Estimation of a population size or even population trends for this species is not possible with currently available information. Population monitoring for this species is largely limited to only a few specific sites. However, natural habitats occupied by the Kit Fox are being transformed (e.g., agriculture, solar energy). Thus, in numerous locations throughout the range, it is safe to assume that, overall, populations and area of occupancy are declining. Nonetheless, the species currently does not meet any of the thresholds for the threatened categories, and is presently assessed as Least Concern. However, this status could change over the next several decades if current habitat loss trends continue.
habitat:
The Kit Fox inhabits arid and semi-arid regions encompassing desert scrub, chaparral, halophytic, and grassland communities (McGrew 1979, O'Farrell 1987). Areas with sparse ground cover are preferred (McGrew 1977, Cypher et al. 2013). It is found in elevations ranging from 400–1,900 m a.s.l., although Kit Foxes generally avoid rugged terrain with slopes >5% (Warrick and Cypher 1998). Loose textured soils may be preferred for denning. Kit Foxes will use agricultural lands, particularly orchards, on a limited basis, and also can inhabit urban environments (Morrell 1972, Cypher 2010). Home range size varies from 251 ha to 1160 ha and generally does not differ between sexes (Cypher 2003). Size can vary with habitat conditions, particularly food availability (Spiegel 1996, Zoellick et al. 2002). Kit foxes are primarily nocturnal and nightly movements exceeding 14 km have been reported (Zoellick et al. 1989, 2002). Kit Foxes use dens year-round and uses include daytime resting, escaping predators, avoiding temperature extremes, conserving moisture, and bearing and rearing young (Egoscue 1962, Morrell 1972, Koopman et al. 1998). Kit Foxes can excavate their own dens, but also will modify and use the burrows of badgers, ground squirrels, prairie dogs, and kangaroo rats (Morrell 1972, List 1997, Koopman et al. 1998). Dens are distributed throughout home ranges, and an individual fox typically uses over 11 dens during a given year (Koopman et al. 1998).

Kit Foxes primarily consume animal prey and common items include rodents, rabbits, invertebrates, birds, lizards, and snakes. Among rodents, kangaroo rats, pocket mice, prairie dogs, and ground squirrels generally are preferred, and common invertebrate prey include beetles, crickets, and grasshoppers (Cypher 2003, List et al. 2003). Fluctuations in food availability related to variable annual precipitation levels are a primary factor driving Kit Fox population dynamics (White and Garrott 1997, Cypher et al. 2000). Kit Foxes do not require free water but will drink it if available (Egoscue 1956, Golightly and Ohmart 1984).

Kit Foxes experience intense interference and exploitative competition from other species, particularly coyotes (White et al. 1995, Cypher and Spencer 1998, Kozlowski et al. 2008). Other competitors include bobcats, badgers, golden eagles, and red foxes. Predators generally are the primary source of mortality, but other causes include vehicles, harvest, and rodenticides (Ralls and White 1995; Cypher et al. 2000, 2014). Disease does not appear to be a significant factor in most Kit Fox populations. At one site, annual survival probabilities for adults ranged from 0.20 to 0.81 over 16 years with a mean of 0.44 (Cypher et al. 2000). 

Kit Foxes pair during October and November (if not already paired), and breed in December and January (Egoscue 1956). Gestation is 49-55 days, and parturition occurs during January-March (Egoscue 1956, Egoscue 1962, Zoellick et al. 1987). Typical litter size averages about 4 and ranges from 1-9 (Cypher 2003). Annual reproductive success is strongly influenced by food availability (Egoscue 1975, White and Garrott 1997) and at one location ranged from 20-100% over a 16-year period (Cypher et al. 2000). Kit Foxes mate for life and are primarily monogamous with occasional instances of polygyny (Egoscue 1962; Ralls et al. 2001, 2007). Young from previous years, typically females, may delay dispersal and assist with raising the current year’s litter (Koopman et al. 2000, Ralls et al. 2001).
threats: The main threat to the long-term survival of the Kit Fox is habitat conversion, mainly to agriculture but also to urban and industrial development. In both western and eastern Mexico, prairie dog towns, which support important populations of Kit Foxes are being converted to agricultural fields (e.g., Ávila-Flores et al. 2012), and in eastern Mexico the road network is expanding, producing a concomitant increase in the risk of vehicle mortality. In the San Joaquin Valley of California, habitat conversion for agriculture is slowing, but habitat loss, fragmentation, and degradation associated with industrial and urban development are still occurring at a rapid pace. More recently, expansive industrial-scale solar energy generating facilities are being constructed throughout the western USA, but particularly in California, Arizona, and Nevada.
population:
The species is common to rare. Density fluctuates with annual environmental conditions, which are dependent upon precipitation (Cypher et al. 2000). In Utah, density ranged from 0.1–0.8/km² (Egoscue 1956, 1975). In California, density varied from 0.15–0.24/km² over a period of three years on one study site (White et al. 1996) and from 0.2–1.7/km² over 15 years on another study site (Cypher et al. 2000). Kit Fox densities in prairie dog town complexes in Mexico were 0.32–0.8/km² in Chihuahua (List 1997) and 0.1/km² in Coahuila and Nuevo Leon (Côtera 1996).

In Mexico, data on which to base a population estimate for Kit Foxes are only available from two localities with very specific characteristics (presence of prairie dog towns). Therefore, the estimation of a population size for the country or even population trends is not possible with current information. However, because natural habitats occupied by the Kit Fox are being transformed, it is safe to assume that, overall, populations of the Kit Fox in Mexico are declining. In the past 10 years, about 40% of prairie dog towns in Coahuila and Nuevo Leon were converted to agriculture (L. Scott and E. Estrada unpubl.), and of the area occupied in Chihuahua by prairie dogs in 1988, 76% remained in 2005 (Ávila et al. 2012) and by 2013 only 3% remained  (R. Sierra and E. Ponce pers. comm.).

In the United States, Kit Fox abundance is unknown. Populations are relatively large and trends are assumed to be relatively stable in Arizona, Nevada, New Mexico, Texas, Utah, and possibly the Mjoave Desert of California, based on extensive remaining suitable habitat. Populations in Colorado, Idaho, and Oregon are relatively small and trends are unknown (Cypher 2003). Populations of the Endangered (USFWS) San Joaquin Kit Fox in the San Joaquin Valley of California are likely still declining due to continuing habitat loss, fragmentation, and degradation (USFWS 1998).
range: The Kit Fox inhabits the deserts and arid lands of western North America. In the United States, it occurs from southern California to western Colorado and western Texas, north into southern Oregon and Idaho. In Mexico, it occurs across the Baja California Peninsula and across northern Sonora and Chihuahua to western Nuevo León, and south into northern Zacatecas (McGrew 1979, Hall 1981).
useTrade: In Mexico, Kit Foxes are occasionally sold illegally on the pet market. Kit Foxes are harvested for fur in some states in the USA (e.g., Arizona, Nevada, New Mexico, Texas and Utah), but otherwise are not used commercially.
conservationActions:
Not listed on the CITES Appendices. The Kit Fox is considered Vulnerable in Mexico (SEMARNAT 2010). In the United States, the San Joaquin Kit Fox (V. m. mutica) is federally classified as Endangered, and as Threatened by the state of California (USFWS 1998). In Oregon, Kit Foxes are classified as Threatened. In Colorado, Kit Foxes are classified as Endangered. In Idaho, Kit Foxes are considered a protected non-game species. Harvests are not permitted in Idaho, Oregon, or California, and the Kit Fox is a protected furbearer species (i.e., regulated harvests) in Utah, Arizona, Nevada, New Mexico and Texas. In Mexico, the vulnerable status of the Kit Fox grants conservation measures for the species, but these are not enforced. In the United States, state and federal protections for Kit Foxes are being enforced. 
In Mexico, Kit Foxes are found in the Biosphere Reserves of El Vizcaino, Mapimi, El Pinacate and Janos, in the Area of Special Protection of Cuatro Ciénegas, and are probably found in another eight protected areas throughout their range. In the United States, they occur in numerous protected areas throughout their range. The Endangered subspecies V. m. mutica occurs in the Carrizo Plain National Monument and various other federal, state, and private conservation lands.

Efforts are underway to protect the prairie dog towns of both eastern (Pronatura Noreste) and western Mexico (Institute of Ecology from the National University of Mexico), which are known to be strongholds for the Kit Fox, but no specific actions focused on the Kit Fox are being undertaken in Mexico. In the United States, a recovery plan has been completed (USFWS 1998) and is being implemented for the San Joaquin Kit Fox. Recovery actions include protection of essential habitat, and demographic and ecological research in both natural and anthropogenically modified landscapes.

No captive breeding efforts are currently being conducted for Kit Foxes. Facilities such as the Arizona-Sonora Desert Museum in Tucson, Arizona, California Living Museum in Bakersfield, California, and several zoos keep live Kit Foxes for display and educational purposes.

Gaps in knowledge
In general, demographic and ecological data are needed throughout the range of the species so that population trends and demographic patterns can be assessed. In Mexico, available information on the Kit Fox is scarce. The most important gaps in our knowledge of the species are the present distribution of the species and population estimates throughout its range. General biological information is needed from more localities in the Mexican range of the Kit Fox. In the United States, information is needed on the effects of solar energy plants, investigating dispersal patterns and corridors, determining metapopulation dynamics and conducting viability analyses, developing conservation strategies in anthropogenically altered landscapes, assessing threats from non-native Red Foxes, and range-wide population monitoring.

Research in progress in Mexico includes investigations of abundance and diet in the Janos Biosphere Reserve as well as relationships between Kit Foxes and sylvatic plague. Research in progress on the endangered San Joaquin Kit Fox include investigations of solar energy development effects, trophic interactions, urban ecology, population genetic structure, ecology in core and satellite population areas, and population effects of sarcoptic mange. Research in progress elsewhere in the USA includes abundance and ecology in Oregon, detection and ecology in Idaho, survey methods in low-density areas, interactions with coyotes near artificial water sources in Utah, effects of off-highway vehicles in Arizona, and distribution and occupancy in New Mexico.

rationale: Listed as Vulnerable because it has an extent of occurrence (EOO) is 7,379 km<sup>2</sup>, it is known from fewer than 10 threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: This species inhabits montane rapids and streams with small waterfalls in sub-tropical, evergreen, broad-leaved forests, both during the breeding and non-breeding season. It prefers pools where it lives among the rocks; it can also be found in the leaf litter and on low vegetation under 1 m high (D.-Q. Rao pers. comm. June 2019). It is unlikely to tolerate habitat disturbance. Breeding takes place by larval development in streams, where it lays its eggs under rocks (D.-Q. Rao pers. comm. June 2019).
threats: The threats to the species are habitat degradation caused by small-scale wood extraction and small hydroelectric dams that modify the flow of the river (D.-Q. Rao pers. comm. June 2019). It is also harvested for human consumption, but not at levels to constitute a major threat (D.-Q. Rao pers. comm. June 2019).
population: The species is locally common. Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species is restricted to two mountains, Wuliang and Ailao, in Jingdong County, Yunnan Province, China. It has been recorded between 1,500–2,400 m asl. It occurs in 2-10 threat-defined locations, and its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 7,379 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: There is a small degree of collection for human consumption, but this is limited due to the small size of the species and its strong odour and is not considered to be a major threat (D.-Q. Rao pers. comm. June 2019).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs in the Ailaoshan and Wuliangshan National Nature Reserves. 

Conservation Actions Needed
Ongoing protection of the habitat is needed to ensure the survival of the species. 

Research Needed
There is a need for close population monitoring of this species given its very limited range.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because this species has an extent of occurrence of 449 km<sup>2</sup>, and its range is considered severely fragmented, and there is a continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat outside of protected areas. The survival of this species is dependent on the habitat protection provided by the many protected areas this species is found in, which are well protected at present. The species is likely to be endemic to the region where it has been recorded, but it is feared that some subpopulations may have already been lost due to ongoing habitat loss outside the protected areas. Therefore, without this high degree of protection, it is very likely that the species’ remaining habitat would be degraded and fragmented resulting in further major population declines.
habitat: This species is an inhabitant of forest-fringed, small hill streams, particularly those with cascades. The frog lives on the rocks of mountain streams, and is often found perched on stones near small waterfalls or on stone walls in waterfalls. It does not survive where the forest has been removed. The eggs are laid in rock crevices near cascades and waterfalls, where the water splashes over them, and the larvae cling to the stones and rocks in streams by means of a ventral sucker;12-60 eggs have been observed attached to a cliff in a waterfall. Tadpoles are adsorbed on stones with abdominal suckers; a metamorphic tadpole still has abdominal suckers.
threats: Previous threats to this species are habitat destruction and degradation caused by silviculture, clear-cutting, and the construction of hydroelectric plants and other infrastructure, but these are no longer considered to be a problem. In the 2008 assessment, it was reported that the subpopulation in Hong Kong appeared to be relatively secure, but part of the habitat of the Guangdong subpopulation was under threat when it was last surveyed in 1997. While the currently known subpopulations of this species are not threatened at present, it is believed that there may be some undiscovered subpopulations that exist outside but in the vicinity of the nature reserves (J. Yang pers. comm. June 2019). If subpopulations are confirmed, then it is likely that they will be threatened by the increasing urbanisation that is occurring on the coast and it is plausible to suspect that they are in decline (J. Yang pers. comm. June 2019).
population: It is a locally common species throughout its range. The subpopulation that definitely belong to this species species are considered to be relatively stable, however the uncertain subpopulations in Guangdong are unknown as no surveys have been carried out since 1997. Its range is considered to be severely fragmented.
range:
This species is known only from a small area of southern China in Hong Kong (both the New Territories and Hong Kong Island) and nearby Guangdong Province (Xiangtoushan National Nature Reserve and Gutian Nature Reserve in Huizhou City) between 20-790 m asl (M.W.N. Lau pers. comm.). It is likely to be restricted to the known localities and the area within the immediate vicinity of the Nature Reserves outside of Hong Kong, however further surveys are required to verify this (Y.Y. Wang and J. Yang pers. comm. June 2019).

It is possible that the subpopulations in Guangdong may belong to an undescribed species, however further taxonomic work needs to be carried out (Y.Y. Wang pers. comm. June 2019). For the purposes of this assessment, the record has been coded as 'Presence Uncertain' and excluded from the extent of occurrence (EOO) calculation. Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 449 km2.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
Most of the range of the Hong Kong population is within protected areas, and it is also protected in Hong Kong under the Wild Animals Protection Ordinance. In Guangdong Province in China, it occurs in Xiangtoushan National Nature Reserve and Gutian Nature Reserve, however these records are uncertain (J. Yang pers. comm. June 2019). This species is also on the "List of Beneficial or of Important Economic or Scientific Value Terrestrial Wild Animals under States Protection", under the protection of the "Law of the People's Republic of China on the Protection of Wildlife", which provides a moderate degree of protection and makes it illegal to collect (China Red List Assessment Workshop June 2019).

Conservation Needed
Continued enforcement of protected areas is necessary for the conservation of this species and its habitat.

Research Needed
Further research is required on its distribution, and the taxonomic status of the subpopulations from Guangdong Province need to be resolved.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because of an observed population decline, estimated to be more than 50% over the past 10 years, inferred from the impact of over harvesting for subsistence on this species.
habitat:
This species inhabits hill streams and cascades fringed by forests.The frog lives on rocks near streams and waterfalls. Adult frogs often climb cliffs near waterfalls during the day, and jump into cliff crevices inside waterfalls after being disturbed. At night they mostly climb rocks near streams or shrub branches and leaves. It may tolerate some habitat disturbance, providing that the streams are pristine (J. Yang and J. Wang pers. comm. June 2019). During reproduction, the eggs clumps are placed in rock crevices in the waterfall. Tadpoles inhabit broad streams, lush vegetation on the sides of rivers, and water in rocky streams, often adsorbed on the bottom of rocks.

Its generation length is estimated to be 3 years, based on similar sized species.
threats:
Exploitation for human consumption is a major threat to this species. In southern Hainan, outside of protected areas, forest habitat in lowland areas is affected by the expansion of small-scale rubber plantations which are a threat to this species (J. Yang pers. comm. June 2019). Small-scale banana plantations and areca crops, along with associated pollution (from herbicides and pesticides) are also considered be threats to lowland populations of the species (J. Yang and J. Wang pers. comm. June 2019).

It was previously reported that the construction of hydroelectric plants was a threat to this species, but this is no longer considered to be a problem as construction has taken place and there are no current plans for any new hydroelectric plants (J. Yang and J. Wang pers. comm. June 2019).
population: It is a locally common species, but the population is thought to be small. Repeated surveys have recorded declines; the subpopulations at Wanling Town and Zhongping Town are suspected to have declined by 70% (J. Wang pers. comm. June 2019), and overall it is suspected that the global population has declined by 50% over the last 10 years (J. Yang and J. Wang pers. comm. June 2019). Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat and due to the overharvesting of the species, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species is endemic to south-west and central Hainan Province, China, and has been recorded between 80–960 m asl. It is not expected to occur more widely (J. Yang pers. comm. June 2019). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 13,582 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: It is a fairly large species which is harvested for local human consumption, and this is thought to be causing declines in the population (J. Yang and J. Wang pers. comm. June 2019).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
Most of this species' range lies within protected areas. This species is on the "List of Beneficial or of Important Economic or Scientific Value Terrestrial Wild Animals under States Protection", under the protection of the "Law of the People's Republic of China on the Protection of Wildlife", which provides a moderate degree of protection and makes it illegal to collect (China Red List Assessment Workshop June 2019).

Conservation Needed
Even though it is illegal to collect, there is a need to improve enforcement and control the harvest of this species (J. Yang and J. Wang pers. comm. June 2019). Further habitat protection is required in lowland areas on Hainan Island (J. Yang pers. comm. June 2019).

Research Needed
Research on the ecology of this species is required (J. Yang and J. Wang pers. comm. June 2019).

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
habitat: This species inhabits montane forests, and is often found on boulders near streams during the breeding season. It is a territorial species. During the non-reproductive period the species is found dispersed throughout the forest, and then moves to streams when it is time to breed, as breeding takes place in the streams. The timing of breeding season appears to vary by location, occurring in Sichuan from June-August and in Zhejiang from May-June. This species breeds by larval development, with females laying approximately 278-421 eggs each season. The resulting tadpoles are equipped with abdominal suckers to help them stick to stones in the stream and not be washed away by the current (Fei et al. 2012).
threats: Habitat destruction and degradation caused by deforestation, the construction of hydroelectric plants, and the liming of streams for fish are major threats to this species. It is also collected by the local people for consumption in certain areas, although this is not considered a threat.
population: This species is common in suitable habitat. Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species is known from southern, central and west China including Shannxi, Gansu, Sichuan, Guixhou, Zhejiang, Hunan, Fujian, Guangxi and Guangdong Provinces. Records from Yunnan Province, and from Fan Si Pan Mountain in Viet Nam (Ohler et al. 2000) refer to Amolops mengyangensis (Ohler 2007). This species probably occurs more widely than current records suggest, especially in areas between known sites. It is found at elevations between 700-1,900 m asl.
useTrade: The species is collected by the local people for consumption in certain areas, but this does not constitute a major threat to the species.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
Most of this species' range lies within protected areas and the habitats have some form of protection. This species is on the "List of Beneficial or of Important Economic or Scientific Value Terrestrial Wild Animals under States Protection", under the protection of the "Law of the People's Republic of China on the Protection of Wildlife", which provides a moderate degree of protection and makes it illegal to collect (China Red List Assessment Workshop June 2019).

Conservation Needed
Recommended conservation measures include improved management of the existing protected area(s) and habitat maintenance and restoration.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats.

rationale: Listed as Least Concern because, although the distribution is somewhat limited - its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 27,007 km<sup>2</sup> - threats are mostly localized and the population is presumed to be large and stable.
habitat: This species inhabits mountain streams and subtropical forests, and breeding takes place by larval development in streams. From April to August, adults often live in the dense forests near Liuxi River. During the daytime, they mostly hide under big rocks near the river, and at night, they often crouch among rocks, grasses or deciduous leaves near the river, feeding on small animals such as Lepidoptera, Coleoptera, Hymenoptera insects and spiders. Breeding season likely begins in late April or early May. During this time females lay 282-429 eggs in clusters, which adhere to the bottom of stones in the stream. Tadpoles then develop in the same stream and are often found near rocks.
threats: The species is threatened in parts of its range by the development of facilities for expanding tourism, and by the impact on stream habitats from small-scale hydropower development (F. Xie pers. comm. June 2019).
population: This species is common and has a largely stable population.
range: This species is known from southern Sichuan Province and Chishui in Guizhou Province, China. It occupies an elevational range between 700-1,500 m asl. Records tentatively referred to this species were reported from Fan Si Pan Mountain, Lao Cai Province, northern Viet Nam, at 1,400-1,900 m asl, by Orlov et al. (2000). However, the identity of these records has not yet been confirmed so they are retained in the map as "Presence Uncertain." Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 27,007 km2.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species has been recorded from several protected areas in China. Within Viet Nam, the one location from which it has tentatively been recorded is within Hoang Lien Son National Park. This species is on the "List of Beneficial or of Important Economic or Scientific Value Terrestrial Wild Animals under States Protection", under the protection of the "Law of the People's Republic of China on the Protection of Wildlife", which provides a moderate degree of protection and makes it illegal to collect (China Red List Assessment Workshop June 2019).

Conservation Needed
Continued and strengthened management of protected area(s) where this species occurs, and expanded protection of forest elsewhere in its range is needed.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the threats of development for tourism and hydroelectric power.

rationale: With an Extent of Occurrence of 173750 km<sup>2 </sup>and an estimated population size of 20000 individuals, this species qualifies as Least Concern; however, the population trend should be closely monitored since there is an ongoing threat of loss of roost sistes, as old mines are being re-opened for mining.
habitat: The species predominantly roosts in natural caves, however it has been observed in old gold and asbestos mines (Monadjem et al. 2008). Jacobs et al. (2013) reported the species from the Arid Savanna, Succulant-Karoo, Nama-Karoo, Shrublands and Desert. Furthermore, the species is also recorded from the Eastern Kalahari Bushveld, Kalahari Duneveld, Bushmanland, Gariep Desert, Southern Namib Desert, Richtersveld and the Upper Karoo.
threats: The species is potentially threatened by the re-opening of mine adits, as well as re-use of old mines.
population: It occurs in small colonies of less 100 individuals per colony
range: The species is restricted to the arid, warm western parts of southern Africa, with records reported from Angola, Namibia and western South Africa (Jacobs et al. 2013). In the assessment region, the species is recorded from the Northern Cape and North West provinces of South Africa.
conservationActions: There are no direct conservation measures in place. It has however been recorded from formally protected Richtersveld National Park and the Augrabies Falls National Park.

rationale: Liolaemus occipitalis é restrita à costa atlântica do sul do Brasil e leste do Uruguai. Sua extensão de ocorrência é de 7.000 km2. Algumas subpopulações desapareceram devido à remoção e descaracterização do seu hábitat, principalmente relacionada à perda de duas espécies de plantas herbáceas presentes em sua área de ocorrência, Panicum racemosum e Hydrocotyle bonariensis. A área onde a espécie efetivamente ocorre foi profundamente alterada nas últimas décadas pelos empreendimentos imobiliários, especialmente no Litoral Norte do Rio Grande do Sul, onde as subpopulações estão severamente fragmentadas (interrupção do fluxo gênico). Atualmente, as áreas ao longo da Península de Mostardas (Litoral Médio) está sendo fortemente alterado pela silvicultura e plantio de Pinus. Há também ameaça pela implantação de Parques Eólicos no litoral médio-sul do Rio Grande do Sul. Definitivamente a espécie vem sofrendo declínio de qualidade do seu habitat, com sua área de ocupação fortemente fragmentada e descaracterizada. Por esse motivos, a espécie foi categorizada como Vulnerável (VU).
habitat: É uma espécie restrita a restrita às dunas nas restingas do litoral do sul do Brasil e leste do Uruguai. A vegetação presente nas dunas é essencial para a espécie, já que as plantas oferecem alimentação para esta espécie – através da presença de insetos; proteção contra predadores e funcionam como sítios de termorregulação e construção de tocas (Bujes and Verrastro 2008). Alguns estudos tem demonstrado que Liolaemus occipitalis está associado principalmente a comunidades vegetais que ocorrem em ambientes não-urbanizados (sem alteração). A presença da espécie em áreas semi-urbanizadas e urbanizadas é muito baixa, e quando ocorre, está associada a plantas que caracterizam o ambiente natural, como Panicum racemosum e Hydrocotyle bonariensis (Melamed and Verrastro 1997). Apresenta um padrão de coloração claro e críptico (coloração de camuflagem), que o confunde com a areia. Enterram-se na areia fofa ou em tocas que eles constroem na base dos montículos de vegetação herbácea. Apresenta alimentação à base de insetos, aranhas e material vegetal (flores e frutos de gramíneas), e reprodução ovípara entre os meses de primavera-verão (setembro a março).
threats: De acordo com as características de endemismo e restrição a hábitats arenosos do litoral, esta espécie de lagarto é ameaçada pela descaracterização do hábitat e a fragmentação dos ambientes de dunas, pela urbanização das praias, causando isolamento das subpopulações. A região mais afetada e destruída encontra-se na região norte do Rio Grande do Sul, onde existem cinco áreas que mantem ainda ambientes naturais. No litoral sul de Rio Grande do Sul, existem grandes extensões de dunas, ainda preservadas, mas que vem sendo afetadas pela implementação de Parques eólicos e plantações de Pinus. No estado de Santa Catarina, as populações são naturalmente fragmentadas, restringindo-se à algumas áreas de restingas com dunas altas e vegetação em forma de moitas de gramíneas. As alterações resultantes de ações antrópicas estão gerando o isolamento e/ou desaparecimento de subpopulações naturais da espécie devido à degradação em consequência da fragmentação dos habitats onde ela ocorre.
population: Liolaemus occipitalis era um dos vertebrados mais abundantes das dunas do litoral do Rio Grande do Sul até aproximadamente duas décadas atrás. A diminuição no número de áreas naturais e semi-naturais, juntamente com as mudanças na sua fauna e flora, têm sido verificadas devido ao acelerado avanço antrópico. De acordo com as características de endemismo e restrição a hábitats arenosos da costa sul-brasileira, esta espécie de lagarto é ameaçada pela descaracterização do hábitat e a fragmentação dos ambientes de dunas. A região mais afetada e destruída encontra-se na região norte do estado do Rio Grande do Sul, onde existem cinco áreas que mantém ainda ambientes naturais. No litoral sul de Rio Grande do Sul existem grandes extensões de dunas, ainda preservadas, mas que vem sendo afetadas pela implementação de parques eólicos e plantações de Pinus. Em Santa Catarina, as populações são naturalmente fragmentadas, restringindo-se a algumas áreas de restingas com dunas altas e vegetação em forma de moitas de gramíneas. Os resultados de filogeografia demonstram que esta espécie apresenta subpopulações isoladas com diferenças genéticas que podem indicar unidades evolutivas importantes para propostas de conservação das mesmas. Sua tendência populacional é decrescente pois através de dados de campo, desde 1986 até 2013, vem-se observando a extinção local de subpopulações e a diminuição da abundância nas subpopulações remanescentes (L. Verrastro com. pess. 2013).
range: Liolaemus occipitalis é restrita à costa atlântica do sul do Brasil e leste do Uruguai (Verrastro 2004, Verrastro and Rauber 2013, Carreira and Maneyro 2013). No Brasil, habita a segunda faixa de dunas nas restingas costeiras do estado de Rio Grande do Sul e Santa Catarina, sendo o limite norte de sua distribuição a Ilha de Santa Catarina (Praia dos Ingleses) (Relatórios de atividades do Sistema de Autorização e Informação em Biodiversidade – SISBio, Bujes and Verrastro 1998, 2008, Gomes and Krause 1982, Muller and Steiniger 1978, Quintela et al. 2006,  Verrastro and Bujes 1998, Verrastro and Krause 1999, Verrastro  and Rauber 2013, Verrastro et al. 2006). A área de ocupação não pode ser estimada com precisão, mas é certamente inferior a 2.000 km2 e há um declínio contínuo da mesma pelas atividades antrópicas.
useTrade: A espécie não é usada ou comercializada.
conservationActions: É uma espécie prioritária para conservação no Uruguai (Carreira and Estrades 2013). A espécie é contemplada pelo Plano de Ação Nacional para a Conservação dos Anfíbios e Répteis Ameaçados da Região Sul do Brasil (Brasil 2012). Ocorre no Parque Estadual de Itapeva, Parque Nacional da Lagoa do Peixe, Estação Ecológica do Taim e Refúgio da Vida Silvestre Banhado dos Pachecos. Monitoramento das subpopulações de Liolaemus occipitalis, principalmente no Litoral Norte do Rio Grande do Sul, onde seria necessária uma área de preservação das dunas. Sugere-se a criação de uma Unidade de Conservação restritiva nas dunas da Praia da Joaquina, no município de Florianópolis, Santa Catarina.

rationale: Liolaemus curicensis has been assessed as Least Concern because, although the distribution is limited (with an estimated extent of occurrence of 5,100 km2), the species is locally very abundant with no sign of a major population decline and the only threats are localized.
habitat: This species is found in Andean shrublands and rocky areas and hillsides. It is a viviparous species that feeds on arthropods (Pincheira-Donoso et al. 2008).
threats: This species is locally threatened by mining operations (copper) and three hydroelectric projects.
population: This species is very abundant where it occurs. There is no sign of a population decline.
range: This species is endemic to Chile, occurring in O'Higgins, Metropolitan, and Maule Regions (Pincheira-Donoso and Nuñez 2005), at elevations between 900 and 2,600 m asl (Núñez 1996, P. Espejo, unpubl. data).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: There are currently no conservation measures in place for this species, nor are any needed. The species does not occur in any protected areas.

rationale: This species is assessed as Critically Endangered due to its very small range (with an extent of occurrence of 10 km<sup>2</sup>), extreme, recent population decline from very abundant to just a few individuals, nearly complete destruction of its habitat due to the construction of hydroelectric plants, and lack of occurrence in any protected area. This species is on the brink of extinction.
habitat: This species occurs in rocky areas of Andean shrubland. It has an insectivorous diet and a viviparous reproductive mode (Núñez 1996, Pincheira-Donoso and Núñez 2005, Ministerio del Medio Ambiente 2013).
threats: This species is severely threatened by three hydroelectric projects that have nearly obliterated its habitat. Although many individuals were translocated to another area, this area was in turn destroyed for further hydroelectric development. (Ministerio del Medio Ambiente 2013, H. Núñez, unpubl. data 2015).
population: Due to hydroelectric development, the population of this species has apparently suffered a precipitous decline. Although the species was once very abundant, only three individuals were seen in 2015 (J. Mella, unpubl. data).
range: This species is endemic to Chile, occurring in Termas del Flaco (north bank of the River Tinguiririca) and Damas River, O'Higgins Region (Pincheira-Donoso and Nuñez 2005, Ministerio del Medio Ambiente 2013). In Termas de Flaco the species was collected at 1,520 to 3,000 m asl  (Nuñez 1996, Pincheira-Donoso and Nuñez 2005).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: The species was classified as Critically Endangered (CR) by the Chilean Environmental Ministry (Ministerio del Medio Ambiente 2013). Conservation measures needed are ex situ reproduction and search for suitable habitat to translocate the few remaining individuals.

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern because, although the distribution is limited (with an estimated extent of occurrence of 8,700 km<sup>2</sup>), it is locally abundant, the population trend appears to be stable, there are no major threats, and it occurs in a protected area.
habitat: This species is found in a variety of dry, sandy habitats such as desert and shrubland (Pincheira-Donoso and Núñez 2005). It has oviparous reproduction (Pincheira-Donoso et al. 2008).
threats: This species may be locally threatened by mining, solar farms, and wind farms, but is not subject to major threats across most of its range.
population: This species is locally abundant and the population apparently stable. It appears to undergo population fluctuations tied to El Niño-Southern Oscillation (ENSO) events. Populations explode after ENSO rains that cause widespread vegetative growth (P. Valladares pers. comm. 2015).
range: This species is endemic to Chile, occurring from the Atacama to northern Coquimbo Region (Pincheira-Donoso and Núñez 2005), at elevations between sea level and 2,000 m asl (Pincheira-Donoso et al. 2008).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. It is classified as Rare by the Reglamento de la Ley de Caza of the Ministerio de Agricultura (MMA 2014) and occurs in Llanos de Challe National Park.

rationale: This species is listed as Least Concern because, although the distribution is limited (extent of occurrence of 12,000 km<sup>2</sup>), it is locally abundant, the population trend appears to be stable, there are no major threats, and it occurs in two protected areas.
habitat: This species is found in sandy desert shrubland habitats (Pincheira-Donoso and Núñez 2005). It has oviparous reproduction and its diet is insectivorous (Pincheira-Donoso et al. 2008, G. Lobos, unpubl. data 2015).
threats: This species is locally threatened by mining, coastal port development, and thermoelectric plants.
population: This species has been reported as one of the most abundant species at some sites (e.g. Morrillos). Its population is likely to be stable. It appears to undergo population fluctuations tied to El Niño-Southern  Oscillation (ENSO) events. Populations explode after ENSO rains that cause  widespread vegetative growth (P. Valladares pers. comm. 2015).
range: This species is endemic to Chile, occurring in the lowlands of Atacama and Antofagasta Regions (Pincheira-Donoso and Núñez 2005, Troncoso-Palacios and Garin 2013). It has an elevation range between sea level to 250 m asl (Pincheira-Donoso et al. 2008).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: There are currently no species-specific conservation measures in place or needed for this species. It occurs in Llanos de Challe and Pan de Azucar National Parks.

rationale: Listed as Vulnerable, as this species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 8,119 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in at least two but no more than ten threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: The primary habitat type in Sinharaja World Heritage Site is broadly regarded as tropical lowland evergreen forest (Biju et al. 2014). Specimens of this species were found on the banks of streams and in marshy areas under forest cover. These marshy areas are covered with a thick layer of leaf litter. Its breeding season is May through August (Biju et al. 2014), and it breeds by larval development (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). This species is not thought to be tolerant to habitat disturbance (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).
threats:
Threats to this species include small-scale firewood collection, human-induced fires, encroaching human settlements, small-scale hydropower stations, encroaching large- and small-scale agriculture (including tea, cinnamon, rubber, and oil palm plantations), and the resulting pollution from the use of pesticides and chemical fertilizers (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). 

Climate change also poses a threat to this species. This is the only perhumid region in all of South Asia, where the dry season is short, with an average rainfall of at least 100 mm per month, which explains its biodiversity-rich mixed-dipterocarp forests. While there does not appear to be a negative rainfall trend in this region, warming is predicted to result in reduced surface moisture. While the southwest monsoon rainy period (May-July) is gradually becoming longer, the first intermonsoon (March-April) is yielding less rain, delaying the onset of the rains that follow the December-February dry season. These factors combine to increase the risk of forest fires (natural fires are unknown in rainforests).
population: This species was considered to be relatively abundant at the type locality during the breeding season (May-August) (Biju et al. 2014). In general it is uncommon, however is found to be common in marshes and flood plains (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). A decreasing population trend is inferred from the ongoing decline in the quality and extent of the species' habitat.
range: This species is known from its type locality of Kudawa, Sinharaja, Ratnapura District, Sri Lanka, where it was recorded at an elevation of 517 m asl (Biju et al. 2014). Additionally, records from Kudawa in Sinharaja forest and the adjacent Kanneliya Forest Reserve that were previously allocated to I. aurantiaca have now been assigned to this species (Biju et al. 2014). This species occurs from sea level to 660 m asl, is likely restricted to its known range and therefore unlikely to occur more widely (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). The extent of occurrence (EOO) of its mapped range is 8,119 km2, which is thought to represent at least two but no more than ten threat-defined locations due to changing intensities of agriculture and development.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is known to occur in several protected areas, including Sinharaja World Heritage Site and Honduwa Sanctuary (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).

Conservation Needed
Continued and strengthened management of protected area(s) where this species occurs, and expanded protection of suitable habitat elsewhere in its range is needed.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the threats of encroaching agriculture and development, as well as the potential impacts of climate change.

rationale: This species is listed as Near Threatened because the distribution is limited (with an extent of occurrence of 2,700 km<sup>2</sup>) and there are several threats within this small range. However, the species occurs in two protected areas in which these activities do not operate and so, while the population status is not known, the species is probably not at immediate risk of extinction. Monitoring is needed to understand the population trends, especially in consideration of several development projects planned within the distribution. The species nearly qualifies for Vulnerable applying Criterion B1ab(iii), however, it is not clear whether it occurs at fewer than 10 locations or as a severely fragmented population.
habitat: This fossorial species is from arid habitats, being found in xeric woods and transitional areas between xeric lowlands and mesic uplands such as wooded ravines (Henderson and Powell 2009). It occurs in plantations and possibly pastures and gardens. It feeds on earthworms, insects (including termites), and small vertebrates (Joglar 2005).
threats: This species is threatened by development for housing, commercial areas, and infrastructure (including for wind energy).
population: This species is rarely encountered, probably due to its secretive fossorial habits. The species has been recorded as recently as 2015 (R. Thomas pers. comm. 2015). More research is needed to understand the population trend of this species in its range outside protected areas, where it is subject to localized pressures, to understand the overall population trend, however, part of the distribution falls within protected areas.
range: This species is endemic to southwestern Puerto Rico and has an elevation range from sea level to about 600 m asl (Henderson and Powell 2009).
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: This species occurs in Guanica and Susua State Forests. More research is recommended into population trends.

rationale: This species is listed as Near Threatened because the distribution is limited (with an extent of occurrence of 720 km<sup>2</sup>) and there are several threats within the small range. However, the species occurs in three protected areas and, while the species is presently common, population monitoring is needed to determine the effect of development projects on the population of this species.
habitat: This species is from xeric habitats including dry forest, scrub, and littoral vegetation. Its tolerance of disturbed habitats is unknown. It is found under rocks and plant debris such as palm fronds. At night it has been found in cactus. It is an egg laying species (Henderson and Powell 2009).
threats: This species is potentially threatened by development for housing, commercial areas, and infrastructure (including for wind energy).
population: In 1997-1998, the density of this species was estimated to range from 104-208 individuals/ha (Genet et al. 2001). Recent observations suggest the abundance has not changed substantially (R. Joglar pers. comm. 2015).
range: This species is known only from Puerto Rico where it occurs along the southern coast and the  Isla Caja de Muertos (Henderson and Powell 2009). The elevation ranges from sea level to approximately 100 m.
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in these species.
conservationActions:
There are no species-specific conservation measures in place for this species. It occurs in the Guanica and Boquerón State Forests and Caja de Muerto Natural Reserve.

Population monitoring is needed to determine the effect of development projects on the population of this species.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 1,004 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in four threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: Both adults and juveniles of this species have been recorded living in and around clear, relatively cold, fast-flowing streams in montane cloud forest that are shaded with 70–90% tree canopy cover  (Wickramasinghe et al. 2012, Gabadage et al. 2014). Water temperature in the streams range between 16.9–18.6 degrees C (17.8 ± 0.5 degrees C) and the depth of water varies from 40–80 cm. Individuals have been commonly observed on the moss-covered boulders by, next to, and in streams. Most boulders have accumulated leaf litter on the surface, under which individuals and amplectant pairs have been found (Gabadage et al. 2014). All juveniles were observed near stream banks covered with leaf litter and gravel. All other individuals were found on the land within ~1-2 m of water. Of the males observed, 89% were found on boulders (2–4 m circumference, 30–50 cm above the water level) in mid-stream (Gabadage et al. 2014). When disturbed, individuals of this species dive into the streams and retreat into submerged rocky crevices, remaining underwater up to 15–25 minutes without emerging. Ten pairs in amplexus have also been found underwater, but no details of egg laying and development have been noted (Gabadage et al. 2014). It is expected to breed in streams by larval development, as with its congeners. This species is not likely to tolerate habitat disturbance (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).
threats:
Within the Peak Wilderness Nature Reserve, Sripada Peak is a place of worship of all religions in the country of Sri Lanka, with millions of visitors, especially during the six-month-long peak tourism season. During this time, a large amount of garbage collects, light pollution increases, and the forest is exploited (Wickramasinghe et al. 2013). A stream at one of the popular tourist sites, 'Seethagagula', has been blocked in one place by a private company, and the water has been diverted to an artificial tank to facilitate a place for visitors to bathe (M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. February 2020). Downstream from this site large amounts of domestic chemicals (e.g., shampoo) are being disposed of in the stream, and it is suspected that this could negatively impact amphibian populations given that large aggregations of tadpoles (not of this species) were observed at higher elevations of the same stream, but in areas below the polluted site low densities or no individuals were observed (M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. February 2020). Furthermore, during the dry season the reduced volume of water in the stream may lead to greater concentrations of chemicals in the breeding pools (M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. February 2020).

Tea cultivation in the surrounding areas is slowly expanding, and illegal tree felling to cultivate tea has become a major threat in the area. Additionally, during the wet season fish species such as the Stone Sucker (Garra ceylonensis) travel upstream and block the stream in several places, which could create a barrier for the breeding of this species as it is suspected to breed in streams (M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. February 2020). Invasive plant species are also suspected of causing changes to the understory and canopy cover of the area (M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. February 2020). Road construction and the planting of non-native tree species may lead to soil erosion and landslides, making existing habitat unsuitable for this species (Gabadage et al. 2014). Within Piduruthalagala Forest Reserve, the construction of mini hydropower stations pose a threat to the species (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). 

Climate change also presents a threat to this species, as annual rainfall is declining steeply across this region, especially on the perhumid western slopes. This area is becoming markedly drier and more seasonal. From an annual average rainfall of about 2,500 mm of rain a century ago, the highlands now receive around 1,900 mm, and years with less than 1,500 are increasingly common (De Silva and Sonnadara 2016).  This reduction in rainfall occurs largely during the first intermonsoon in March-April, extending the duration of the usual December-February dry period. There has been a decline in rainfall of about 4 mm per year during the first intermonsoon and southwest monsoon over the past century, with a lesser decrease of 0.5 mm per year during the northeast monsoon. Additionally, the percentage of wet days during the southwest monsoon has decreased from 59% to 47% over the past century (Thavakaran et al. 2019). Added to changes in the spatial and temporal distribution of rainfall is the fact that the climate is also warming, with average annual temperatures rise of about 0.8° C across the country over the past century, and temperature in the highlands rise by about 1.1° C (De Costa 2008).  These factors combine to increase the risk of forest fires (natural fires are unknown in rainforests). 

Forest dieback could be an additional threat to this species. It was first observed in Sri Lanka’s montane ‘cloud’ forests by Perera (1978). Prior to 2013, dieback was never documented within Peak Wilderness, and now a large area has been affected (Wickramasinghe et al. 2013).Despite several studies (see Ranasinghe and Dissanayake 2003, Ranasinghe et al. 2007, Chandrajith et al. 2009), the aetiology of  dieback remains enigmatic, though there has been concern that an environmental stressor that kills extensive stands of woody vegetation, apart from the loss of suitable habitats for amphibians, may also directly threaten amphibians. Gunawardena et al. (1998) and Jayalal et al. (2017) suggest that high acidity in mist- and rain-water may present a significant risk to the highland biota in Sri Lanka. While there is no direct evidence to date (see Silva et al. 2019) that amphibians are negatively affected; it is thought to be a threat for species that inhabit areas where mist persists for long periods, and for species found in open habitats with aquatic life history stages in shallow lentic habitats (M. Meegaskumbura pers. comm. February 2020).
population: This species was previously known from only two specimens (Wickramasinghe et al. 2012). There had been no sightings since the original description and the species was believed to be extinct (Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda 1998), given that surveys in the the general area of Kandy turned up no new records. It was rediscovered in 2009, when close to 100 individuals were recorded over the course of a two-year study to document amphibian species richness across an elevational gradient (Wickramasinghe et al. 2012). Another subpopulation of 57 individuals was discovered 42 km away during further surveys from 2011-2014 (Gabadage et al. 2014). This species is thought to be common in suitable habitats during the wet season, however the pristine stream habitats in which it occurs are difficult to find (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). A decreasing population trend is inferred from the ongoing decline in the quality and extent of its habitat.
range:
This species is endemic to Sri Lanka and for a long time was known only from the general type locality of "Ceylon" (= Sri Lanka). The scientific name appeared to suggest that it might have been collected in the vicinity of the city of Kandy in central Sri Lanka; however, all of the Central Province was referred to as Kandy in the late 19th century, when the species was described (Wickramasinghe et al. 2012). 

In 2009 the species was rediscovered in the Peak Wilderness Sanctuary in Central Province, Sri Lanka, at 1,879 m asl (Wickramasinghe et al. 2012). The Sanctuary comprises 240 km², of which 211.75 km² have natural or semi-natural vegetation (Wickramasinghe et al. 2012). Its eastern boundary is adjacent to Horton Plains National Park (Wickramasinghe et al. 2012). In 2014, Gabadage et al. published a report of this species from another locality, in the southern portion of Pidurutalagala Forest Reserve from 1,400-1,600 m asl, which is ~42 km from the population in Peak Wilderness Sanctuary. It has since also been recorded from Hirikatuoya (S. Wijayasekara unpub. data February 2020) and Canyon village in Maskeliya (D. Kandambi unpub. data February 2020). Adenomus dasi has also been synonymised with this species, which provides additional individuals in Moray Estate in the Peak Wilderness Sanctuary (Meegaskumbura et al. 2015). 

Overall, this species occurs at elevations ranging between 1,000-1,879 m asl (Wickramasinghe et al. 2012, Gabadage et al. 2014, Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). This species is thought to be restricted to its known range, although it likely occurs at suitable elevations between mapped localities (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 1,004 km2, which is thought to represent four threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
Although this species is found within the Peak Wilderness Sanctuary, which has been declared part of the Central Hills World Heritage Sites, its habitat is under severe human pressure (Wickramasinghe et al. 2012). It is also found within Piduruthalagala Forest Reserve and Hirikatuoya (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).

Conservation Needed
Continued and strengthened management of protected areas where this species occurs, and expanded protection of cloud forest elsewhere in its range is needed.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the threats of tourism, pollution, encroaching agriculture, hydropower development, and the potential impacts of climate change.

rationale:
In view of the small subpopulation sizes estimated to date (Table 1 in the Supplementary Material) it is plausible that there could well be fewer than 10,000 mature individuals, and an assessment of the threatened status of the Australian Humpback Dolphincan be inferred under criterion C. Australian Humpback Dolphins live in small geographically isolated subpopulations connected by limited gene flow. No subpopulation studied to date (Table 1 in the Supplementary Material) is estimated to contain more than 104 mature individuals. Therefore, it is highly likely that the largest subpopulation across their range would be < 1000 mature individuals. Anthropogenic mortality of only 3.7, 4.1 and 5.3 individuals per year from a population of 100 individuals would result in 30%, 50% and 80% declines in population abundance after 3 generations, respectively (see Moore 2015 Table 5).

Given the number of development projects that are underway or proposed throughout a great proportion of the species’ range in Australia (Fig. 2 in the Supplementary Material) a continuing decline in the number of mature individuals is projected. There are indications already of considerable declines in at least some locations along the Queensland coast, which are potentially linked to environmental stressors (Cagnazzi 2013). Habitat degradation and loss is ongoing and expected to increase across the species’ range in Australia (Allen et al. 2012; Bejder et al. 2012; Cagnazzi et al. 2013b). The loss and fragmentation of suitable habitats is one of the primary drivers of population declines for species following a metapopulation structure model such as humpback dolphins (Brown et al. 2014, Cagnazzi 2010, Schnell et al. 2013). Additionally, the species’ range is considered a hotspot of future extinction risk for marine mammals because of cumulative human impacts (Davidson et al. 2012).

Considering the available evidence and following a precautionary approach we considered this species as Vulnerable under IUCN criterion C2a(i) because the total number of mature individuals is plausibly fewer than 10,000, a projected continuing decline due to cumulative impacts; and each of the defined subpopulations studied to date is estimated to contain fewer than 1,000 mature individuals. Although the species may not meet any of the criteria for Endangered at this time, it is likely to do so in the near future considering It is possible that 1) number of mature individuals is less than 2,500, 2) the reductions in population size have been larger and pervasive enough to cause a net reduction for the entire species of at least 20% over a period of 2 generations and 3) that the number of mature individuals in each subpopulation across their range is ≤ 250 individuals.
habitat:
Within their geographical range Australian Humpback Dolphins are found primarily in coastal waters. Opportunistic data collected during aerial surveys designed to estimate the distribution and abundance of Dugongs (Dugong dugon) in the Great Barrier Reef indicated that Australian Humpback Dolphins were sighted on average 6.4 km (se = 1.26, Range 0-55.6 km) from the nearest point of land and 2.7 km (std. err. = 0.27, range = 0-8.1 km) to the nearest shallow area (either point of land or charted reef, less than 2m deep at low tide) (Corkeron et al. 1997). In Queensland and in the Northern Territory humpback dolphins are found mostly within 10 km off the coast (Palmer et al. 2014b, Parra et al. 2004, Parra et al. 2006b). Accordingly, in Keppel Bay, Central Queensland, where up to 10 km offshore waters still remain below 10m in depth, Australian Humpback Dolphins were recorded on average 2.8 km (SD = 4.21, Range = 0-24 km) off the coast. In Western Australia, sightings obtained from recent exploratory surveys and ongoing studies seem to confirm a similar pattern, with the majority of the sightings obtained within 5 km off the coast (Brown and Hunt personal communication). In Papua New Guinea, the first tentative sightings of Australian Humpback Dolphins were made in the Kikori Delta region; close to the coastline and in waters 1.6-11.4 m deep (Beasley et al. 2014).

While coastal waters are arguably the primary habitat of Australian Humpback Dolphins, most survey work has been conducted close to the coast, thus the extent to which humpback dolphins use offshore waters is not yet fully understood. Observations of Australian Humpback Dolphins at least up to 55.6 km from land, indicate that this species may occasionally venture further offshore especially in sheltered and protected waters such as in the Great Barrier Reef where sand flats occur almost continuously from the mainland to the outer reefs (Corkeron et al. 1997).

Along the Australian Coast Humpback Dolphins are more likely to be found in relatively shallow and protected coastal habitats such as inlets, estuaries, shallow bays, inshore reefs and coastal archipelagos rather than in open stretches of coastline. In Queensland and Northern Territory, humpback dolphins are mainly found in water less than 20 km from the nearest river mouth and in water less than 15-20 m deep (Parra et al. 2004). Few animals have been observed in waters up to 30-50 m deep, but remained in close proximity (within 5 km) to the coast (Parra et al. 2004). In both Queensland and Northern Territory humpback dolphins have been also recorded as far as 20-50 km upstream in large rivers such as the East Alligator River, Northern Territory, and in the Fitzroy and Brisbane rivers in Queensland (Cagnazzi 2010, Palmer et al. 2014b, Parra et al. 2004). No studies on habitat use have been conducted in Western Australia. Preliminary surveys and ongoing studies in few locations indicate that Australian Humpback Dolphins appear to utilize a wide range of near-shore habitats. For example, around the North West Cape, dolphins have been sighted in clear waters over Ningaloo Reef, and in turbid waters in Exmouth Gulf, and in depths ranging from 1 to 40 m deep (T. Hunt 2015, pers. comm., 19 February)

Among subpopulations there appear to be some differences in habitat selection suggesting high adaptability of this species to local environment characteristics. For example, in Cleveland Bay Australian Humpback Dolphins showed preferences for waters close to the coast and 2-5 m deep, followed by waters 1-2 m deep whereas in Keppel Bay (~630 Km south) humpback dolphins showed preference for waters 2-5 and 5-10 m deep, while In Port Curtis (~700 km further south) humpback dolphins showed preference for water 5-10 and 10-15 m deep. Within these regions humpback dolphins showed selection for various types of habitats including dredged channels, reefs, seagrass flats and mangroves.
