Monitor population trends at breeding colonies and at sea. Study the routes used between nesting colonies and the sea (Medrano et al. 2019). Research the areas used at sea and the marine threats. Research the impact of light pollution; reduce and mitigate the consequences of this threat. Further improve fledgling rescue operations and carry out citizen education campaigns in Peru and Chile. Protect known breeding colonies and flight paths between colonies and the sea (Medrano et al. 2019).

rationale: Even though the population size of this species is very large, it breeds only in a small number of relatively small colonies, which are threatened by habitat degradation. The population is considered to be in decline due to various threats, but the rate of decline is not known. The species is therefore classified as Near Threatened.
habitat: Markham’s Storm-petrel breeds in dispersed colonies in saline areas, using fissures and holes created by saltpetre deposits for nesting (Tobias et al. 2006, Schmitt et al. 2015, Barros et al. 2019). In Paracas, the species breeds in small, dispersed colonies up to 5 km from the sea on sloping ground (Tobias et al. 2006). The colonies in Chile are located on the east of the Cordillera de la Costa mountain range at up to 50 km distance from the sea (Barros et al. 2019, Medrano et al. 2019). In Chile, known colonies are located at 600-1,100 m a.s.l. (Medrano et al. 2019). Reproduction can be asynchronous within a colony (Barros et al. 2019). Nevertheless, in the northern colonies in Paracas, near Arica and in Salar de Quiuña, most pairs lay eggs between April and August, and are with chicks between July and January (Jahnke 1994, Barros et al. 2019, Medrano et al. 2019). Pairs breeding in the colonies of Pampa Perdiz, Salar Grande and Salar de Navidad further south lay eggs between November and January, while chicks hatch between January and April (Malinarich et al. 2018, Barros et al. 2019, Medrano et al. 2019). The species feeds opportunistically both inshore and offshore on fish, crustaceans and cephalopods (Garcia-Godos et al. 2002). Adults arrive at the colonies at least 45 min after sunset (Barros et al. 2019).
threats: The principle threat faced by Markham’s Storm-petrel is the mining of saltpetre from the salt plain on which it nests (Torres-Mura and Lemus 2013, Barros et al. 2019). This has resulted in the loss of considerable amounts of breeding habitat, as it destroys the burrows and crevices in which nests are placed (Schmitt et al. 2015, Barros et al. 2019). Light pollution also represents a significant level of mortality, with 10-20 fresh corpses reported each morning next to a single light close to a breeding colony (Schmitt et al. 2015). It is assumed that fledglings are attracted to the lights of nearby cities during their first flights (Torres-Mura and Lemus 2013, Schmitt et al. 2015), and already few, strong light sources may affect large parts of a breeding colony (F. Medrano in litt. 2019). It has been estimated that each year around 20,000 fledglings die because of light pollution, representing 1/3 of the entire cohort (F. Medrano in litt. 2019). Light-pollution was found to be a severe threat to seabirds and Hydrobatidae in particular, which can potentially have a detrimental effect on the overall population size (Rodriguez et al. 2017). Further threats include infrastructure developments (roads, wind farms and power lines), military exercises and garbage (Barros et al. 2019). Overall, given the severity of the threats presented by mining and light pollution and their potentially detrimental impacts on the population size, the number of locations of occurrence (as defined by the most severe threat) is assumed to be relatively small.
population: A minimum of 2,305 pairs were present on the Paracas peninsula in 1992 (Tobias et al. 2006). Following the recent discovery of several large breeding colonies in the Atacama Desert (Schmitt et al. 2015, Barros et al. 2019), the global population was estimated to number c.50,000-60,000 breeding pairs (Schmitt et al. 2015, Barros et al. 2019, Medrano et al. 2019). This equates to 100,000-120,000 mature individuals, or 150,000-180,000 individuals in total.
range: Markham’s Storm-petrel (Hydrobates markhami) occurs in the tropical zone of the eastern Pacific Ocean. Between July and September, it is found over warm, equatorial waters, while between January and July it moves to cooler waters of the Peru Current and further west (Pyle 1993, Spear and Ainley 2007). It breeds on the Paracas peninsula on the coast of central Peru and in the Atacama Desert of southern Peru and northern Chile (Carboneras 1992, Barros et al. 2019). In Paracas, the species forms six breeding colonies (Medrano et al. 2019), which were estimated at a minimum of c.2,300 pairs in 1992 (Tobias et al. 2006). In Chile, several colonies have been discovered recently: near Arica, the species breeds in five colonies, of which two colonies hold fewer than 10 pairs (Pampa Tana, Pampa La Higuera), one colony holds 90 pairs (Pampa Chuño), another colony around 10,000 pairs (Pampa Camarones), and the largest colony around 25,000 pairs (Pampa Chaca; Barros et al. 2019, Medrano et al. 2019). Further colonies were located in Tarapacá and Antofagasta regions: The colony in Salar de Quiuña is estimated at c.400 breeding pairs, the colony in Pampa La Perdiz at c.600 pairs, the colony in Salar Grande at 20,000 pairs and a smaller colony further south in Salar de Navidad at fewer than 10 pairs (Barros et al. 2019, Medrano et al. 2019). It is assumed that several more breeding colonies could be located around the border of Chile and Peru, and in Mejillones and Antofagasta (Barros et al. 2019).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions Underway

Surveys are being carried out to locate new breeding colonies and to estimate the population size (Barros et al. 2019, Medrano et al. 2019). Grounded fledglings are rescued and released by the Servicio Agricola y Ganadero.

Conservation Actions Proposed

Expand the search for new breeding colonies and estimate their population size. Monitor the known colonies. Study the species's ecological requirements, breeding biology, post-breeding movements, and the connectivity between colonies or breeding areas. Assess threats to the species and their impacts on the population size and trend. Protect the breeding colonies and flight paths to the sea (Barros et al. 2019). Reduce the impact of light pollution in northern Chile (Barros et al. 2019). Continue and expand the rescue and release programme for grounded fledglings.

rationale: Listed as Vulnerable, as this species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 12,878 km<sup>2</sup>, it is thought to occur in 10 or fewer threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: This species is normally terrestrial, but can also be semi-arboreal, and is associated with hill streams in tropical wet forest. According to Bopage et al. (2011), the preferred microhabitat of this species is shaded rocky terrain near streams in dense forest. Adults have been observed in rock crevices, leaf-litter and decaying logs, and within tree holes. Larvae are found in permanent pools. This species is not likely to tolerate habitat disturbance (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).
threats:
Threats to this species include small-scale firewood collection, human-induced fires, encroaching human settlements, small-scale hydropower stations, encroaching large- and small-scale agriculture (including tea, cinnamon, rubber, and oil palm plantations), and the resulting pollution from the use of pesticides and chemical fertilizers (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Illegal gem mining taking place in the area is also a threat to this species' habitat (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). 

Additionally, climate change potentially poses a threat, as this species range includes the only perhumid region in all of South Asia where the dry season is short, with an average rainfall of at least 100 mm per month, which explains its biodiversity-rich mixed-dipterocarp forests. While there does not appear to be a negative rainfall trend in this region, warming is predicted to result in reduced surface moisture. While the southwest monsoon rainy period (May-July) is gradually becoming longer, the first intermonsoon (March-April) is yielding less rain, delaying the onset of the rains that follow the December-February dry season. These factors combine to increase the risk of forest fires (natural fires are unknown in rainforests).
population: This species is relatively abundant where it has been recorded (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). A decreasing population trend is inferred from the ongoing decline in the quality and extent of this species' habitat.
range: This species is a Sri Lankan endemic and is found over much of the southwest quarter of the island where it has been recorded at elevations between 30-1,230 m asl. It is likely to be restricted to its known range and will occur between known localities at appropriate elevations (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). The extent of occurrence (EOO) of its mapped range is 12,878 km<sup>2</sup> and is thought to represent ten or fewer threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species has been recorded from several protected areas, including the Peak Wilderness Forest Reserve, Sinharaja World Heritage Site, Kanneliya Reserve Forest, Haycock Forest Reserve, Gilimale-Eratne Forest Reserve and Kitulgala Forest Reserve. 

Conservation Needed
Continued and strengthened management of protected area(s) where this species occurs, and expanded protection of suitable habitat elsewhere in its range is needed.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the threats of deforestation, agro-chemical pollution, and encroaching agriculture within its known range, as well as the potential impacts of climate change.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 3,623 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in at least four but no more than five threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: This terrestrial species is associated with wet leaf-litter, rocks and other ground cover, and occurs close to streams in tropical wet montane forest. This species is not thought to tolerate habitat disturbance (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Its breeding strategy has not been recorded, but reproduction presumably takes place in water, probably in streams, by larval development.
threats:
Threats to this area include small-scale firewood collection, human-induced fires, encroaching human settlements, small-scale hydropower stations, encroaching large- and small-scale agriculture (including tea, cinnamon, rubber, and oil palm plantations), and the resulting pollution from the use of pesticides and chemical fertilizers (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). 

Climate change also poses a potential threat. This is the only perhumid region in all of South Asia where the dry season is short, with an average rainfall of at least 100 mm per month, which explains its biodiversity-rich mixed-dipterocarp forests. While there does not appear to be a negative rainfall trend in this region, warming is predicted to result in reduced surface moisture. While the southwest monsoon rainy period (May-July) is gradually becoming longer, the first intermonsoon (March-April) is yielding less rain, delaying the onset of the rains that follow the December-February dry season. These factors combine to increase the risk of forest fires (natural fires are unknown in rainforests).

Forest dieback could be an additional threat to this species, especially within the Peak Wilderness Reserve. This could potentially be a result of climate change or pollution, however the exact cause is unknown. Prior to 2013, dieback was never documented in this region and now a large area has been affected (Wickramasinghe et al. 2013).
population: This species is uncommon (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). A decreasing population trend is inferred from the ongoing decline in the quality and extent of the species' habitat.
range: This species was previously only known from the Kitulgala Forest Reserve, Messana Forest Reserve, Peak Wilderness Nature Reserve [at low elevations] and Sinharaja World Heritage Site in southwestern Sri Lanka. It has now also been recorded from Erathna in Sripada and Udamaliboda (D. Gabadage pers. comm. February 2020). It occurs at elevations ranging between 150-1,070 m asl. This species is thought to be restricted to its known range and is therefore unlikely to occur much more widely than what is currently mapped (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). The extent of occurrence (EOO) of this updated distribution is 3,623 km<sup>2</sup>, which is thought to represent at least four but no more than five threat-defined locations due to the changing intensity of encroaching agriculture and development across its range.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species has been recorded from several protected areas, including the Kitulgala Forest Reserve, Messana Forest Reserve, Peak Wilderness Nature Reserve and the Sinharaja World Heritage Site.

Conservation Needed
Expansion of effective forest preservation and continued management of existing protected areas is essential for the conservation of this species.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the threats of agricultural work in the area.

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered because of a population decline estimated to have been of at least 80% over the past 10 years, based on the very obvious decline in records from suitable habitat. While the exact causes of the decline are unknown, possible causes include the impacts of climate change, ongoing decline in the quality and extent of its habitat (including the effects of pollution), and the possible influence of diseases such as chytridiomycosis.
habitat: This terrestrial species is found in, and around, tropical lowland moist forest. Adults have been recorded from shaded rubber plantations, tea estates, and well-covered domestic gardens bordering the forest, however they require a high degree of forest cover (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). The breeding habitat is not known, but it is assumed to breed by larval development, and the generation length of this species is 2 years (M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. February 2020). This species is not thought to tolerate habitat disturbance (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).
threats:
Threats to this area include small-scale firewood collection, human-induced fires, encroaching human settlements, small-scale hydropower stations, encroaching large- and small-scale agriculture (including tea, cinnamon, rubber, and oil palm plantations), and the resulting pollution from the use of pesticides and chemical fertilizers (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). 

Climate change also poses a threat to this species. This is the only perhumid region in all of South Asia where the dry season is short, with an average rainfall of at least 100 mm per month, which explains its biodiversity-rich mixed-dipterocarp forests. While there does not appear to be a negative rainfall trend in this region, warming is predicted to result in reduced surface moisture. While the southwest monsoon rainy period (May-July) is gradually becoming longer, the first intermonsoon (March-April) is yielding less rain, delaying the onset of the rains that follow the December-February dry season. These factors combine to increase the risk of forest fires (natural fires are unknown in rainforests). 

The recent apparent disappearance or near-disappearance of the species at its known sites, even in suitable habitat, is characteristic of a decline caused by chytridiomycosis. However this is not confirmed, and further work is required for verification.
population:
This species is very rare, and while it has always been rare, in recent years observations of the species within suitable forest habitat have decreased (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). The last observations of this species were in 2018 in Kanneliya Forest Reserve and at the type locality (M. Wickramasinghe and D. Gabadage pers. comm. February 2020). Two individuals were recorded at Kanneliya Forest Reserve, however no subsequent surveys have been conducted (M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. February 2020). A single individual was recorded from the type locality, and no further records have been made despite repeated survey efforts to the area (D. Gabadage unpub. data February 2020). 

Therefore, within the last ten years, a population decline of at least 80% is estimated to have taken place based on obvious decline in records in suitable habitat, however the exact causes are unknown (M. Wickramasinghe, R. Pethiyagoda, D. Samarasinghe pers. comm. February 2020). In addition to this past decline, a decreasing population trend is inferred from the ongoing decline in quality and extent of habitat described in the threat section of this assessment.
range: This species has a restricted distribution in southwestern Sri Lanka, where it has been recorded at elevations between 50-500 m asl (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 3,289 km<sup>2</sup>, and its distribution is thought to represent at least three threat-defined locations, but not likely more than five, due to differing intensities of agricultural encroachment and development across its range.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species has been recorded from the Kanneliya Forest Reserve, Gilimale-Eratne Forest Reserve, and the Sinharaja World Heritage Site.

Conservation Needed
Expansion of effective forest preservation and continued management of existing protected areas is essential for the conservation of this species.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. Specifically, research is needed to determine the reasons for decline in suitable habitat. There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the threats of expanding forest conversion to agriculture and pollution due to agricultural effluents. Additionally, population surveys are urgently needed to locate the species, as it is becoming increasingly uncommon within its range.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 307 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in four threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: This is a terrestrial species associated with shaded, wet leaf-litter, in tropical moist forest. Larvae are found in inland wetlands and marshes, including old abandoned gem mining pits surrounded by tropical forest. This species is not thought to be tolerant to habitat disturbance as it requires canopy cover (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).
threats:
Threats to this species across its range include small-scale firewood collection, human-induced fires (in the northern portion of its range only), encroaching human settlements, small-scale hydropower stations, encroaching large- and small-scale agriculture (including tea and cinnamon plantations), and the resulting pollution from the use of pesticides and chemical fertilizers (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Within Morningside Reserve specifically, this species is threatened by the loss of forest canopy for expansion of cardamom and tea plantations at the expense of cloud forest habitat, clearing of undergrowth, small-scale collection of firewood, and encroaching human settlements. Changing agricultural practices within cardamom plantations could also negatively affect this species, particularly if the change involves the use of agro-chemicals. Small-scale potato cultivation and the resulting pollution from pesticide use also presents a threat to this species (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Lowland species (e.g. P. rus and hallidayi encroaching into highland habitats within the Morningside reserve may also constitute a threat to this species as it is displacing and out competing other species (M. Meegaskumbura pers. comm. February 2020). Additionally, invasive plant species (e.g. Acacia sp.) are actively being planted in the region, which is resulting in forest clearing as plantations expand (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Illegal gem mining taking place in the area is a threat to this species, although once these sites have been abandoned the remaining pits are used as breeding sites (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). 

Climate change also poses a threat to this species across its range, as this is the only perhumid region in all of South Asia where the dry season is short, with an average rainfall of at least 100 mm per month, which explains the biodiversity-rich mixed-dipterocarp forests. While there does not appear to be a negative rainfall trend in this region, warming is predicted to result in reduced surface moisture. While the southwest monsoon rainy period (May-July) is gradually becoming longer, the first intermonsoon (March-April) is yielding less rain, delaying the onset of the rains that follow the December-February dry season. These factors combine to increase the risk of forest fires (natural fires are unknown in rainforests).
population: This species is uncommon (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). However, it was found in large numbers at the type locality in 1996, perhaps benefiting from human modification of the habitat through the creation of mining pits, which this species uses for breeding (Fernando and Siriwardhane 1996). A decreasing population trend is inferred from the ongoing decline in the quality and extent of this species' habitat.
range: This species was previously known only from two sites in southern Sri Lanka: Morningside in eastern Sinharaja, and Mahawalatenna in Balangoda. It has now also been recorded from Hadapan Ella Plains (P. Samarawickrama unpub. data February 2020) and Gongala (D. Gabadage unpub. data February 2020). The recorded elevation range is 515-1,110 m asl, the extent of occurrence (EOO) of its expanded distribution is 307 km<sup>2</sup>, and it is expected to occur in four threat-defined locations. This species is likely restricted to its known localities (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species has been recorded from the Sinharaja World Heritage Site as well as Morningside Forest Reserve (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).

Conservation Needed
Continued and strengthened management of protected area(s) where this species occurs, and expanded protection of suitable habitat elsewhere in its range is needed.

Research Needed
There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the threats of encroaching agriculture and development, agro-chemical pollution, and the potential impacts of climate change.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 4,804 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in at least two but no more than five threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: Adults are terrestrial and arboreal, preferring lowland moist forest habitats. Breeding takes place in water-filled tree holes, with tadpoles documented inside. This species has not been recorded from modified habitats. During field observations in 2008-09, nearly 20 adult specimens of this species were found in differently sized phytotelmata at different heights, and one subadult was found in a stream (Bopage et al. 2011). Since this species is not a ground-dweller, it may choose trees as suitable microhabitats where it can prey effectively while remaining well camouflaged (Bopage et al. 2011). This species is not thought to tolerate habitat disturbance (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).
threats:
Threats to this area include small-scale firewood collection, human-induced fires, encroaching human settlements, small-scale hydropower stations, encroaching large- and small-scale agriculture (including tea, cinnamon, rubber, and oil palm plantations), clearing of undergrowth, and the resulting pollution from the use of pesticides and chemical fertilizers (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Within the Morningside Reserve, changing agricultural practices within cardamom plantations could also negatively affect this species, particularly if the change involves the use of agro-chemicals. Small-scale potato cultivation and the resulting pollution from pesticide use also presents a threat to this species (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). As a result of climate change, other lowland species (e.g. P. rus and hallidayi) encroaching into highland habitats within the Morningside reserve may also constitute a threat to this species as it is displacing and out competing other species (M. Meegaskumbura pers. comm. February 2020). Additionally, invasive plant species (e.g. Acacia sp.) are actively being planted in the region, which is resulting in forest clearing as these plantations spread (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). 

Climate change also poses a threat to this species, as its range includes the only perhumid region in all of South Asia (the dry season is short, with an average rainfall of at least 100 mm per month), which explains the regions biodiversity-rich mixed-dipterocarp forests. While there does not appear to be a negative rainfall trend in this region, warming is predicted to result in reduced surface moisture. While the southwest monsoon rainy period (May-July) is gradually becoming longer, the first intermonsoon (March-April) is yielding less rain, delaying the onset of the rains that follow the December-February dry season. The extended dry period has obvious consequences for non-aquatic amphibians such as the direct-developing Pseudophilautus. These factors combine to increase the risk of forest fires (natural fires are unknown in rainforests).
population: This species is uncommon (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). A decreasing population trend is inferred from the ongoing decline in the quality and extent of its habitat.
range: This species is endemic to Sri Lanka. The type series was collected at 150 m asl in Kanneliya Forest Reserve (near Galle) (Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda 2001), and the species is known from Central, Sabaragamuwa, Southern, and Western provinces (Garg et al. 2018). It has been recorded at elevations between 70-1,300 m asl (Karunarathna and Amarasinghe 2009, Bopage et al. 2011). This species is thought to be restricted to its known range (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 4,804 km2, which is thought to represent at least two but no more than five threat-defined locations, due to the widespread impacts of climate change and encroaching agriculture.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs in Morningside Forest Reserve, Peak Wilderness Nature Reserve, Kanneliya Forest Reserve, and Hiyare Forest Reserve (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). 

Conservation Needed
Continued and strengthened management of protected area(s) where this species occurs, and expanded protection of forest elsewhere in its range is needed. 

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. There is a need for close monitoring of the population status of this species given its habitat specialization and intolerance of disturbance.

rationale: The species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) is 8,428 km<sup>2</sup> and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat. It probably occurs in more than 10 locations and its population is probably not severely fragmented. Thus the species is close to qualifying for Vulnerable, and it is currently assessed as Near Threatened.
habitat: This species is arboreal, terrestrial, and sub-fossorial, and mostly inhabits moist montane forest. Adults can be found in leaf-litter, under ground cover, in tree holes and crevices, and in water tanks. Larvae are found in stagnant waters in small and shallow ground pools (Bowatte and Meegaskumbura 2011). It can also be found in gardens, secondary forest and other lightly disturbed areas. This species is a habitat-generalist facultative tree-hole breeder, which lays floating eggs (Wijayathilaka et al. 2018). The tadpoles of this species are filter feeders (Wijayathilaka et al. 2018). This species is likely to tolerate a degree of habitat disturbance (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).
threats:
Localized threats within the southwestern portion of this species' range include small-scale firewood collection, human-induced fires, encroaching human settlements, small-scale hydropower stations, encroaching large- and small-scale agriculture (including tea, cinnamon, rubber, and oil palm plantations), and the resulting pollution from the use of pesticides and chemical fertilizers (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). 

Climate change also poses a threat, as the range of this species includes the only perhumid region in all of South Asia, where the dry season is short, with an average rainfall of at least 100 mm per month, which explains its biodiversity-rich mixed-dipterocarp forests. While there does not appear to be a negative rainfall trend in this region, warming is predicted to result in reduced surface moisture. While the southwest monsoon rainy period (May-July) is gradually becoming longer, the first intermonsoon (March-April) is yielding less rain, delaying the onset of the rains that follow the December-February dry season. These factors combine to increase the risk of forest fires (natural fires are unknown in rainforests).
population: This species is locally common and its population is stable (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).
range: This species occurs in a number of isolated subpopulations in the low country wet zone and the central hills of Sri Lanka, including Sinharaja Forest, Knuckles Range, Namunukula and Udwattakele. It is found in the low hills of the Central, North Western, Sabaragamuwa, Southern and Uva Provinces (Frost 2019). It has an elevational range of 460-1,220 m asl. It may occur more widely and the number of threat-defined locations is thought to exceed ten (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). The extent of occurrence (EOO) of its currently mapped range is 8,428 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species has been recorded in a number of protected areas, including the Knuckles Range, Namunukula Forest Reserve, Sinharaja World Heritage Site, the Royal Botanical Gardens, and Udawattakele Reserve Forest.

Conservation Needed
Expansion of effective forest preservation and continued management of existing protected areas is essential for the conservation of this species. 

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the threats of encroaching human settlements and agriculture, as well as the resulting pollution, and the potential impacts of climate change.

rationale: Listed as Vulnerable, as this species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 8,722 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in at least three but no more than ten threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: It is a largely aquatic species, found mostly in rocky cascades, on wet rock surfaces and under boulders, in lowland and sub-montane tropical moist forest. It has also been recorded in disturbed areas, including home gardens, provided there is suitable aquatic habitat for breeding (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). This species breeds by larval development, and tadpoles are often found on wet rock surfaces. This species is thought to be tolerant to a degree of habitat disturbance (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).
threats:
Threats to this area include small-scale firewood collection, human-induced fires, encroaching human settlements, small-scale hydropower stations, encroaching large- and small-scale agriculture (including tea, cinnamon, rubber, and oil palm plantations), and the resulting pollution from the use of pesticides and chemical fertilizers (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Granite quarrying also presents a threat to this species throughout its range (M. Meegaskumbura and M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. F ebruary 2020). 

Additionally, climate change poses a threat to this species, as its range includes the only perhumid region in all of South Asia, where the dry season is short, with an average rainfall of at least 100 mm per month, which explains its biodiversity-rich mixed-dipterocarp forests. While there does not appear to be a negative rainfall trend in this region, warming is predicted to result in reduced surface moisture. While the southwest monsoon rainy period (May-July) is gradually becoming longer, the first intermonsoon (March-April) is yielding less rain, delaying the onset of the rains that follow the December-February dry season. These factors combine to increase the risk of forest fires (natural fires are unknown in rainforests).
population: This species is common in suitable habitat (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Since 2005, the localities of Ivsiriya Forest Reserve, Andubagala, Waga, Pelmella (Bulathsingsheh), Thalawakela, and Avissawella in the western portion of the range have experienced possible local extinctions due to habitat degradation and loss from encroaching human settlements, agriculture and small-scale logging which has caused the drying of this species' habitat (P. Samarawickrama, S. Karunarathna, M. Wickremasinghe, N. Perera, D. Gabadage, and S. Gunatilleke pers. comm. February 2020). A decreasing population trend is inferred from ongoing decline in the quality and extent of its habitat.
range: This species is endemic to central, western and southern Sri Lanka where it has an elevational range of 60-1,300 m asl (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 8,722 km<sup>2 </sup>and it likely occurs in at least three but no more than ten threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is presumed to occur in many protected areas, and has been recorded in Kanneliya Forest Reserve. 

Conservation Needed
Continued and strengthened management of protected area(s) where this species occurs, and expanded protection of suitable habitat elsewhere in its range is needed.

Research Needed
There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the threats of agro-chemical pollution, habitat loss and degradation, and the impacts of climate change.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 1,556 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in at least two but no more than five threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: This species inhabits closed-canopy rainforest and cloud forests, and can be found in cardamom plantations within cloud forests. It is usually found close to streams or marshy areas. Adult males are usually perched about one metre above ground, on understorey shrubs (Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda 2005). This species shows a particular microhabitat preference for Freycinetia sp., inside leaf clusters on the plant, with 100% of the specimens recorded from this microhabitat during the survey period (Bopage et al. 2011). Breeding takes place by direct development and it is not dependent upon water. This species is not thought to be tolerant of habitat disturbance (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).
threats:
Threats to this area include small-scale firewood collection, human-induced fires, encroaching human settlements, small-scale hydropower stations, encroaching large- and small-scale agriculture (including tea, cinnamon, rubber, and oil palm plantations), and the resulting pollution from the use of pesticides and chemical fertilizers (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Additionally, forelimb malformations have been observed in this species, possibly attributable to infection or exposure to agrochemicals (de Silva 2011).

Within the Peak Wilderness Nature Reserve, Sripada Peak is a place of worship of all religions in the country of Sri Lanka, with millions of visitors, especially during the six-month-long peak tourism season. During this time, a large amount of garbage collects, light pollution increases, and the forest is exploited (Wickramasinghe et al. 2013). Tea cultivation in the surrounding areas is slowly expanding, and illegal tree felling to cultivate tea has become a major threat in the area. 

In this region the forest is dying back, possibly due to pollution and/or climate change. Prior to 2013, dieback was never documented in this region and now a large area has been affected (Wickramasinghe et al. 2013). 

Climate change also poses a threat to this species. This is the only perhumid region in all of South Asia (the dry season is short, with an average rainfall of at least 100 mm per month), which explains its biodiversity-rich mixed-dipterocarp forests. While there does not appear to be a negative rainfall trend in this region, warming is predicted to result in reduced surface moisture. While the southwest monsoon rainy period (May-July) is gradually becoming longer, the first intermonsoon (March-April) is yielding less rain, delaying the onset of the rains that follow the December-February dry season. The extended dry period has obvious consequences for non-aquatic amphibians such as the direct-developing Pseudophilautus. These factors combine to increase the risk of forest fires (natural fires are unknown in rainforests).
population: This species is uncommon (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Over the course of nine surveys to the Peak Wilderness Nature Reserve, the species was only recorded once. However, another survey produced observations of eight individuals over a two-hour period (<span class="gI">M. Meegaskumbura pers. comm. 2014). A decreasing population trend is inferred from the ongoing decline in the quality and extent of this species' habitat.
range: This species is known from southwestern Sri Lanka where it occurs at elevations ranging between 100-1,270 m asl (K. Manamendra-Arachchi pers. comm. February 2020). There are records from Morningside Forest Reserve, the nearby Handapan Ella Plains, and western Sinharaja near Kudawa (Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda 2005). It has also been observed in the Kanneliya Forest Reserve in the Kanneliya-Dediyagala-Nakiyadeniya complex of southern Sri Lanka (Bopage et al. 2011), as well as from Kottawa Forest Reserve, and Runakanda Forest Reserve, which each represent a separate forest patch in a highly fragmented landscape (K. Manamendra-Arachchi unpub. data February 2020). In addition, this species has also now been recorded from Peak Wilderness Forest Reserve, Aberdeen ginigathhena, and Rassagala (D. Samarasinghe unpub. data February 2020). These locations are geographically distinct and are embedded in a vast deforested matrix; the threat of habitat loss is driven by local factors and differs in intensity among sites. This species might possibly occur between known localities, but is not thought to occur more widely (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 1,556 km2 and its distribution is thought to represent at least two but no more than five threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is found in the Sinharaja World Heritage Site (the largest remnant of Sri Lanka's forests), and forest reserves bordering the eastern margin of the World Heritage Site. Much of the species range is encompassed by the Morningside Forest Reserve.  It is also known from the Kanneliya Forest Reserve (Bopage et al. 2011). 

Conservation Needed
Expansion of effective forest preservation and continued management of existing protected areas is essential for the conservation of this species.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the threats of encroaching agriculture and development, pollution, and the potential impacts of climate change.

rationale: Listed as Vulnerable, as this species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 10,842 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in 10 or fewer threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat. However, population monitoring is key as this species is close to the threshold for EN so further declines may warrant an immediate uplisting.
habitat: This is a canopy species that inhabits lowland and montane tropical moist forest. It has also been found in shaded residential gardens (S. Wijayasekara pers. comm. February 2020). Adults have been observed perched 0.3-2 m above the ground on branches, mossy logs and sometimes on mossy rock surfaces (Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda 2005). Breeding is by direct development. This species is not likely to be tolerant of habitat disturbance as it requires forest cover (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).
threats:
Threats to this species include small-scale firewood collection, human-induced fires, encroaching human settlements, small-scale hydropower stations, encroaching large- and small-scale agriculture (including tea, cinnamon, rubber, and oil palm plantations), and the resulting pollution from the use of pesticides and chemical fertilizers (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Across the Central Hills, various species of invasive plants are encroaching on the natural forest habitat causing habitat loss and degradation (M. Meegaskumbura, N. Wijayathilaka, M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. February 2020). Within Morningside, it is threatened by the loss of forest canopy for expansion of cardamom and tea plantations at the expense of cloud forest habitat, clearing of undergrowth, small-scale collection of firewood, and encroaching human settlements. Changing agricultural practices within cardamom plantations could also negatively affect this species, particularly if the change involves the use of agro-chemicals. Small-scale potato cultivation and the resulting pollution from pesticide use also presents a threat to this species (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Lowland species (e.g. P. rus and hallidayi encroaching into highland habitats within the Morningside reserve may also constitute a threat to this species as it is displacing and out competing other species (M. Meegaskumbura pers. comm. February 2020). Additionally, invasive plant species (e.g. Acacia sp.) are actively being planted in the region, which is resulting in forest clearing (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). 

Climate change also poses a threat to this species. In the central highlands, annual rainfall is declining steeply across this region, especially on the perhumid western slopes. This area is becoming markedly drier and more seasonal. From an annual average rainfall of about 2,500 mm of rain a century ago, the highlands now receive around 1,900 mm, and years with less than 1,500 are increasingly common (De Silva and Sonnadara 2016). This reduction in rainfall occurs largely during the first intermonsoon in March-April, extending the duration of the usual December-February dry period. There has been a decline in rainfall of about 4 mm per year during the first intermonsoon and southwest monsoon over the past century, with a lesser decrease of 0.5 mm per year during the northeast monsoon. Additionally, the percentage of wet days during the southwest monsoon has decreased from 59% to 47% over the past century (Thavakaran et al. 2019). Added to changes in the spatial and temporal distribution of rainfall is the fact that the climate is also warming, with average annual temperatures rise of about 0.8° C across the country over the past century, and temperature in the highlands rise by about 1.1° C (De Costa 2008). The preponderance of amphibian species in the highlands are Pseudophilautus shrub frogs which, being direct developers, are independent of bodies of standing water. Instead, they depend on the ambient moisture of the forest for both homeostasis and reproduction. Highland aridification and warming therefore, are serious—if as yet unassessed—potential threats to these species. In the southwestern lowland portions of this species’ range, there does not appear to be a negative rainfall trend. However, warming is predicted to result in reduced surface moisture. While the southwest monsoon rainy period (May-July) is gradually becoming longer, the first intermonsoon (March-April) is yielding less rain, delaying the onset of the rains that follow the December-February dry season. The extended dry period has obvious consequences for non-aquatic amphibians such as the direct-developing Pseudophilautus. In both regions, the combination of warming and extended dry periods increase the risk of forest fires (natural fires are unknown in rainforests).
population:
This species is uncommon across its range. However, in a few known localities it is known to be common (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).
Over the last 25 years, a 20-30% population decline has been documented (M. Wickramasinghe pers. comm. February 2020).
range: This species is known from isolated subpopulations in the southwestern region of Sri Lanka where it has been recorded at elevations of 30-1,100 m asl. Specific records come from Haycock, Weddagala, Kitugala, Kosmulla, Pathanegala, Kadugannawa and Pussellawa. It has also been recorded in Ambagamuwa, Kithulgala (Pradeep Kumara and Ukuwela 2009), Hiyare, Kottawa, Deniyagala, as well as Hattota-amane (Samarawickrama et al. 2012), Sinharaja (D. Gabadage unpub. data February 2020), Norton Bridge, Morningside, Gannoruwa, Gilimale, Aberdeen Falls (S. Wijayasekara unpub. data February 2020), Maskeliya, Nawalapitiya, Waleboda, Ginigathhena (D. Kandambi unpub. data February 2020), Kanneliya (V. Pushpamal unpub. data February 2020), and Wattegama (D. Samarasinghe unpub. data February 2020). This species is likely restricted to its known range (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 10,842 km2 and the distribution is thought to contain fewer than ten threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place 
This species has been recorded in several protected areas, including Kanneliya Forest Reserve, Haycock Forest Reserve, Gilimale-Eratne Forest Reserve and Knuckles Forest Reserve.

Conservation Needed
Continued and strengthened management of protected area(s) where this species occurs, and expanded protection of cloud forest elsewhere in its range is needed.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the threats of agro-chemical pollution, encroaching agriculture and urbanization, and the potential impacts of climate change.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 4,674 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in at least two but fewer than five threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: This species is found in leaf-litter on the forest floor in damp shaded closed-canopy rainforest habitats. At night, males perch and vocalize from branches and leaves around 0.3 m above ground (Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda 2005). It is a direct developer and is not dependent on water. This species is not thought to be tolerant of habitat disturbance (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).
threats:
Threats in this area include small-scale firewood collection, human-induced fires, encroaching human settlements, small-scale hydropower stations, encroaching large- and small-scale agriculture (including tea, cinnamon, rubber, and oil palm plantations), and the resulting pollution from the use of pesticides and chemical fertilizers (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). 

Climate change also poses a threat to this species. This is the only perhumid region in all of South Asia, where the dry season is short, with an average rainfall of at least 100 mm per month, which explains its biodiversity-rich mixed-dipterocarp forests. While there does not appear to be a negative rainfall trend in this region, warming is predicted to result in reduced surface moisture. While the southwest monsoon rainy period (May-July) is gradually becoming longer, the first intermonsoon (March-April) is yielding less rain, delaying the onset of the rains that follow the December-February dry season. The extended dry period has obvious consequences for non-aquatic amphibians such as the direct-developing Pseudophilautus. These factors combine to increase the risk of forest fires (natural fires are unknown in rainforests).
population: This species is common in suitable habitat (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). A decreasing population trend is inferred from ongoing decline in the quality and extent of its habitat.
range: This species was previously known only from the general Sinharaja region of southwestern Sri Lanka, but is now also known from the Dombagaskanda region within the Ingiriya Forest Reserve (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Within the Sinharaja region there are records from Sinharaja, Morawaka and Deniyaya (Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda 2005). This species is thought to occur between known localities, but is not likely to occur much more widely (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). It occurs at elevations ranging between 150-1,060 m asl, its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 4,674 km<sup>2</sup>, and it is thought to occur in at least two but no more than five threat-defined locations due to different intensities of habitat loss.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is found in the Sinharaja World Heritage Site, the largest remnant of Sri Lanka's forests, and Ingiriya Forest Reserve.

Conservation Needed
Continued and strengthened management of protected area(s) where this species occurs, and expanded protection of suitable habitat elsewhere in its range is needed.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the threats of encroaching agriculture and human activity, pollution, and the potential impacts of climate change.

rationale: Listed as Vulnerable, as this species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 11,663 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in 10 or fewer threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: This species occurs in shaded places including rainforests and anthropogenic habitats such as home gardens. It is usually observed 0.3-2 m above ground, perched on branches or leaves. Calling males are sometimes found concealed in dried, curled leaves, although in Gilimale males were always observed vocalizing while on leaves (Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda 2005). Breeding is by direct development. This species is not likely to tolerate habitat disturbance as it requires forest cover (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).
threats: Threats to this area include small-scale firewood collection, human-induced fires, encroaching human settlements, small-scale hydropower stations, encroaching large- and small-scale agriculture (including tea, cinnamon, rubber, and oil palm plantations), and the resulting pollution from the use of pesticides and chemical fertilizers (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Within the Peak Wilderness Nature Reserve, Sripada Peak is a place of worship of all religions in the country of Sri Lanka, with millions of visitors, especially during the six-month-long peak tourism season, during which a large amount of garbage collects, light pollution increases, and the forest is exploited (Wickramasinghe et al. 2013). Tea cultivation in the surrounding areas is slowly expanding, and illegal tree felling to cultivate tea has become a major threat in the area. In this region the forest is dying back, possibly due to pollution and/or climate change. Prior to 2013, dieback was never documented in this region and now a large area has been affected (Wickramasinghe et al. 2013). Within Morningside, it is threatened by the loss of forest canopy for expansion of cardamom and tea plantations at the expense of cloud forest habitat, clearing of undergrowth, small-scale collection of firewood, and encroaching human settlements. Changing agricultural practices within cardamom plantations could also negatively affect this species, particularly if the change involves the use of agro-chemicals. Small-scale potato cultivation and the resulting pollution from pesticide use also presents a threat to this species (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Lowland species (e.g. P. rus and hallidayi encroaching into highland habitats within the Morningside reserve may also constitute a threat to this species as it is displacing and out competing other species (M. Meegaskumbura pers. comm. February 2020). Additionally, invasive plant species (e.g. Acacia sp.) are actively being planted in the region, which is resulting in forest clearing (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Climate change also poses a threat to this species. This is the only perhumid region in all of South Asia (the dry season is short, with an average rainfall of at least 100 mm per month), which explains its biodiversity-rich mixed-dipterocarp forests. While there does not appear to be a negative rainfall trend in this region, warming is predicted to result in reduced surface moisture. While the southwest monsoon rainy period (May-July) is gradually becoming longer, the first intermonsoon (March-April) is yielding less rain, delaying the onset of the rains that follow the December-February dry season. The extended dry period has obvious consequences for non-aquatic amphibians such as the direct-developing Pseudophilautus. These factors combine to increase the risk of forest fires (natural fires are unknown in rainforests).
population: This species is common (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).
range: This species is endemic to the southwestern lowlands of Sri Lanka, and is found at elevations from 60-1,000 m asl. It has been recorded from Kottawa, Haycock, Gilimale and Induruwa (Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda 2005). This species is restricted to its known range (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 11,663 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs in several reserves, including Peak Wilderness Nature Reserve, Gilimale Nature Reserve, Kanneliya Forest Reserve, Kottawa Forest Reserve and Haycock Hill Forest Reserve.

Conservation Needed
Continued and strengthened management of protected area(s) where this species occurs, and expanded protection of suitable habitat elsewhere in its range is needed.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the threats of conversion of habitat for plantation agriculture, and agro-chemical pollution.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 3,907 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in five or fewer threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: This species inhabits closed-canopy forest. It presumably breeds by direct development and is not dependent on water. This species is not likely to tolerate habitat disturbance as it requires forest cover (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).
threats:
Threats to this species include small-scale firewood collection, human-induced fires, encroaching human settlements, small-scale hydropower stations, encroaching large- and small-scale agriculture (including tea, cinnamon, rubber, and oil palm plantations), and the resulting pollution from the use of pesticides and chemical fertilizers (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Within the Peak Wilderness Nature Reserve, tea cultivation in the surrounding areas is slowly expanding, and illegal tree felling to cultivate tea has become a major threat in the area. In this region the forest is dying back, possibly due to pollution and/or climate change. Prior to 2013, dieback was never documented in this region and now a large area has been affected (Wickramasinghe et al. 2013). 

Climate change also poses a potential threat to this species. This is the only perhumid region in all of South Asia where the dry season is short, with an average rainfall of at least 100 mm per month, which explains its biodiversity-rich mixed-dipterocarp forests. While there does not appear to be a negative rainfall trend in this region, warming is predicted to result in reduced surface moisture. While the southwest monsoon rainy period (May-July) is gradually becoming longer, the first intermonsoon (March-April) is yielding less rain, delaying the onset of the rains that follow the December-February dry season. The extended dry period has obvious consequences for non-aquatic amphibians such as the direct-developing Pseudophilautus. These factors combine to increase the risk of forest fires (natural fires are unknown in rainforests).
population: This species is thought to be uncommon (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). A decreasing population trend is inferred from the ongoing decline in the quality and extent of this species' habitat.
range: This species was previously known only from the type locality in Haycock Hill (Hiniduma) Forest Reserve in southwestern Sri Lanka, where it was recorded at 660 m asl (Manamendra-Arachchi and Pethiyagoda 2005). In 2011, a record was published from the southern lowland portion of Kanneliya Forest Reserve (Bopage et al. 2011). It has now also been recorded from Peak Wilderness Nature Reserve (S. Wijayasekara unpub. data February 2020), Aberdeen falls, Rambukpitiya village in Nawalapitiya, Rassagala village in Balangoda, Dothaloya village in Aranayaka and Norton Bridge (D. Kandambi unpub. data February 2020), and Dediyagala (S. Udugampala unpub. data February 2020). It occurs at elevations ranging between 61-660 m asl. This species is thought to be restricted to known localities (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020) and the extent of occurrence (EOO) of the currently mapped distribution is 3,907 km2. It is thought to occur in five or fewer threat-defined locations due to differing intensities of encroaching agriculture and urbanization.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs in several reserves including Peak Wilderness Nature Reserve, Haycock Hill-Hiniduma Forest Reserve and Kanneliya Forest Reserve.

Conservation Needed
Continued and strengthened management of protected area(s) where this species occurs, and expanded protection of suitable habitat elsewhere in its range is needed. 

Research needed
Further survey work is needed to establish the limits of the species' range. There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the threats of agro-chemical pollution, habitat loss and degradation, and the potential impacts of climate change.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 3,497 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in at least three but no more than five threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: This arboreal species inhabits lowland, submontane and montane tropical moist forests. Adults can be found on moss, bushes and tree trunks up to 2 m above the ground. It is rarely found outside primary forest. It can be found close to stagnant water, and breeding takes place in rocky pools in streams. This species is not thought to tolerate habitat disturbance (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).
threats:
Threats to this area include small-scale firewood collection, human-induced fires, encroaching human settlements, small-scale hydropower stations, encroaching large- and small-scale agriculture (including tea, cinnamon, rubber, and oil palm plantations), and the resulting pollution from the use of pesticides and chemical fertilizers (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). 

Climate change also poses a threat to this species. This is the only perhumid region in all of South Asia, where the dry season is short, with an average rainfall of at least 100 mm per month, which explains its biodiversity-rich mixed-dipterocarp forests. While there does not appear to be a negative rainfall trend in this region, warming is predicted to result in reduced surface moisture. While the southwest monsoon rainy period (May-July) is gradually becoming longer, the first intermonsoon (March-April) is yielding less rain, delaying the onset of the rains that follow the December-February dry season. These factors combine to increase the risk of forest fires (natural fires are unknown in rainforests).
population: This species is considered uncommon (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). A decreasing population trend is inferred from the ongoing decline in the quality and extent of its habitat.
range: This species is endemic to central and southwestern Sri Lanka, where it has been recorded at elevations between 60-900 m asl (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Records from the central hills near Pidurutalagala that were previously mapped for this species are believed to have been in error, and have been removed (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). This species is thought to occur between known localities, but is not likely to occur more widely (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 3,497 km<sup>2</sup>, which is thought to represent at least three but no more than five threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species has been recorded from the Sinharaja World Heritage Site, the largest remnant of Sri Lanka's forests, which was inscribed in 1988. It has also been recorded from Kanneliya Forest Reserve (Bopage et al. 2011), Peak Wilderness Sanctuary, Yagirala Forest Reserve, Kiriamunadeniya Forest Reserve, Panvila Forest Reserve, and the K-D-N complex (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).

Conservation Needed
Continued and strengthened management of protected area(s) where this species occurs, and expanded protection of suitable habitat elsewhere in its range is needed. 

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the threats of habitat loss and degradation due to subsistence wood extraction, conversion to tea and cardamom plantations, and agrochemical pollution of land and water.

rationale: Listed as Vulnerable, as this species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 10,395 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in 10 or fewer threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat:
This subterranean species inhabits evergreen forests, paddy fields, rubber plantations, rural gardens and farms, wetlands (boggy areas), and cattle pastureland. Adults are often found under moist decaying leaf litter, in humus, dung and rotting vegetation. This species reproduces by larval development; the eggs are laid on land and the larvae live in flowing water. 

This species has been recorded in tea plantations (De Silva 2009) and other agricultural habitats that retain high enough levels of vegetation and moisture. However, it is not thought to be tolerant of more extreme changes that result in much lower soil moisture levels, consistently alter soil chemistry, and have have the potential to result in fragmentation (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).
threats: The species is known from both intact habitats and agricultural landscapes. Elevated levels of human activity may actually be causing a high enough level of disturbance such that it constitutes a cause for concern. Therefore, localized threats are considered to be extreme habitat loss and degradation. In particular, the heavy use of pesticides and other agrochemicals can cause chemical leaching into the soil. In addition, since 2005, construction of large-scale dams, large-scale hydropower stations (Kalugaga and Moragahakanda, established in 2019), several small-scale hydropower stations, as well as water extraction for agricultural purposes in some localities, all pose a threat to this species as these activities cause desiccation of larval habitats (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Additional threats include roads, road construction, and the accompanying concrete barriers and drains within the species' range (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Climate change also poses a threat to the species due to changes in the spatial and temporal patterns of rainfall, which results in the soil drying (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Sand mining and subsequent erosion is a threat throughout its range (M. Wickremasinghe pers. comm. February 2020).
population: This species can be locally abundant in some localities, while at others it is found in low numbers (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). A decreasing population trend is inferred from the ongoing decline in the quality and extent of the habitat.
range: This species is endemic to central and southwestern Sri Lanka where it has been recorded at elevations ranging from 20-1,500 m asl, but is not found above 1,500 m asl (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). A record from northeastern India has been disputed, and is highly improbable and therefore not included on the map. This species is the most widely distributed caecilian in the country (De Silva 2009). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 10,395 km<sup>2</sup> and it is thought to occur in ten or fewer threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species has been recorded from the well-protected areas of Sinharaja World Heritage Site, Dellawa Forest Reserve, Knuckles Range Forest Reserve, and the Udawattakele Forest Reserve.

Conservation Needed
Continued and strengthened management of protected area(s) where this species occurs, and expanded protection of suitable habitat elsewhere in its range, is needed in view of the varying degrees of habitat loss and degradation faced by this species.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the threats of habitat loss, agrochemical pollution, and the potential impacts of climate change.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 1,223 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in five or fewer threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat:
This subterranean species inhabits evergreen forests, rubber plantations, tea plantations, paddy fields, rural gardens and farms, wetlands (boggy areas), and cattle pastureland. The adults are often found in humus. It is assumed to be oviparous with terrestrial eggs and aquatic larvae.

This species has been recorded in agricultural habitats that retain high enough levels of vegetation and moisture. However, it is not thought to be tolerant of more extreme changes that result in much lower soil moisture levels, consistently alter soil chemistry, and have have the potential to result in fragmentation (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Furthermore, it appears to be less adaptable than Ichthyophis glutinosus.
threats:
The species is known from both intact habitats and agricultural landscapes. Elevated levels of human activity may actually be causing a high enough level of disturbance such that it constitutes a cause for concern. Therefore, localized threats are considered to be extreme habitat loss due to agroindustry and clear cutting, as well as heavy use of pesticides and other agrochemicals due to chemical leaching into the soil. In addition, since 2005, construction of large-scale dams, large-scale hydropower stations (Kalugaga and Moragahakanda, established in 2019), several small-scale hydropower stations, as well as water extraction for agricultural purposes in some localities, all pose a threat to this species as these activities cause desiccation of larval habitats (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Additional threats include roads, road construction, and the accompanying concrete barriers and drains within the species' range (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Sand mining and subsequent erosion is a threat throughout its range (M. Wickremasinghe pers. comm. February 2020), as is land filling for domestic waste. 

Climate change also poses a threat to the species due to changes in the spatial and temporal patterns of rainfall, which results in the soil drying (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).

Forest dieback could be an additional threat to this species. It was first observed in Sri Lanka’s montane ‘cloud’ forests by Perera (1978). Despite several studies (see Ranasinghe and Dissanayake 2003, Ranasinghe et al. 2007, Chandrajith et al. 2009), the aetiology of dieback remains enigmatic, though there has been concern that an environmental stressor that kills extensive stands of woody vegetation, apart from the loss of suitable habitats for amphibians, may also directly threaten amphibians. Gunawardena et al. (1998) and Jayalal et al. (2017) suggest that high acidity in mist- and rain-water may present a significant risk to the highland biota in Sri Lanka. While there is no direct evidence to date (see Silva et al. 2019) that amphibians are negatively affected; it is thought to be a threat for species that inhabit areas where mist persists for long periods, and for species found in open habitats with aquatic life history stages in shallow lentic habitats (M. Meegaskumbura pers. comm. February 2020).
population: This species is uncommon and was last recorded from within the Pattipola Reserve in 1986, despite five general amphibian surveys to the area, and many general amphibian surveys conducted throughout the rest of its known range which failed to record the species (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). The most recent record is from Haldummulla in 2004 (S. Karunarathna unpub. data 2020). A decreasing population trend is inferred from the ongoing decline in the quality and extent of the habitat.
range: This species is endemic to the mountains of south central Sri Lanka. It has been recorded at elevations between 460-1,890 m asl and is likely restricted to its currently known range (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 1,223 km<sup>2 </sup>and, given the possibility of local extinctions and the ongoing threat of clear-cutting within its small range, this species is likely restricted to fewer than five threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There is no information on the use or trade of this species.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species has been recorded from Pattipola Forest Reserve and Namunakula Forest Reserve (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).

Conservation Needed
Expansion of effective forest preservation and continued management of existing protected areas is essential for the conservation of this species.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the threats of habitat loss and pollution throughout its range. Additionally, it is necessary to investigate about this species complex in order to elucidate the taxonomic identity of its members.

rationale: Listed as Vulnerable, as this species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 8,820 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in 10 or fewer threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat:
This subterranean species is present in forests, rubber plantation areas, paddy fields, rural gardens and farms, wetlands (boggy and muddy areas), and pastureland. Adults are often found in humus and other rotting vegetation. It is oviparous with terrestrial eggs and aquatic larvae in streams. 

This species has been recorded in agricultural habitats that retain high enough levels of vegetation and moisture. However, it is not thought to be tolerant of more extreme changes that result in much lower soil moisture levels, consistently alter soil chemistry, and have have the potential to result in fragmentation (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).
threats: The species is known from both intact habitats and agricultural landscapes. Elevated levels of human activity may actually be causing a high enough level of disturbance such that it constitutes a cause for concern. Therefore, localized threats are considered to be extreme habitat loss due to large-scale agriculture, as well as heavy use of pesticides and other agrochemicals due to chemical leaching into the soil. Since 2005, construction of large-scale dams, large-scale hydropower stations (Kalugaga and Moragahakanda, established in 2019), several small-scale hydropower stations, as well as water extraction for agricultural purposes in some localities, pose a threat to this species as these activities cause desiccation of larval habitats (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Additional threats include roads, road construction, and the accompanying concrete barriers and drains within the species' range (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Climate change also poses a threat to the species due to changes in the spatial and temporal patterns of rainfall, which results in the soil drying (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Sand mining and subsequent erosion is a threat throughout its range (M. Wickremasinghe pers. comm. February 2020).
population: This species appears to be less common than Ichthyophis glutinosus, however it is not known from many specimens (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). A decreasing population trend is inferred from the ongoing decline in the quality and extent of the habitat.
range: This species is found throughout southwestern Sri Lanka. It has been recorded at elevations between 20-1,525 m asl (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). It is not likely to occur more widely than the currently known localities (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020), which are thought to represent 10 or fewer threat-defined locations, due to expanding agriculture and hydropower. The extent of occurrence (EOO) of its distribution is 8,820 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species has been recorded from several protected areas, including Peak Wilderness Forest Reserve and Sinharaja Forest Reserve, which is a World Heritage Site.

Conservation Needed
Expansion of effective forest preservation and continued management of existing protected areas is essential for the conservation of this species.

Research Needed
Further research is required to fully resolve the taxonomic status of the species. More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the threats of extreme habitat loss due to large-scale agriculture and the resulting agro-chemical pollution.

rationale: Listed as Vulnerable, as this species has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 5,504 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in 10 or fewer threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: This species inhabits the shrub understory of closed-canopy lowland rainforest. It is not believed to be tolerant of habitat degradation. Males are seen calling at night in chorus from leaves up to 1 m above the ground (Meegaskumbura and Manamendra-Arachchi 2005). It presumably breeds by direct development, as with congeners.
threats:
Threats to this species include small-scale firewood collection, human-induced fires, encroaching human settlements, small-scale hydropower stations, encroaching large- and small-scale agriculture (including tea, cinnamon, rubber, and oil palm plantations), and the resulting pollution from the use of pesticides and chemical fertilizers (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).
