Climate change also poses a potential threat to this species, as its range includes the only perhumid region in all of South Asia (the dry season is short, with an average rainfall of at least 100 mm per month), which explains its biodiversity-rich mixed-dipterocarp forests. While there does not appear to be a negative rainfall trend in this region, warming is predicted to result in reduced surface moisture. While the southwest monsoon rainy period (May-July) is gradually becoming longer, the first intermonsoon (March-April) is yielding less rain, delaying the onset of the rains that follow the December-February dry season. The extended dry period has obvious consequences for non-aquatic amphibians such as the direct-developing Pseudophilautus. These factors combine to increase the risk of forest fires (natural fires are unknown in rainforests).
population: This species is considered to be rare (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). A decreasing population trend is inferred from the ongoing decline in the quality and extent of this species' habitat.
range: This lowland endemic is known from the southwest quarter of Sri Lanka where it occurs at elevations ranging between 60-900 m asl (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). The species is thought to be restricted to its mapped range (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020), which has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 5,504 km<sup>2</sup>. The distribution is thought to represent ten or fewer threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs in several forest reserves, including the Kottawa Forest Reserve and the Beraliya Forest Reserve. 

Conservation Needed
Continued and strengthened management of protected area(s) where this species occurs, and expanded protection of suitable habitat elsewhere in its range is needed.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the threats of habitat conversion, agro-chemical pollution, and the potential impacts of climate change.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 3,697 km2, it occurs in at least two but no more than five threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: This forest-dependent species occurs in lowland and mid-elevation rainforests, is restricted to primary and secondary forests with extensive canopy cover (Meegaskumbura et al. 2009), and therefore has a low tolerance threshold towards habitat disturbance (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Individuals can be found perching on leaves of shrubs that they climb at night to vocalize (Meegaskumbura et al. 2009). Males have been observed 0.5-1.5 m above ground level (Meegaskumbura et al. 2009). This species breeds by direct development. Eggs are laid in a depression in the soil and the female covers it up later (M. Meegaskumbura pers. comm. October 2010).
threats:
Threats to this area include small-scale firewood collection, human-induced fires, encroaching human settlements, small-scale hydropower stations, encroaching large- and small-scale agriculture (including tea, cinnamon, rubber, and oil palm plantations), and the resulting pollution from the use of pesticides and chemical fertilizers (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Within the Peak Wilderness Nature Reserve, Sripada Peak is a place of worship of all religions in the country of Sri Lanka, with millions of visitors, especially during the six-month-long peak tourism season. During this time, a large amount of garbage collects, light pollution increases, and the forest is exploited (Wickramasinghe et al. 2013).

Forest dieback could be an additional threat to this species. Prior to 2013, dieback was never documented in Peak Wilderness and now a large area has been affected, but the cause is still unknown (Wickramasinghe et al. 2013).

Climate change also poses a threat through potential changes in precipitation patterns. This is the only perhumid region in all of South Asia, where the dry season is short, with an average rainfall of at least 100 mm per month, which explains its biodiversity-rich mixed-dipterocarp forests. While there does not appear to be a negative rainfall trend in this region, warming is predicted to result in reduced surface moisture. While the southwest monsoon rainy period (May-July) is gradually becoming longer, the first intermonsoon (March-April) is yielding less rain, delaying the onset of the rains that follow the December-February dry season. The extended dry period has obvious consequences for non-aquatic amphibians such as the direct-developing Pseudophilautus. These factors combine to increase the risk of forest fires (natural fires are unknown in rainforests).
population: Although the species' distribution within canopy-covered forest is not uniform, it is considered to be common where it is found (M. Meegaskumbura pers. comm. October 2010, Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Forest fragmentation is limiting its dispersal ability and the population is therefore considered to be severely fragmented (M. Meegaskumbura pers. comm. November 2010). A decreasing population trend is inferred from the ongoing decline in the quality and extent of its habitat.
range: This species is endemic to Sri Lanka and is currently known from Kanneliya-Dediyagala-Nakiyadeniya (KDN Complex), Kitulgala, Kottawa Forest Reserve, and the Sinharaja World Heritage Site (Meegaskumbura et al. 2009, M. Meegaskumbura pers. comm. November 2010), Peak Wilderness Nature Reserve, Gilimale, Aberdeen falls (S. Wijayasekara unpub. data February 2020), and Balanthota village in Ginigathhena (D. Kandambi unpub. data February 2020). This species is thought to occur between known localities, but is not likely to occur more widely (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). Its elevational range is 60-700 m asl (Meegaskumbura et al. 2009, Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020), its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 3,697 km2, and it is thought to occur in at least three but no more than five threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no reports of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs within the Peak Wilderness Nature Reserve and the Kottawa, Kitulgala, Sinharaja and Kanneliya-Dediyagala-Nakiyadeniya Forest Reserves. 

Conservation Needed
Continued and strengthened management of protected area(s) where this species occurs, and expanded protection of suitable habitat elsewhere in its range is needed.

Research Needed 
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the threats of human activities such as encroaching agriculture and pollution, as well as the potential impacts of climate change.

rationale: Listed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 2,798 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in at least two but no more than five threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: This species occurs in lowland rainforest. Individuals have commonly been observed near the forest edge with open canopy, and are found in greater abundance in these areas than in closed canopy forest (Wickramasinghe et al. 2012). Observations of breeding behavior indicate that this species does not have a free-living larval stage, however it is unclear if they are foam nesters or a direct developing species (Wickramasinghe et al. 2012). Further studies need to clarify the breeding biology of this species (Wickramasinghe et al. 2012). This species is thought to tolerate a small amount of habitat disturbance, however it requires pristine breeding habitats and some forest cover (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February).
threats:
Threats to this species include small-scale firewood collection, human-induced fires, encroaching human settlements, small-scale hydropower stations, encroaching large- and small-scale agriculture (including tea, cinnamon, rubber, and oil palm plantations), and the resulting pollution from the use of pesticides and chemical fertilizers (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). 

In parts of this species range, specifically along the Induru River, one of the main branches of the Kalu River that flows through the Gilimale Forest Reserve, forest fragmentation has become the major threat in this area due to the fast rate of deforestation. The Induruwa Mukalana and Guruluwana regions became separated due to deforestation between 2002 and 2012 and are now two separate islands. Many isolated forest patches that existed in the area disappeared between 2007 and 2012, having been cleared and converted to human settlements. By 2012, the gravel road which consisted of water holes during the monsoonal rains had been concreted about half the road's length (750 m of the total 1,500 m). This has led to more visitors and more vehicles entering the forest reserve, which also resulted in large quantities of garbage being discarded in the forest, and the remaining temporary water holes drying out quickly when vehicles are driven through them. Forest patches also are being cleared and converted to small tea plantations. Apart from logging, hazardous activities such as gem mining, sand mining, use of agro-chemicals, cutting and burning the forest edge, drying out of water bodies, and soil erosion are also threats.

Climate change also poses an additional threat to this species, as its range includes the only perhumid region in all of South Asia where the dry season is short, with an average rainfall of at least 100 mm per month, which explains the regions biodiversity-rich mixed-dipterocarp forests. While there does not appear to be a negative rainfall trend in this region, warming is predicted to result in reduced surface moisture. While the southwest monsoon rainy period (May-July) is gradually becoming longer, the first intermonsoon (March-April) is yielding less rain, delaying the onset of the rains that follow the December-February dry season. The extended dry period has obvious consequences for non-aquatic amphibians such as the direct-developing species. These factors combine to increase the risk of forest fires (natural fires are unknown in rainforests).
population: This species is rare (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020). A decreasing population trend is inferred from the ongoing decline in the quality and extent of this species' habitat.
range: This species was previously known only from the type locality in Gilimale Forest, Ratnapura, Sabaragamuwa Province, Sri Lanka. Additional records from Dolukanda (S. Wijayasekara and D. Samarasinghe unpub. data February 2020) and from Baduraliya in Mathugama (D. Kandambi unpub. data February 2020) have now been found. The subpopulation at Dolukanda is isolated, as surveys to the surrounding areas have not recorded the species to date (S. Wijayasekara pers. comm. February 2020), but it is likely to occur more widely than currently mapped (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).  It is known from around 150 m asl (Wickramasinghe et al. 2012, Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020), its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 2,798 km2, and it is thought to occur in at least two but no more than five threat-defined locations.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is known from the Gilimale Forest Reserve and Dolukanda Conservation Forest (Sri Lanka Red List Assessment Workshop February 2020).

Conservation Needed
Continued and strengthened management of protected area(s) where this species occurs, and expanded protection of suitable habitat elsewhere in its range is needed.

Research Needed
More information is needed on this species' distribution, population status, ecology, and threats. There is a need for monitoring the population status of this species given the threats of encroaching agriculture and urbanization, mining, hydropower, pollution, and the potential impacts of climate change. Additionally, there is currently no DNA data available for this species. Further DNA analysis should be prioritized in order to confirm its taxonomic status.

rationale: This species has a relatively wide range in the upper Syr Darya River and can be found in many different populations, although these can be small and isolated. There is probably a declining population trend due to the impacts of urbanisation, industrialisation and associated water use, but this decline is not thought to be at a high enough rate to qualify for a threatened category, and there are probably stable populations in mountainous areas of its range. This species is therefore assessed as Least Concern.
habitat: This species occurs in the headwaters of the Syr Darya in cold water (below 17°C) in rocky streams. It is benthivorous with a maximum body mass  recorded at 15.7 g. It spawns on gravel and males protect the offspring (Chelpakova et al. 2011).
threats: This species is threatened from water pollution, stream modification, dams, agriculture, mining, water abstraction, climate change and invasive species (Karimov 2015, Karimov et al. 2017, Karimov et al. 2019). In southwestern Kazakhstan, this species seems to be strongly impacted by industrialisation in the south-east of the city of Schymkent.
population: This species is found in many, often small and isolation populations. While some populations in the mountainous areas of its range are thought to be stable, it is probably experiencing an overall decline due to urbanisation, industrialisation and associated water use. In southwestern Kazakhstan it is strongly impacted by industrialisation in the south-east of the city of Schymkent.
range: Cottus spinulosus is a regional endemic found in the upper Syr Darya River drainage in Fergana Valley, where it is mostly found in springs, as well as in the Arys, Badam and Talas rivers (Vanina and Stejskal 2017, Mamilov et al. 2017) with total length of about 1,000 km. It has an extent of occurrence (EOO) of much more than 100,000 km2 but it is found in many, often small and isolated populations within its range. It occurs in many more than 10 populations.
useTrade: This species is not used or traded.
conservationActions: The species is included in Uzbek Red Data Books. Research is needed into its population, distribution, ecology and threats, alongside monitoring of habitat trends, habitat protection and restoration, and invasive species control where threats exist.

rationale: This species has an extremely large range, and hence does not approach the thresholds for Vulnerable under the range size criterion (extent of occurrence <20,000 km<sup>2</sup> combined with a declining or fluctuating range size, habitat extent/quality, or population size and a small number of locations or severe fragmentation). Despite local declines, the global population trend appears to be increasing, and hence the species does not approach the thresholds for Vulnerable under the population trend criterion (>30% decline over 10 years or three generations). The population size is very large, and hence does not approach the thresholds for Vulnerable under the population size criterion (<10,000 mature individuals with a continuing decline estimated to be >10% in 10 years or three generations, or with a specified population structure). For these reasons the species is evaluated as Least Concern.
habitat: Behaviour Some birds are migratory, overwintering in Africa, although many others are resident or nomadic (del Hoyo et al. 1994). It relies heavily on soaring flight, and has been shown to fly at altitudes of 10,000 m and higher. Birds hunt alone but congregate at food sources and roosts; they also tend to migrate singly, but concentrations (usually up to 15 individuals) form at sea crossings and strong thermals (del Hoyo et al. 1994; Ferguson-Lees and Christie 2001). Habitat It is a species of expansive open areas in a wide array of environments, from mountains to semi-desert, and is recorded regularly from sea level up to c.3,000 m (del Hoyo et al. 1994). Diet It feeds almost exclusively on carrion, mainly that of large mammals (del Hoyo et al. 1994). Breeding site The nest is usually built on a rocky outcrop, with sheltered ledges or small caves preferred (del Hoyo et al. 1994). Management information Effective protection in areas with a plentiful supply of food (which often includes the carrion of domestic animals), has been shown to catalyse impressive population recoveries, and reintroduction has been successful in parts of its range (del Hoyo et al. 1994).
threats:
It declined markedly throughout the 19th–20th centuries in much of Europe, North Africa and the Middle East, mainly due to direct persecution and "bycatch" from the poisoned carcasses set for livestock predators (Snow and Perrins 1998, Ferguson-Lees and Christie 2001, Orta et al. 2015). Direct persecution has decreased, although it may still be a threat in eastern Europe, Central Asia and possibly the Middle East (Botha et al. 2017). Unintentional poisoning through poison bates remains the most significant threat to the species (Botha et al. 2017) - during 2000-2010 2,146 Griffon Vultures were found poisoned in Spain (RSPB 2014). In some areas a reduction in available food supplies, arising from changes in livestock management practices, also had an impact (Ferguson-Lees and Christie 2001, Orta et al. 2015). It is very highly vulnerable to the effects of potential wind energy development (Strix 2012) and electrocution has been identified as a threat (Global Raptors Information Network 2015). Disturbance caused by visitors may also pose a threat in some areas (Choresh et al. 2019). Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) used for veterinary purposes pose a threat to this species. One case of suspected poisoning caused by flunixin, an NSAID, was recorded in this species in 2012 in Spain (Zorrilla et al. 2015), and several more have occurred since (Herrero-Villar et al. 2020). Diclofenac, a similar NSAID which has caused severe declines in Gyps vulture species across Asia, was authorised for veterinary use in Spain in 2013. Diclofenac was detected in livestock carcasses in the Iberian Peninsula between 2013 and 2019 (Herrero-Villar et al. 2020), and in 2021 the first case of a vulture death in Europe due to ingestion of Diclofenac was confirmed (Herrero-Villar et al. 2021). 

There were widespread declines in the population of Griffon vultures throughout Portugal and the Iberian Peninsula during the 20th century (Carneiro et al. 2015). This is a result of the species ingesting toxins from the carcasses they feed on, which accumulate in their system and increase mortality rates. Most of the carcasses the species feeds on are high in toxins as they came through livestock management or hunting practises; lead bullet fragments are often ingested leading to a build-up of toxic levels of lead within the species. This was worsened in 2001 when the EU legislated against the disposal of livestock carcasses in the field to curb the spread of bovine spongiform encephalopathy, or mad cow disease. This lowered food availability and forced some vultures to seek out food in areas including garbage dumps, where they risk ingesting further heavy metals. In an analysis of 121 wild vultures sampled on the Iberian Peninsula, every individual had lead present in its blood, ranging in concentration from 4.97 to 300.23 μg/dl. The declines are further worsened by the intentional, and illegal, poisoning of Griffon vultures, the largest cause of non-natural mortality in large birds of prey (Carneiro et al. 2015).
population: The European population is estimated at 34,800-44,700 pairs, which equates to 69,600-89,400 mature individuals (BirdLife International in prep.). Approximately 10% of the global range for this species falls within Europe, so a very preliminary estimate of the global population size is 696,000-894,000 mature individuals. However, Botha et al. (2017) estimate the population to be much smaller than this, at 80,000-120,000 individuals. It is placed in the band 80,000-900,000 mature individuals.
conservationActions:
Conservation actions underway
CITES Appendix II, CMS Appendix II, Raptors MOU Category 3, EU Birds Directive Annex I. Breeding schemes are in place in at least 8 European countries (Derlink et al. 2018). A Multi-species Action Plan to Conserve African-Eurasian Vultures was produced in 2017 (Botha et al. 2017). The species has been reintroduced to several countries in Europe, including France, Italy and the Balkans. Supplementary feeding also take place in several countries, and has successfully increased the breeding population in Serbia (Marinkovic et al. 2021). Several projects are underway to battle the threat of illegal poisoning, such as the BalkanDetox LIFE project (https://balkandetoxlife.eu/). 

Conservation Actions Proposed
Research the extent of poisoning by NSAIDs in Europe. Ensure enforcement of regulations imposed to avoid diclofenac intoxication in vultures. If necessary, implement a ban on veterinary use of diclofenac in Europe and promote vulture-safe alternatives. Continue monitoring population trends. Investigate the effect of human disturbance on colony size (Choresh et al. 2019). Identify threats outside of breeding areas. Continue to raise awareness and build capacity to fight illegal poisoning. Enforce legal consequences of illegal poisoning. For a comprehensive list of proposed conservation actions, see Botha et al. (2017).

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered on the basis that this species occurs in a single location, a plateau with an area of around 10 km<sup>2</sup> (representing the maximum extent of occurrence and area of occupancy), and there is a continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat as a result primarily of rock extraction and wind farm development and potentially from already ongoing effects of climate change, and the species appears to be in decline based on recent surveys.
habitat: This is a species of an open, high-altitude, sparsely vegetated plateaus bordering moist forest (Giri and Bauer 2008), known only from a single plateau about 20 km south west of Satara (Z.A. Mirza pers. comm. February 2011). It occurs under rocks.
threats: This species is restricted to the summit of a small high-altitude plateau, where a possible future, or potentially ongoing, threat exists from climate change. Fragmentation of formerly continuous habitats by wind farms and associated road infrastructure represent the major threat, and removal of rocks that act as shelter sites is likely to increase competition with juvenile Sarada superba. The monsoon is becoming more erratic and appears to be affecting the seasonal activity of this species, presumably because it has specific temperature or humidity requirements. Roads represent a major barrier to dispersal.
population: These geckos are reasonably common during the monsoon (S. Chikane, H. Bhosle and V. Giri pers. comm. March 2011), but very patchily distributed and not observed outside the monsoon season, which is becoming more erratic. Based on repeated recent surveys from 2009 to 2018 the population trend appears to be declining. It is reliant on rocks, which are slowly being removed for construction and are thought likely to act as shelter sites for hatchling Sarada superba, which breed during the same season and are becoming more common, and this species may displace the gecko (V. Giri pers. comm. 2019). The habitat is fragmentary, and research is underway to clarify whether the population of this small gecko is severely fragmented (V. Giri pers. comm. 2019).
range: This gecko is endemic to India and is known  from only two localities in the Western Ghats, on the Chalakewadi Plateau, Satara District, Maharashtra (Giri and Bauer 2008), which has an area of around 10 km<sup>2</sup>.  Surveys have not recorded it from other nearby plateaus in surveys. It has been collected at 1,100 m asl (V. Giri pers. comm. 2019). Very few plateaus in the Western Ghats reach this altitude, and the species is consequently unlikely to be more widespread.
useTrade: The species is not in use.
conservationActions: This gecko is not known from any protected areas. Detailed ecological and population studies are required, including genetic research into population connectivity, temperature and humidity requirements, and the impacts of competition with hatchlings of a sympatric lizard and of wind farms are required. Although not protected area, no development is permitted within the area encompassed by wind farms.

rationale: Listed as Near Threatened on the basis that, following this species' recent rediscovery, it appears to be more widespread than previously recognized and much of its range lies within protected areas. A number of human activities are ongoing within its range that are likely to degrade or remove suitable habitat, but at present the population is not likely to be severely fragmented and threats presently appear to be localized. As such it is close to qualifying for a threatened category applying criterion B1, and further research is needed to determine whether threats are or may soon become more widespread than presently recognized.
habitat: This species has been recorded from tropical montane shola (cloud forest) It was found in grass clumps beneath fallen logs and rocks. Gravid females were observed to contain at least two eggs.
threats: In the Palni hills, deforestation has been observed due to tourism related activities mainly in the Kodaikanal region, and forest is also affected by to conversion of land for human settlements. Forests in parts of the Anaimalais are affected by hydroelectric projects and their associated canals. It is not known which, if any, of these activities impact this species. It occurs close to tea estates, and is a soil-dwelling species that is likely to get exposed to pollutants such as pesticides. Upslope displacement of other Ristella species has been observed, and there is encroachment from feral and other invasive animals such as cats. At present all these processes are thought likely to be localized and much of this species' known range lies within protected areas.
population: During December 2014 and January 2015 fieldwork revealed juveniles, gravid females, and males and females together in Kodaikanal Wildlife Sanctuary. There were three sightings over a total of 60 man hours of targeted surveys in three nearby (within 10 km) localities (Ganesh 2018) Prior to this, a single record from 1932 in the Palni Hills was the only record since its original description (Ganesh and Asokan 2010). The known range is partly fragmented by both natural barriers and areas of anthropogenic, unsuitable habitat.
range: Ristella rurkii is endemic to India and is distributed in the Anaimalai Hills, Palni Hills in the southern Western Ghats, in the states of Tamil Nadu and Kerala (Smith 1935). This species is, however, known only from historical records and has not been recorded since 1839, but was recently (2014) rediscovered from Kodaikanal Wildlife Sanctuary (Ganesh 2018), where it has been recorded from four closely adjacent localities. The original type locality, given as "North India" where this genus is absent, has resulted in confusion about its exact distribution, and there has been a lack of recent fieldwork within its range. The lowest known elevation is about 2,000 m, indicating that a historical report from the lower-elevation Travancore Hills is likely not correct.
useTrade: The species is not in use.
conservationActions: This species is known from two protected areas: Kodaikanal Wildlife Sanctuary and Anamalai Tiger Reserve. Further surveys are needed in the adjoining hills of Kerala State are recommended to better-document its geographic range and impacts of possible threats.

rationale: Listed as Vulnerable on the basis that this species is known from a single location (as it occurs only marginally in the Samanala reserve, in an area subject to the same threats as the type locality) and, although there is some degree of ongoing encroachment, the major threat to this species' survival is believed to be a likely future increase in populations of invasive predators, including domestic cars, which is expected to result from an increase in religious tourism in this area. It is consequently close to qualifying for listing as Critically Endangered applying criterion B, and will trigger this criterion immediately should this threat become active, but is not believed to be at immediate risk of extinction.
habitat: This species was collected from tall, straight trees providing thick canopy cover, and tall clay walls with crevices, in a home garden (Karunarathna and Ukuwela 2019). It is diurnal, and active up to 7 m high on vertical services (Karunarathna and Ukuwela 2019). The surrounding area is a matrix of tropical evergreen rainforest, home gardens and tea and rubber plantations both in and outside the protected area (Karunarathna and Ukuwela 2019). Mean annual rainfall in this area is from 3,500-4,500 mm, received mostly via the southwest monsoon (May–September). The mean annual temperature in this region is 26.4–27.9 ºC. (Karunarathna and Ukuwela 2019). During surveys between 2006 and 2019 only five specimens were found within forest, the first in 2012 (S. Karunarathna pers. comm. 2019). This may reflect detection bias as this species is found only in very well-forested home garden habitats (Karunarathna and Ukuwela 2019), which in this area closely resemble natural forest (S. Karunarathna pers. comm. 2019).
threats: The type locality, which lies outside the Samanala protected area, is subject to encroachment from tea plantations and small-scale hydropower projects (Karunarathna and Ukuwela 2019), and threats extent into the reserve's buffer zone. Although the major part of the Samanala protected area is subject to limited disturbance, most of this reserve lies at elevations above 1,000 m asl. and this species is confined to lower-elevation areas at the margins of the reserve, barely outside the buffer zone.  Increased pilgrimage, with extensive associated rubbish that is likely to attract invasive predators (mostly cats) in larger numbers, is considered a plausible future threat, and is likely to represent the primary threat to this species (S. Karunarathna pers. comm. 2019).
population: This species is "quite rare" (Karunarathna and Ukuwela 2019). These authors reported an encounter rate of six geckos per survey hour during surveys in March 2019, across six localities over an area of 20 ha. The population density is very low (S. Karunarathna pers. comm. 2019).
range: This recently-described species is known only from Udamaliboda, and from the Lihinihela, Borangamuwa and Warnagala areas of Samanala Nature Reserve, all in Sabaragamuwa Province, Sri Lanka (Karunarathna and Ukuwela 2019). It has been recorded from 435 to 634 m asl (Karunarathna and Ukuwela 2019). It has not been found in surveys of surrounding areas.
useTrade: There is no known use of or trade in this species.
conservationActions: This species occurs both within and outside Samanala Nature Reserve (Karunarathna and Ukuwela 2019). Karunarathna and Ukuwela (2019) propose that the need to preserve natural and semi-natural habitat for this species should be considered when planning new hydropower projects in this area. More research into the life history and ecology. of this recently-recognized species is recommended

rationale: Piliocolobus rufomitratus is listed as CR A3c. This species is endemic to forests along a 60-km stretch of the lower Tana River. The current population is estimated at ca 1,000 individuals. Future population reduction of 80% or more is possible should the rate of decline in forest cover approach levels reached several years back and continue for the next three generations (2019-2048). This is especially likely if the Tana River Primate National Reserve (TRPNR) is officially annulled, an action now being considered by national authorities. The entire population lies in a politically insecure area over which there is a low level of conservation activity, and much unplanned, unregulated, and unsustainable exploitation of natural resources.
habitat: Piliocolobus rufomitratus occupies riverine and flood-plain forests. This folivorous species has a home range of ca 4–19 ha (Decker 1994). Mean group size is ca 13 individuals (Butynski and Mwangi 1994) with generally one adult male (Marsh 1979, Decker 1994, Mbora 2003). Piliocolobus rufomitratus is arboreal, but must come to the ground (rarely) to move between, and colonise, distant forest patches.
threats:
Piliocolobus rufomitratus has declined as a result of several causes, including: (a) drastic changes in vegetation due to dam construction, irrigation projects, and water diversion, which affect the water table and the frequency and severity of flooding which, in turn, affect the amount and quality of habitat; (b) forest clearance for agriculture; (c) fires that destroy forests; (d) habitat degradation due to livestock and the unsustainable collection of wood and other forest products; (e) selective felling of fig trees for canoes; and (f) corruption, inter-ethnic violence, and insecurity (Butynski and Mwangi 1994, 1995; Wieczkowski and Mbora 2000; De Jong and Butynski 2012; Struhsaker and Grubb 2013; Wieczkowski and Butynski 2013; Butynski and Hamerlynck 2016; Butynski and De Jong 2019). Because all remaining forests inhabited by P. rufomitratus are small and seriously threatened, the long-term survival of the species is in question.

There has been considerable alteration of river flow volume and the flood cycle by five hydroelectric power dams up-river (Butynski 1995). A sixth dam, the High Grand Falls Dam, is under construction (Hamerlynck et al. 2012, Butynski and Hamerlynck 2016). The High Grand Falls Dam, the second largest dam in Africa, will be accompanied by large-scale irrigation schemes and water transfer to the ‘Lamu Port and Lamu Southern Sudan-Ethiopia Transport Corridor’. The establishment of this dam is expected to have additional negative impacts on the forests of the Lower Tana River and, therefore, on P. rufomitratus.

One special concern is the rapidly growing human population in the region. Another is the possible annulment of the Tana River Primate National Reserve (TRPNR; 169 km²) which the High Court of Kenya ordered in January 2007. According to the Kenya Wildlife Act 2013, Section 37, change of boundaries or revocation of a National Reserve can only be published by the Cabinet Secretary and approved by Parliament. Change or revocation can only be recommended if they do not endanger any species or critical habitat. As such, it seems unlikely that annulment will occur, despite the court ruling in 2007.

About 35% of P. rufomitratus occur in the TRPNR. Even with the continued existence of the TRPNR the long-term survival of P. rufomitratus is not certain, as the high level of insecurity and inadequate law enforcement in the region is expected to continue (Butynski and Mwangi 1994, 1995; Struhsaker and Grubb 2013; Wieczkowski and Mbora 2000; Butynski and De Jong 2018).

According to Global Forest Watch data, Kenya's Tana River region has lost 16% of its forest cover since the turn of the century, tropical forest habitat being reduced from approximately 60,000 to 50,000 hectares. Although the annual rate of loss has remained fairly consistent throughout this period (530 ha/yr avg), it has spiked several times to more than double or triple that rate. Should the TRPNR be annulled and/or peak rates of deforestation be reached again, it is conceivable that this species could lose 80% or more of its habitat by mid-century.
population:
Total number of Piliocolobus rufomitratus estimated at 1,100–1,300 individuals in 1994 (Butynski and Mwangi 1994, 1995). Total population today ca 1,000 individuals and is expected to continue to decline (Mbora 2003, Karere et al. 2004, Butynski and Hamerlynck 2016, T. Butynski and Y. de Jong pers. obs. 2018).

Although the annual rate of habitat loss of this species has remained fairly consistent (530 ha/yr avg), it has spiked several times to more than double or triple that rate. Should the Tana River Primate National Reserve (TRPNR) be annulled and/or peak rates of deforestation be reached again, it is conceivable that this species could lose > 80% of its habitat by mid-century.
range:
Piliocolobus rufomitratus is a medium-sized monkey that occurs along the lower Tana River and in the Tana Delta, north coast of Kenya. It occurs along a 60-km stretch of the lower Tana River from Kipende in the north to Mitipani in the south where the Lamu-Garsen Road crosses the Tana River floodplain. A small number of individuals may still exist in the Tana Delta. This species lives in about 34 distinct, small (1–500 ha) forests, some of which are isolated. Some of the more important forests are Guru South, Sifa East, Baomo South, Mnazini East, Bubesa West 1 and Hewani South 2 (Butynski and Mwangi 1994).

Piliocolobus rufomitratus is broadly sympatric with Cercocebus galeritus, Cercopithecus mitis albotorquatus, Paragalago cocos and Otolemur garnettii lasiotis, and narrowly sympatric on the forest edge with Papio cynocephalus ibeanus, Chlorocebus pygerythrus hilgerti and Galago senegalensis braccatus (De Jong and Butynski 2009, 2012; Butynski and De Jong 2019).
conservationActions:
Piliocolobus rufomitratus is listed on Appendix I of CITES and on Class B of the African Convention on the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources. Given the current poor management of the Tana River Primate National Reserve (TRPNR), the continued clearing of forest and settlement of people within the TRPNR, and the low level of conservation activity in the region, the long-term survival of P. rufomitratus seems bleak. A small number of P. rufomitratus may still be present in the Tana River Delta. This delta became a Ramsar Site in 2012, but the forests there continue to be destroyed and, in any case, the number of P. rufomitratus there is small (Butynski and de Jong 2019). Otherwise, the Tana Delta holds no protected area.

Ndera Community Conservancy, established in 2010 with the help of the Northern Rangeland Trusts (www.nrt-kenya.org), aims to conserve 150 km² of the lower Tana River and to improve the viability of forest patches within and outside the TRPNR (Mbora and Allen 2011, J. King pers. comm. 2016). The Ndera Community Conservancy provides an opportunity for improved conservation of those forests upon which P. rufomitratus depends.

Stringent habitat protection is required for all forests of the Lower Tana River and Tana Delta. The Mchelelo Research Station in the TRPNR needs to be rehabilitated and re-established.

Piliocolobus rufomitratus is listed as one of the world’s 25 most threatened primates (Butynski and Hamerlynck 2016).

rationale:
The global population of Macquarie Perch is inferred to have declined significantly in extent of occurrence (EOO) (Criterion A2c) with the species now effectively restricted to upland forested catchments. The pre-1990 EOO was 258,634 km2 and the post-1990 EOO is 65,231 km2, a reduction of 75%. These figures are calculated from the Atlas of Living Australia dataset, after eliminating obvious distributional errors. The reduction in area of occupancy (AOO) likely mirrors this decline, but there is no accurate national dataset to allow calculation of historic AOO with confidence. The current AOO is 492 km2. This population decline is likely to also extend into the future (Criterion A3c) as existing populations are now generally small, fragmented, and recent experience suggests that many populations suffered significantly during the recent Millennium Drought in southeastern Australia (Lintermans et al. 2014) with drought and other climatic extremes (severe storms) predicted to become more frequent under climate change. Such declines in abundance and distribution are unlikely to be reversible. The population is now considered severely fragmented.

The impact on Macquarie Perch from the the Epizootic Haematopoietic Necrosis virus (EHNV), carried by alien species such as Redfin Perch (Perca fluviatlis) and Rainbow Trout (Oncorhynchus mykiss) has also been shown to cause dramatic mortality of Macquarie Perch under laboratory conditions and is suspected of involvement in the extirpation of some populations (e.g. Lake Eildon) (Langdon 1989). Once EHNV is in a catchment, it is virtually impossible to eradicate. Redfin Perch have also been directly associated with declines of Macquarie Perch in New South Wales (Lachlan River catchment) with predation of juveniles the likely mechanism of impact (Gilligan et al. 2010).

Based on this information, a population reduction of 50% is inferred over the past three generations (42 years). Based on this population reduction and the restricted distribution, this species is therefore assessed as Endangered.
habitat: This species now inhabits cool, clear water of rivers, lakes and reservoirs, demonstrating a preference for slow-flowing deep rocky pools. Males are reported to reach sexual maturity at two years of age and ~210 mm total length, and females at three years and 300 mm, but ripe males have been recorded at ~120 mm (Lintermans 2007). Maximum known age is 30 years and in a reservoir population 25% of spawning fish were 15-30 years old (Tonkin et al. 2018) but most riverine individuals would be expected to be less than 15-18 years old. Spawning occurs from October to December with fish migrating from lakes to tributaries to spawn (Cadwallader and Rogan 1977, Tonkin et al. 2018). Spawning is either at the foot of pools with eggs drifting downstream to lodge amongst gravel and cobble in riffles; or spawning is directly in riffles. Adults are largely crepuscular and nocturnal occupying well defined homesites during the day (Thiem et al. 2013, Koster et al. 2014).
threats:
Major threats include habitat loss and modification, overfishing (legal and illegal), impacts of alien fish species (competition, predation) and likely a viral disease (Epizootic Haematopoietic Necrosis Virus (EHNV)) largely spread/magnified by Redfin Perch (Lintermans 2007, 2013). In particular, alterations to hydrology (river regulation and water extraction and cold-water pollution), loss of connectivity between populations and habitats (dams and barriers), and changes to land use (riparian vegetation loss and sedimentation) have resulted in highly fragmented populations which have effectively isolated Macquarie Perch among waterways (Pavlova et al. 2017, Tonkin et al. 2017). The restricted distribution and now isolation of riverine populations, which largely occur in headwaters and tributary systems make the few remaining remnant riverine populations particularly vulnerable to episodic disturbance events including extreme drought, floods and sedimentation (Tonkin et al. 2017). Such isolation has also resulted in loss of genetic diversity possibly reducing their adaptive potential to habitat changes associated with climate change (Pavlova et al. 2017) making future adaptation to continuing threats less likely. Changed fire management practices as a result of extensive uncontrollable bushfires has resulted in increased hazard-reduction burn frequency, and an inability to control such burns in mountainous and remote locations results in burning to the waterline, followed by subsequent sedimentation of critical habitats (spawning riffles and refuge pools). 

Populations in impoundments are susceptible to relatively rapid and catastrophic collapses, often to extinction (Lintermans 2012). The populations of Macquarie Perch in Dartmouth and Eildon reservoirs in Victoria and Lake Burrinjuck in New South Wales initially supported significant recreational fisheries (Cadwallader and Rogan 1977). There are also anecdotal reports of good populations in Tantangara Reservoir in New South Wales (Trueman 2011), with this population now extirpated. All of these impoundment populations have declined dramatically, with the species now effectively extirpated from Eildon, Burrinjuck and Tantangara. The species did not survive the impoundment of the Queanbeyan River to form Googong Reservoir in New South Wales, with existing spawning habitat flooded by the new impoundment and a natural barrier (waterfall) preventing access to spawning habitats upstream of the new impoundment. An emergency translocation was required to allow fish to access suitable spawning habitat upstream of Googong Reservoir, but the re-established population subsequently failed during the Millenium Drought (1997-2010) (Lintermans 2013). The enlargement of the Cotter Reservoir in the ACT resulted in a similar disruption to spawning migrations between the reservoir and the stream, with existing spawning habitats flooded and instream barriers (exacerbated by low flow conditions as a result of an upstream impoundment) blocking access to new spawning sites (Broadhurst et al. 2018).

Additionally, interactions with alien species such as trout and Redfin Perch have exposed this species to Epizootic Haematopoietic Necrosis Virus (EHNV, carried by Redfin Perch). Proposed pumped-hydro schemes pose a significant risk of transferring EHNV and Redfin Perch from the upper Tumut system to the upper Murrumbidgee subpopulation in the future. Habitat modification, clearing of riparian vegetation, constructions of dams and weirs act as barriers to migration and recolonisation and cold water discharges from dams can prevent successful breeding in this species. Illegal fishing and unwitting harvest as a result of mis-identification remains a threat to this species.
population: There are no robust population estimates for subpopulations. This species has experienced population declines in recent decades due to habitat loss and modification, overfishing, impacts of alien fish species and probably a viral disease introduced by Redfin Perch (Lintermans 2007, 2013). In particular, alterations to hydrology (river regulation and extraction), connectivity (dams and barriers), and land use (riparian and sedimentation) have resulted in highly fragmented populations which have effectively isolated Macquarie Perch among waterways (Pavlova et al. 2017, Tonkin et al. 2017). Populations in impoundments are susceptible to relatively rapid and catastrophic collapses, often to extinction (Lintermans 2012), and such collapses have occurred in Lake Burrinjuck, Tantangara Reservoir, Googong Reservoir in NSW, and Lake Eildon in Victoria. Other populations in lowland habitats such as the mid-lower Murray have disappeared since the mid-1900s, and the Macquarie River population (type locality) is extinct. Several viable subpopulations have been lost in the last 10-15 years including Goodradigbee River/Burrinjuck, Queanbeyan River. Lachlan River, and the Broken River is now unlikely to be viable in the long-term. However, two subpopulations outside the natural range resulting from historical translocations are well established (Yarra River in Victoria, Cataract Reservoir in NSW) (Pavlova et al. 2017) and a population in the Mongarlowe River persists, with very low recruitment after collapsing in the 1980s/1990s (Lintermans 2008).
range:
This species is native to the Murray-Darling Basin in southeastern Australia where it is currently found in New South Wales, Victoria and the Australian Capital Territory (Lintermans 2007). It was historically occasionally recorded in the lower reaches of the Murray River in South Australia and the Macquarie River in New South Wales, but it is no longer present there. Within its current natural range it is generally now restricted to the upper reaches of the catchments, often only occupying tributaries of major rivers where natural flow and temperature regimes remain and riparian zones are intact. It is considered that there are 12 subpopulations occurring: Cotter River (ACT); Upper Murrumbidgee River; Mannus Creek; Adjungbilly Creek; Retreat River/Abercrombie River (NSW);  Lake Dartmouth/upper Mitta Mitta River; Hughes Creek; King Parrot Creek; Hollands Creek; Sevens Creek; Yea River; and upper Buffalo River (VIC). Several viable subpopulations have been lost in the last 10-15 years including Goodradigbee River/Burrinjuck, Queanbeyan River; Lachlan River; and the Broken River; and possibly Mannus Creek and Adjungbilly Creek are now unlikely to be viable in the long-term. The historical oral history research of Trueman (2011) records the species in many more localities than it is currently found, with many of these localities not represented in scientific databases. The species was reported to be highly abundant in the main river stems of the southern basin.

Despite a large number of failed attempts, particularly in Victoria, the species has been successfully translocated to several localities in coastal drainages outside of its native range, such as Cataract Reservoir and the Mongarlowe River in New South Wales (Lintermans 2007, 2008) and the Yarra River in Victoria (Pavlova et al. 2017, Tonkin et al. 2017). None of these translocated subpopulations were the result of attempts to reduce extinction risk: all were for recreational fishing, but all now have self-sustaining populations with unique genetic diversity and structure. Within-range translocations/reintroductions have also occurred with a new population established in the Retreat River (NSW), a population in the Queanbeyan River was established for decade but then extirpated in the Millenium Drought (Lintermans 2013) and there are preliminary indications that translocated individuals are commencing to reproduce in the Ovens River (Vic). A 10+ year translocation program to the upper Cotter River has not yet demonstrated any recruitment (Lintermans 2017).
useTrade: This species was/is a popular and highly regarded angling species. The species is completely protected from harvest in New South Wales, and the Australian Capital Territory, however illegal fishing remains a threat to the species. Recreational fishing (and take) is permitted in Victoria, being restricted to two lacustrine and one riverine (translocated) population with strict bag limits and closed seasons.
conservationActions: The species is completely protected from capture in New South Wales and the ACT, however illegal fishing and bycatch fishing mortality remains a threat to the species. Strict bag limits and closed seasons and areas apply for recreational fisheries in Victoria. Additionally there are many large scale initiatives to restore and protect the Murray-Darling river system (fish passage programs; riparian revegetation; alien fish species control), but the Murray-Darling Basin remains highly important for agricultural production in Australia, and this agricultural focus still dominates river management activities. The species was nationally listed as threatened in 1980 but a national recovery plan still has not been completed for the species. State recovery plans or action plans are in place in Victoria and the ACT. In Victoria, hatchery production using ripe wild fish and translocations of fish from Lake Dartmouth has been used to re-establish Macquarie Perch in the Ovens River. A range of habitat restoration works including riparian and instream interventions, have been underway across the species range to reduce the long term decline of the species. Exotic species control has also been applied to some populations, for Common Carp and Redfin Perch in Victoria, and for trout in the Retreat River.

rationale: This species is assessed as Vulnerable due to a suspected past population rate of at least 30%, primarily due to habitat loss but also due to rapid habitat degradation. The Pará State in Brazil has lost 12% of its forest cover from 2000 to 2018 (Global Forest Watch 2020).
habitat: The species occurs in lowland primary and secondary terra firme forests (Costa-Araújo et al. 2019).
threats:
The area within the species' range has suffered extensive environmental damages due to illegal logging and agricultural expansion—this is happening even in federal protected areas and protected indigenous lands. This region is one of the main fronts of forest destruction in the Arc of deforestation, a region infamously characterized by fast, intense and disordered conversion of forests to pastoral and agricultural land and human settlements. In addition, there are four hydroelectric plants in the process of implementation in this region that will directly impact the habitat of the species.

Feeder roads of the Cuiaba-Santarem highway cut through the eastern border of the distribution of M. munduruku, resulting in considerable deforestation, including in protected areas. These roads also connect to the illegal alluvial mining areas in the Rio Crepori. There is extensive damage due to alluvial mining in the north eastern section of its range.
population: This is unknown regarding this species, but it is suspected that populations are in decline due to habitat degradation.
range:
Mico munduruku is endemic to the Amazonian forest of the southwest of Pará State, Brazil, occurring from the left margin of the Rio Jamanxim River, below the mouth of Rio Novo, possibly up to the right margin of the upper Rio Tapajós, below the mouth of the Rio Cururú (Costa-Araújo et al. 2019).

Based on specimens observed in the field, interviews with local inhabitants, specimens examined in museum collections and field reports, there are seven localities in the northern Tapajós–Jamanxim interfluve where the distinctive marmosets can be found, covering an area of approximately 55,000 km (Costa-Araújo et al. 2019). The state of Pará in Brazil has lost 12% of its forest cover from 2000 to 2018 (Global Forest Watch 2020).
conservationActions: Mico munduruku already faces the above-mentioned threats, and they will only increase as hydroelectric plants and complementary infrastructure projects as roads and transmission lines come to completion, inducing more intense settlement and forest reduction in the region. For these reasons, further research is urgently needed to better delimit the species’ range and to estimate population size and density, allowing for assessment of its conservation status and mitigate some of the projected impacts on its populations.

rationale: Boubli et al. (2019) estimated a loss of 42% of habitat (forest, excluding savannas) within the species range to date, or 39% of the species’ total range (forest and savannas). Using predictive models, the species’ habitat loss over the next 24 years will amount to 50% under the “governance” scenario and to 86% under the “business as usual” scenario (Boubli et al. 2019). Due to the ongoing process of Protected Area downgrading, downsizing, and degazettement (PADDD) in the Brazilian Amazon and the planned hydroelectric complex of dams for this region (Bernard et al. 2014, Fernandes et al. 2017, Ferreira et al. 2014, Pack et al. 2016, UHE Teles-Pires 2018), the “business as usual” scenario is considered more probable. Based on this, we classify Plecturocebus grovesi as Critically Endangered (CR A3c), i.e., population reduction projected, inferred or suspected to be met in the future [up to three titi monkey generations, i.e., 24 years (Veiga et al. 2011, Defler and García 2012)], considering a decline of greater than 80% in extent of occurrence (EOO) and/or habitat quality.
habitat: This species is found in forests.
threats: Populations have undergone a decline in the past due to habitat degradation and loss. The species is threatened by the ongoing process of Protected Area downgrading, downsizing, and degazettement (PADDD) in the Brazilian Amazon and the planned hydroelectric complex of dams for this region (Bernard et al. 2014, Fernandes et al. 2017, Ferreira et al. 2014, Pack et al. 2016, UHE Teles-Pires 2018).
population: Populations have undergone a decline in the past due to habitat degradation and loss. Populations are suspected to undergo a decline of at least 80% over the next three generations (24 years). This is based on predictive models, which suggest species’ habitat loss over the next 24 years (three generations) of 50% under the “governance” scenario and declines of 86% under the “business as usual” scenario (Boubli et al., 2o19). Due to the ongoing process of Protected Area downgrading, downsizing, and degazettement (PADDD) in the Brazilian Amazon and the planned hydroelectric complex of dams for this region (Bernard et al. 2014, Fernandes et al. 2017, Ferreira et al. 2014, Pack et al. 2016, UHE Teles-Pires 2018), the “business as usual” scenario is considered more probable.
range: Plecturocebus grovesi is found in the state of Mato Grosso, Brazil, in the region delimited by the rios Juruena and Arinos to the west and the Rio Teles-Pires to the east. The southernmost record is about 10°S. It is probable that the Amazon forest to Cerrado ecotone delimits its range in the south (∼13°S).  More surveys, however, are necessary to confirm this (Boubli et al. 2019).  This range was formerly believed to have been occupied by Plecturocebus moloch.
useTrade: This species is hunted for food.
conservationActions: Conservation actions needed for this species include additional site management, site/area protection, harvest management, among other actions. Additional research is needed on taxonomy, population size/distribution/trends, and life history and ecology.

rationale: This species is suspected to have undergone a moderately large population reduction over the last decade, which is suspected to continue over the next decade as a result of hydroelectricity development and consequent habitat loss and degradation. However, the past and future population reductions are not thought to be large enough to meet the thresholds for Vulnerable under Criterion A. For these reasons, the species is listed as Near Threatened.
habitat: This species is found in dense vine tangles in riparian thickets and forest undergrowth near water (frequently in seasonally flooded areas and oxbow lakes). It is dependent on habitats generated by the cycle of flooding and ebbing of the rivers (D. Lima in litt. 2020). Feeds individually, in pairs, or in small family groups on a variety of invertebrate prey (Olmos et al. 2006). Forages in thick vegetation but occasionally pursues flushed prey in flight (del Hoyo et al. 2003). Breeds from May to July (Crozariol 2011).
threats:
Its specialised habitat requirements make the species susceptible to changes in hydrological management. The greatest threat to the species is the development of hydroelectrocity projects (HPP), which are likely to flood large parts of the species's habitat (Brasil Choueri et al. 2017, Dornas and Pinheira 2018, D. Lima in litt. 2020). The Estreito Hydro-Power Complex was recently constructed in the Tocantins-Araguaia river basin and within the species's range (T. Dornas in litt. 2020), going into operation in 2012. The reservoir of this project reaches between Estreito (Maranhão) and Palmeirante (Tocantins; Dornas and Pinheiro 2018). Two hydroelectrical plants projects are currently in progress within the species's range: HPP Marabá (Pará) and HPP Santa Isabel (Tocantins). HPP Marabá is projected to produce a reservoir that will reach the dam of HPP Santa Isabel on the Araguai River, and HPP Serra Quebrada in Itaguatins (PAC 2018). HPP Santa Isabel is planned for the region of the Rapids of Santa Isabel, and the reservoir is projected to reach Araguanã (Dornas and Pinheiro 2018). There are plans to construct two further hydroelectrical plants (HPP) within the species's range by 2025: HPP Araguanã and HPP Serra Quebrada, both in Tocantins, but the plans are currently on hold and they are not expected to be constructed within the next 5-10 years (T. Dornas in litt. 2020). HPP Araguanã is projected to create a reservoir that will come close to Araguacema, and HPP Serra Quebrada will dam  the Tocantins river, with a reservoir reaching HPP Estreito (Dornas and Pinheiro 2018). If all the planned hydroelectricity projects are executed, they may alter almost 500 km of river for each of the two major rivers affected (D. Lima in litt. 2020).

Habitat loss is ongoing within the species's range, especially due to clearance for agriculture. Rates of deforestation in Brazil have increased from 2018-2019 (INPE 2019).

A climate vulnerability analysis projected that climatic conditions across the species's entire range will exceed those currently experienced by the species by 2015 (Borges et al. 2019).
population:
Although restricted in range and extent of habitat, it is common where it occurs. A study of ten territories at RPPN Canguçu in Tocantins found an average territory density of 0.31 per ha (31 per km2), ranging from 0.14 to 0.64 ha (Crozariol 2011). Based on these densities, a population of 220,000 pairs was estimated for Cantão State Park (Crozariol 2011). Studies at the Murici and Preto rivers, tributaries of the Araguaia, in the north of Tocantins, detected at least 22 individuals in a 1 km transect in floodplain vegetation (Dornas and Pinheiro 2018).

Based on knowledge of the species's distribution and population densities, the population size has been estimated at 15,000 - 20,000 mature individuals (T. Dornas in litt. 2020). Based on the recorded population densities, the area of tree cover with 50% canopy cover within within the species's mapped range (estimated at 46,600 km2; Global Forest Watch 2020), and assuming 10-25% of the forest is occupied, the population is estimated at 195,720-489,300 individuals, roughly equating to 130,480 - 326,200 mature individuals. Based on these estimates, the population size is here placed in the band 15,000 - 350,000 mature individuals.

There are no large gaps between areas with records and the species is considered to have a relatively high dispersal ability (Borges et al. 2019), so it is assumed to have one subpopulation.
range: Cercomacra ferdinandi is endemic to the Araguaia-Tocantins basin, Brazil, occurring in Pará and Maranhão, through Tocantins and south to Mato Grosso and south to Goiás (Olmos et al. 2006, Vasconcelos and de Souza Werneck 2008, Kirwan et al. 2015, Crozariol 2016, WikiAves 2018). It occurs along the banks and tributaries of the Araguaia river from the Ilha do Bananal to the confluence with the river Tocantins, and along the banks and tributaries of the Tocantins river south to Palmeirante (Olmos et al. 2006, Vasconcelos and de Souza Werneck 2008). Its potential range appears to be larger than its currently known distribution since a species distribution model predicted several suitable regions of habitat in the north-northeastern, southeastern, and especially western parts of its distribution (Marini et al. 2010).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions Underway
It is included in the National Action Plan for the Conservation of the Birds of the Cerrado and the Pantanal (ICMBio 2019). It occurs in the Araguaia National Park, the Cantão State Park, the Ilha do Bananal/Cantão Environmental Protection Area and the Meandros do Rio Araguaia Environmental Protection Area (Dornas and Pinheiro 2018). The National Action Plan includes objectives to monitor the species and the rate of habitat loss, to identify ecological corridors for the species and to study the effects of hydroelectricity developments and other developments (ICMBio 2019). Studies have been carried out on the species's breeding densities and demography (Crozariol 2011).

Conservation and Research Actions Proposed
Undertake surveys to establish range and population size. Monitor habitat trends. Carry out further research into threats to the species, including the impacts of hydropower developments and climate change.
Pass legislation to limit developments along rivers. Lobby the government to revise plans for hydroelectric plants and control forest conversion. Enforce protected areas and protect habitat outside protected areas, particularly within ecological corridors.

rationale: This species is classified as Endangered, despite its large range, because it has a very small population that is considered to be in decline. This and its virtual disappearance from agricultural lowlands make it highly reliant on protected areas in its core breeding range.
habitat: It is a species of cool, dry-country, frequenting coastal and montane fynbos (Curtis et al. 2004, R.E. Simmons, O. Curtis and A. Jenkins in litt. 2004), highland grasslands, Karoo subdesert scrub, open plains with low shrubs and croplands. It often breeds close to coastal and upland marshes with tall shrubs or reeds, occurring in dry steppe and grassland areas further north in the non-breeding season (Brown et al. 1982, Thiollay 1994, R.E. Simmons, O. Curtis and A. Jenkins in litt. 2004). In the Western Cape of South Africa it is most abundant in coastal and montane fynbos (Curtis et al. 2004), whilst in Namibia it favours coastal river floodplains (S. Braine and J. Paterson per Simmons 2005). It prefers open ground with low vegetation for hunting, where it feeds on a diet comprising mainly of small mammals, especially Otomys and Rhabdomys species (R.E. Simmons, O. Curtis and A. Jenkins in litt. 2004). Whilst mammals make up the vast majority of prey taken at coastal sites (and this remains consistent throughout the breeding season [García-Heras et al. 2017]), birds make up a slightly greater proportion than mammals in the diet of pairs nesting in montane habitats (Curtis et al. 2004), although individuals breeding at inland sites start the breeding season with a similar diet to those at coastal sites and as the season progresses their diet shifts to fewer mammals and more birds and reptiles (García-Heras et al. 2017). Local fluctuations in breeding numbers may be related to population cycles in its prey base, such as mice whose numbers fluctuate with rainfall, especially in the more arid regions (Thiollay 1994, R.E. Simmons in litt. 2007, see also García-Heras et al. 2016, 2017). Damp sites, near vleis, marshes or streams, are preferred for breeding (Brown et al. 1982), while south-facing slopes are preferred in montane areas (R.E. Simmons in litt. 2007). Nests are built on the ground and usually hold three to five eggs (Brown et al. 1982, Curtis et al. 2004, R.E. Simmons, O. Curtis and A. Jenkins in litt. 2004). In south-western South Africa, egg-laying takes place in June-November, with peaks in July and September (Curtis et al. 2004). After breeding, females appear to migrate to higher elevations, while the males stay closer to the breeding grounds (Anderson 2013). There appears to be a lack of genetic variation within the species, which while uncommon, is not unique (Fuchs et al. 2014).
threats:
The species has conceivably lost 50% of its preferred breeding habitat over the last century (Curtis et al. 2004), and present rates of loss in the Overberg may be over 1% per annum (R.E. Simmons in litt. 2007). Habitat is primarily lost to agriculture, and this is compounded by the uncontrolled burning of fynbos and grassland, which renders these habitats unsuitable for breeding for about five years (R.E. Simmons, O. Curtis and A. Jenkins in litt. 2004). Alien vegetation and urbanisation are also cited as causes of habitat loss (Curtis et al. 2004). In south-western South Africa, it is thought that breeding birds have been displaced from prime lowland habitats (renosterveld and fynbos) by the spread of cereal agriculture, with breeding pairs presently occupying only coastal areas, with high productivity, and montane habitats, where breeding success is low and levels of nest predation are high (Curtis et al. 2004). It is particularly vulnerable to nest predation because it nests on the ground (see Lee and Simmons 2014). Rodent populations in areas of wheat cultivation may be as low as 33% of those found in renosterveld vegetation (R.E. Simmons in litt. 2004), and remnant patches of renosterveld, which continue to be degraded (R.E. Simmons, O. Curtis and A. Jenkins in litt. 2004), hold lower numbers of rodents than coastal strandveld vegetation (R.E. Simmons in litt. 2004).

Low hatching rates, possibly as a result of high pesticide residues, is an increasing threat now that many remaining breeding habitats are surrounded by agricultural areas (R.E. Simmons, O. Curtis and A. Jenkins in litt. 2004). The ingestion of herbicides and pesticides may account for the death of some adults in South Africa (Simmons 2005). Persistent organocholorines, which were found in blood samples from South African birds, may cause physical stress and reduced immunity at higher blood concentrations (Garcia-Heras et al. 2017b). Road deaths adjacent to west coast breeding grounds also numbered six birds over one breeding season in 2007 (R.E. Simmons in litt. 2007). Drainage, impoundment and inappropriate management of vleis, marshes or streams near breeding grounds could prove detrimental. Climate change in South Africa is predicted to cause a decrease in overall winter rainfall in the core breeding areas, which is likely to lead to a reduction in mouse populations and disruption to breeding (R.E. Simmons in litt. 2007). The same threats may apply to the species in Namibia, and the favoured habitats of the migrant population may be overgrazed, particularly in southern Namibia (Simmons 2005).

Overgrazing in southern Namibia is attributed mainly to resident pastoralists and 'emergency grazing' by farmers from elsewhere, which is offered during years of good rainfall (R.E. Simmons in litt. 2007). Assessments carried out between 2016-2019 found wind farms to be a major threat to Black Harriers, with a mortality rate of 1.5 birds per year at some farms (R.E Simmons, 2019, pers. comm.,). Initial results from a PVA underway by Cervantes et al., (in prep) suggest that if an average of three birds were killed per year by wind farms in South Africa the population would collapse in about 100 years, while if five birds were killed per year by wind farms in South Africa the population would collapse in less than 75 years.
population: The total population is estimated at <1,000 individuals in South Africa, Lesotho and Eswatini (Taylor 2015) with only c.10 mature individuals outside this region (Taylor 2015; <50 individuals of all ages in Namibia [Simmons 2015]). This would equate to approximately 670 mature individuals, placed here in the range 251-999 mature individuals. Based on its distribution, it is thought to form 2 subpopulations, with the largest subpopulation holding the majority of individuals.
range: Circus maurus is restricted to southern Africa, where it is concentrated in the Western Cape (its core range), and occurs in the Eastern Cape, the Northern Cape and Free State (where it is irruptive in both areas), in South Africa (R.E. Simmons in litt. 2004), and is also found in Lesotho (non-breeding birds) (R.E. Simmons, O. Curtis and A. Jenkins in litt. 2004), with a tiny isolated population in northern Namibia (less than 50 birds including about five pairs [Simmons 2015]). It is considered a vagrant in Botswana and Eswatini, where non-breeding birds occasionally occur (Hancock 2008). An unknown proportion migrates between South Africa and Namibia (Simmons 2005).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions Underway
CITES Appendix II. CMS Appendix II. There are fewer than 100 individuals in protected areas (Siegfried 1992). The resident Namibian population occurs within the Skeleton Coast Park and is protected from fires and grazing (Simmons 2005). The breeding ecology and threats for this species are being studied, in particular the effects of habitat fragmentation (Taylor 2015). An ongoing monitoring programme has been underway since 2000, led by R. E. Simmons at the University of Cape Town. A Species Action Plan is underway, facilitated by BirdLife South Africa and Endangered Wildlife Trust of South Africa, and a population viability analysis is being undertaken, led by R.E. Simmons and Dr Francisco Cervantes Peralta (R.E.Simmons, 2019, pers.comm., 20 December).

Conservation Actions Proposed
Investigate the possible occurrence of breeding in the northern Namibian population (likely in October-November) (Simmons 2005). Study the causes of population fluctuations (R.E. Simmons, O. Curtis and A. Jenkins in litt. 2004). Carry out research into its foraging ecology and the availability of rodent prey around habitat fragments (R.E. Simmons, O. Curtis and A. Jenkins in litt. 2004). Provide incentives to landowners to manage fynbos, renosterveld and grasslands beneficially (R.E. Simmons, O. Curtis and A. Jenkins in litt. 2004). Instigate education programmes to raise awareness of the value of this species. Study direct interactions and potential competition between the species and African Marsh Harrier C. ranivorus where they occur in sympatry (Curtis et al. 2004). Promote the species as an icon of Cape conservation needs (R.E. Simmons, O. Curtis and A. Jenkins in litt. 2004). Research the importance of conservation actions in Lesotho (Taylor 2015).

rationale: Moderately rapid declines are known to have occurred in several key areas across this species's range as a result of habitat fragmentation and degradation. Consequently it is classified as Vulnerable.
habitat: In Morocco and Tunisia, it typically occupies open plains, shrub-steppe and high steppe dotted mainly with alfa grass steppes (Stipa spp.). Abundant also in non-degraded wormwood (Artemisia spp.) and other species-mixed shrub vegetation patches, on hard or pebbly soils, avoiding sand (Isenmann and Moali 2000, Thévenot et al. 2003, Isenmann et al. 2005). In Spain, it occurs mostly in areas with low bushes (Seoane et al. 2006, Vögeli et al. 2010, Perez-Granados et al. 2017a, Gomez-Catasus et al. 2019). It may also occur in cereal fields outside the breeding season (Suárez et al. 2008). It is found from 50-1,880 m but mainly over 1,000 m. It feeds on the ground on insects and seeds. Breeding takes place in March-July (Herranz et al. 1994, Perez-Granados et al. 2017b). Breeding in the North African populations starts earlier, at the end of January-February.
threats:
In parts of its range, overgrazing or undergrazing and agricultural development have caused a reduction in its preferred habitats and a considerable decrease in numbers (M. Smart in litt. 2004, Isenmann et al. 2005, Traba et al. 2019). Reforestation schemes also lead to a loss of suitable habitat and infrastructure development has led to fragmentation of habitat, particularly by the construction and development of windfarms in Spain. In Tunisia, the fight against desertification has led to reforestation with Eucalyptus spp. and Optunia spp., which has caused a severe, rapid reduction in the halfa steppes. In Morocco, the loss of the traditional way of life for the nomadic grazers has led to increased sedentary agricultural pressures like the increase in livestock herds. 
The limited dispersal capabilities of the species and its fragmented distribution reduce the exchange of individuals between populations and increases their extinction risk (Méndez et al. 2014).  

The shrinking of its available habitat may be leading to territory saturation, which in turn can lead to agonistic behaviour and nest failure (Vögeli et al. 2010; Pérez-Granados and López-Iborra 2013, 2015). A recent Spanish study has shown that the species's occurrence is principally determined by geographic isolation (extinction events were exclusively related to isolation), landscape matrix and patch size, rather than habitat quality (Vögeli et al. 2010). Isolation of local populations and reduced patch size has a compounding effect on population density since smaller populations suffer reduced singing repertoires which in turn reduce the rescuing from others (receiving immigrants), thus compromising population persistence (Laiolo and Tella 2008, Pérez-Granados et al. 2016). Wildfires can lead to the local extirpation of the species (Pérez-Granados et al. 2013b), although they can have long term benefits (Perez-Granados et al. 2018b). Additionally, wind farms may have negative impacts on the distribution of this lark (Gomez-Catasus et al. 2018b). Political unrest in some of its range may be impacting the species, but the effect this has had on the species is essentially unknown (D. Serrano and J. Traba in litt. 2016). Solar farms have also demonstrated negative effects on local occupancy and persistence of the species (Gomez-Catasus et al. 2018b).
population:
García et al. (2008) estimate 15,400 singing males in Morocco, while in Spain the most recent estimate suggests around 3,700-4,000 males (Traba et al. 2019). The Tunisian population was estimated to be c.600 singing males in 2007 (Suarez, Garcia and Vinuela in litt. 2020).

It has a 0.61 male-biased sex ratio, and the global estimate is currently placed between 25,000 – 35,000 individuals (J García pers. comm. 2020, J Traba pers. comm. 2020). This equates to roughly 19,500 – 27,300 mature individuals (assuming that there are roughly 9,750 – 13,650 females based on the sex ratio, and that pairs are strictly monogamous).
range:
There are two recognised subspecies: the nominate is found in Spain (mainly east Castilla y León and Aragón, also west Castilla y León near the Portuguese border, east Castilla-La Mancha, west Valencia, and south-east Andalucía), Morocco (mostly in Hauts Plataux of the eastern Oujda Province, and centre-north Rekkam region, high plains between the Middle and High Atlas mountain ranges (particularly the Midelt-Missour surroundings). It is also found in Algeria (Hauts Plateaux), and north-west Tunisia; margaritae is found in Algeria (south slopes of Atlas Mountains east to Biskra), south-east Tunisia, northern Libya and coastal west Egypt. 

Currently in Europe, the species is only found in continental Spain, which hosts around 13% of the global population (Suárez et al. 2008). The Spanish population declined by more than 20% during 1970-1990 (Tucker and Heath 1994), and this rate of decline is continuing, with a 41.4% reduction in 92 subpopulations between 2004 and 2015 (Gomez-Catasus et al. 2018a). The mean probability of extinction for the whole Spanish metapopulation in 20 years has been estimated to be 0.879 (Traba et al. 2019). 

The species has also gone extinct at multiple localities in Spain over the past two decades, with a 44% range contraction (Garcia-Anton et al., 2019). This contraction is associated with higher temperatures and lower precipitation, and a decrease in human population density which renders this species vulnerable to rural abandonment (Garcia-Anton et al. 2019). The total Spanish population was estimated at 13,000-15,000 pairs following surveys in 1988 (Garza and Suárez 1990). However, the original survey may have dramatically overestimated the size of the Spanish population, which may have comprised as few as 1,900 pairs in 1988 (Garza et al. 2003). Based upon census data collected in 2004-2007, the population was assessed as c.3,500-4,450 singing males (Suárez and Garza 2007, Suárez 2010) with declines noted in most areas (Garza et al. 2006).
