The most recent estimate for the Spanish population suggest around 3,700-4,000 males (Traba et al. 2019).

Taking into account that the sex ratio is approximately 0.61 (Suárez et al. 2009), these results would mean the existence of roughly 2,200-2,700 pairs. Some authors consider that the sex ratio is even more biased towards males (Tella et al. 2004, Vögeli et al. 2007) which would lead to an even smaller population estimate. The European population declined by more than 40% between 2004 - 2015 (Gomez-Catasus et al. 2018a). A study using autonomous sound recorders discovered several previously unnoticed populations, suggesting that the distribution range is not fully known (Perez-Granados et al. 2018a).

With the exception of Morocco and Tunisia, there is a lack of precise information on distribution and boundaries of both subspecies in North Africa. It is sparsely distributed and uncommon in most areas of its relatively small and fragmented range. In Morocco, the species has a scattered and uneven distribution, and is not recorded in large areas of apparently suitable habitat. Work in Morocco calculated an effective area of suitable habitat of 1,645 km2 (García et al. 2008). This area was estimated to support a population of 15,400 singing males (García et al. 2008), although recent studies highlight a large variation in numbers at a local scale between 2008-2020. In Tunisia, fewer than 600 singing males were estimated in 2007, and the extent of suitable habitat was drastically reduced to <100km2 (Suarez, Garcia and Vinuela in litt. 2020), compared to previous data in Isenmann et al. 2005). As well as declines noted in Spain, habitat loss has been recorded within the Moroccan breeding range, but its impact and overall trends are not well understood.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions Underway
EU Birds Directive Annex I. Bern Convention Appendix II. An EU Species Action Plan was published in 2008 (Inigo et al. 2008). The species has been studied in Spain and Morocco and was included as "Endangered" in the Spanish Red Data Book. It is considered Vulnerable in the European Red List of Birds (BirdLife International 2015). The use of conspecific playbacks to attract birds into managed-habitat areas is being trialled (Perez-Granados and Traba, 2019). The benefits of a reduction in tree cover in Valencia are under study. An EU LIFE project is underway to improve habitat in core areas of central Spain. A Spanish National Conservation Strategy has been drafted, and an initiative to uplist the species to Endangered in the Spanish Threatened Species Catalogue is in review. 

Conservation Actions Proposed
Develop new Recovery Plans at regional and national level (N. López-Jiménez in litt. 2016). Continue monitoring Spanish and Moroccan populations. Adopt methods used in Spain to survey populations in North Africa. Improve knowledge of the effect of windfarms on this species (D. Serrano and J. Traba in litt. 2016, Gomez-Catasus et al. 2018b). Determine appropriate levels of grazing to maintain habitat. Improve knowledge of the effect of overgrazing and habitat loss in North Africa, with emphasis on the effects of concentrated sedentary grazing. Investigate the population and habitat situation in Algeria. Obtain more information on factors determining demography and dispersal, particularly in a fragmentation context (D. Serrano and J. Traba in litt. 2016).

Work with farmers and pastoralists to ensure that levels of grazing benefit the species.  Progress the anti-desertification programs in Morocco. Prevent further degradation to the halfa steppes, and implement direct management to protect the remaining steppes in Tunisia. Prevent further habitat fragmentation, protect important sites and increase connectivity in the most isolated populations (López-Jiménez 2015, D. Serrano and J. Traba in litt. 2016). Develop conservation measures to maintain the populations of this species at a level corresponding to the ecological and scientific requirements (Habitat Directive) level (López-Jiménez, 2015). Since gene flow between Iberian and African populations is extremely low (García et al. 2008, Méndez et al. 2011), it is important that conservation plans for Iberian populations do not rely on the existence of the African populations of the same subspecies.

rationale: Laubuka lankensis is an endemic species in Sri Lanka which has a wide distribution throughout the lowland dry zone island. Due to an Area of Occupancy (AOO) of 184 km2 and restriction to 14 locations, together with threats of continued habitat quality decline from threats of dams, pesticides and invasive species, this species almost meets the threshold for Vulnerable and so shall be assessed as Near Threatened.
habitat: It has been recorded from a range of habits such as reservoirs, canals and rivulets with gravel and sandy substrate (De Silva et al. 2015).
threats:
It has been observed in low numbers in many lakes due to the introduction of invasive O. mosambicus, who is a superior competitor and may have contributed to reduction in numbers. Furthermore, excess usage of agricultural pesticides may accumulate in water bodies, which also poses a considerable threat to this species.

Siltage, owing to the construction of dams, as well as reduction of water flow owing to reservoir loading, may cause habitat degradation downstream and impact the survival of Laubuka lankensis.
population: No population data is available regarding the population size or trend of this uncommon species. A decline in its population may be inferred on the basis of threats faced by this species which include pollution, modifications to its natural habitat and the introduction of invasive species.
range: This species is widely distributed throughout the dry zone lowland in Sri Lanka and endemic to the island (De Silva et al. 2015).
useTrade: Locally, this species is consumed as dry fish.
conservationActions: There are no conservation plans in place for this species.

rationale: Listed as Vulnerable because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 8,625 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in three threat-defined locations, and there is ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat across its range.
habitat: Adults of this species were found at the edge of a small stream in Nothofagus woodland, and larvae were found among rocks within the stream.
threats:
Forest fires are a common and important threat in the area. A major forest fire was averted from the type locality in the summer of 2000. There was also a large forest fire in summer in 2015 that may have affected some sites where the species occurs. Native forest replacement for industrial pine and eucalyptus plantations has occurred at a large scale in central-south Chile (C. Soto pers. comm July 2017). Along with a decrease in rainfall and an increase in temperatures, this replacement has caused fires to be more frequent and severe (C. Soto pers. comm. July 2017). There are pine plantations just outside the border of Tolhuaca National Park, but where this species is found within the park is only native forest (C. Soto pers. comm. January 2017).

Threats to the habitat at San Pablo de Tregua are considered to be minor, as the site constitutes a private reserve by the Universidad Austral de Chile (C. Cuevas pers comm. January 2019). Forestry plans are sometimes permitted in the area however, with the extraction of wood (for firewood etc.) occurring on a small scale (C. Cuevas pers comm. January 2019). Threats at Colehual Alto are more severe as forest plantations are extensive in the area, only a few remnants of native forest remain, a lot of firewood extraction and grazing is occurring, and there are plans for a wind farm in the Pichilingue sector (C. Cuevas pers comm. January 2019).
population: Little information is currently available on the population size. However tadpoles and adults have been observed in several parts of Tolhuaca National Park (C. Correa pers. comm. 2015). Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species was previously only known from the type locality and its immediate surroundings on the western slopes of the Andes, at the border of Malleco Lake in Tolhuaca National Park, around 66 km northeast of Victoria City in Malleco Province, Araucania Region, in southern Chile, at 920 m asl. It has now also been recorded approximately 160 km to the south and southeast from San Pablo de Tregua near Panguipulli in Cordillera de los Andes, and from Colehual Alto in Cordillera de Mahuidanchi (C. Cuevas pers. comm. September 2018). The extent of occurrence (EOO) of this expanded range is 8,625 km<sup>2</sup>, and is comprised of three threat-defined locations. The species may occur at other nearby sites, but it is not thought to occur widely (C. Soto pers. comm. January 2017).
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
The type locality is just inside the boundary of Tolhuaca National Park. The subpopulation at San Pablo de Tregua is within a private reserve of the Universidad Austral de Chile, although small-scale wood extraction is occurring at this site (C. Cuevas pers. comm. January 2019). The Colehual Alto subpopulation is not protected.

Conservation Actions Needed
Ongoing strict protection of the National Park and private reserve is required to prevent conversion to plantations and ensure enough suitable habitat is maintained for the species. In addition, measures should be taken to ensure the management of the Park, reserve and their buffer zones help prevent the spread of devastating forest fires into the range of the species. 

Research Needed
Research on the population, distribution, ecology and threats for this species is required.

rationale: This newly-split species has a small population, which is thought to be declining due to the loss and conversion of its habitat. It is therefore listed as Vulnerable.
habitat: Tolima Blossomcrown is found in the Central Andes at altitudes of 1,200-2,300 m. It inhabits humid premontane forests, but is also found in old secondary growth and occasionally even in coffee plantations and along roads or field edges (Hilty and Brown 1986, Renjifo et al. 2016). It is usually seen in the forest understorey or in secondary scrub along roads and field edges, but males gather in small song-leks within closed-canopy forest (Hilty and Brown 1986; P. G. W. Salaman in litt. 1998, 1999). Breeding occurs in September-October (Hilty and Brown 1986).
threats: The species is threatened by forest loss, as it does not tolerate heavily converted habitats (Züchner et al. 2019). Agriculture has long dominated parts of the east slope of the Central Andes (Stiles et al. 1999). Since the 1950s, much of the original habitat in the higher side-valleys has been cleared and used for coffee, sugarcane and banana plantations, as well as for cultivations of potatoes and beans and cattle-grazing (B. López-Lanús et al. in litt.; P. G. W. Salaman in litt. 1998, 1999). Mature secondary forest patches are scattered and natural vegetation cover has been reduced by c. 85% between 1,900 and 3,200 m altitude (B. López-Lanús et al. in litt.; P. G. W. Salaman in litt. 1998, 1999). In Tolima, hydroelectricity projects have led to habitat destruction and fragmentation (Rico-Guevara et al. 2016). However, recent rates of deforestation in the area are very low (per Tracewski et al. 2016).
population: Tolima Blossomcrown is described as rare (Renjifo et al. 2016, Züchner et al. 2019). It is tentatively estimated to have a population size between 1,000 and 4,500 mature individuals, based on the population estimate of Blossomcrown before the taxonomic split into Santa Marta Blossomcrown and Tolima Blossomcrown.
range: Anthocephala berlepschi occurs in central Colombia (Hilty and Brown 1986). It is found in the central Andes on Volcán Tolima in Quindío and Tolima, with one record in 1976 south on the east slope to Huila (Hilty and Brown 1986; J. E. Orejuela in litt. 1986; P. G. W. Salaman in litt. 1998, 1999).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions Underway

CITES Appendix II. It occurs in the following protected areas: Alto Quindío-Acaime Nature Reserve, Los Nevados National Park, Cueva de los Guácharos National Park, Meremberg Nature Reserve, Roncesvalles Community Reserves and Ibanasca Nature Reserve (J. E. Orejuela in litt. 1986, Strewe and Navarro 2004, Rico-Guevara et al. 2016, Züchner et al. 2019). It is listed as nationally Vulnerable in Colombia (Renjifo et al. 2016).

Conservation Actions Proposed

Assess the species's population, distribution and ecological requirements (P. G. W. Salaman in litt. 1998, 1999). Designate more protected areas, for example at the following AICAs: Cañón del Río Combeima, Cuenca del Rio Toche and Valle de San Salvador (P. G. W. Salaman in litt. 1998, 1999, Rico-Guevara et al. 2016). Create management plans to conserve the species (Rico-Guevara et al. 2016). Improve habitat connectivity and give protection to rural buffer zones around forest fragments (Rico-Guevara et al. 2016).

rationale: The extent of occurrence (EOO) of its range is 22,425 km2, the species is known from two threat-defined locations, and there is a continuing decline in the quality and extent of its habitat. The species is therefore close to qualifying for Vulnerable under the criterion B1 and is listed as Near Threatened.
habitat: This species has been found in forest, plantations, and in rural gardens near forest, living on rocks, and often near streams and rivers because these provide favorable conditions. It is not known how much disturbance of its habitat can be tolerated. It breeds by direct development (M.-O. Rödel pers. comm. July 2016).
threats: There is likely to be extensive pressure on its forest habitat on the Freetown Peninsula primarily for firewood collection and small-scale agriculture, and areas close to Freetown are being cleared for housing development. At Yahoro the current threats include the expansion of small-scale agriculture and grazing activities, artisanal gold mining, and wildfires; the future threat to the species here is flooding from phase two of the Bumbuna hydroelectric dam project (E. Aruna pers. comm. November 2018). At Sinikoro, an area close to the Loma Mountains, all species were collected from within plantations close to streams, but the expansion of both the small-scale agricultural activities and plantations are believed to be threats to the species, as well as gold mining taking place there (E. Aruna pers. comm. November 2018). At Bumbuna, the threats are the expansion of agricultural activities and human settlements, artisanal gold mining and industrial iron ore mining (E. Aruna pers. comm. November 2018). Small-scale grazing, agriculture and firewood collection are also major threats in Guinea (L. Sandberger and M.-O. Rödel pers. comm. July 2016).
population: At the time of its discovery, the species was described as "not rare" on the Freetown Peninsula. However, it is unlikely to still occur at its type locality as this is now within the city of Freetown (A. Hillers pers. comm. September 2014). Elsewhere on the Freetown Peninsula, surveys in 2013 were unable to locate the species where Papenfuss and Barrie rediscovered it in 2004, but it was recorded from from nearby localities (also on the Peninsula) throughout 2014 (A. Hillers pers. comm. September 2014). Due to ongoing declines in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing. It is not known whether this species' population is severely fragmented, but much of its habitat, especially in Guinea, is fragmented and it is therefore likely that the population may be as well (L. Sandberger pers. comm. June 2012).
range: This species was previously only known from the hilly forests of the Freetown Peninsula in Sierra Leone. However, there are now records from northern Sierra Leone at Bumbuna (recorded in 2013) (A. Hillers pers. comm. September 2014; E. Aruna pers. comm. November 2018), and the Yahoro and Sinikoro (E. Aruna pers. comm. November 2018) in Sierra Leone. The species has also been recorded at Soyah in Guinea (recorded in 2011), near the border with Sierra Leone (N.G. Kouamé pers. comm. May 2012 and L. Sandberger pers. comm. June 2012). It might occur more widely in the forest near the border of Guinea and Sierra Leone (M.-O. Rödel and L. Sandberger pers. comm. June 2012). The extent of occurrence (EOO) of this expanded range is 22,425 km2, which is thought to represent two threat-defined locations, and it is known from near sea level up to about 400 m asl.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions
It is present in the Western Area Peninsula Forest National Park of Sierra Leone. The other sites in Sierra Leone and the site in Guinea are not protected (L. Sandberger pers. comm. June 2012). The Sinikoro records are near the border with the Loma Mountains National Park, but it is unknown whether the species occurs within the boundaries of the park.

Conservation Needed 
Effective protection and management of these sites are required, such as creating national parks. 

Research Needed
Additional research is needed to determine the population size, distribution and trends, as well as the life history and ecology of this species.

rationale: Listed as Vulnerable because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 12,012 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in fewer than 10 threat-defined locations, and the extent and quality of its forest habitat, and the number of mature individuals, in northern and north-central Honduras is decreasing.
habitat: This species lives on the ground, along small and medium-sized streams in Lowland Broadleaf Rainforest, Broadleaf Transitional Rainforest and Broadleaf Rainforest (Townsend 2014), or along the ground in ravines (McCranie and Castañeda 2007). It does not tend to survive in degraded habitats, and is a species that breeds by direct development.
threats:
The major threats include deforestation as a result of agricultural and livestock encroachment, human settlements, logging, fires and landslides. In addition, chytrid infection has been reported for a lowland subpopulation (Puschendorf et al. 2006), but the direct effects of the infection in this species are as yet unknown (Townsend and Wilson 2016). In Texiguat, the major threats to this species include high rates of deforestation and encroachment in the wildlife refuge  for extensive cattle ranching and coffee plantations, agricultural crops (e.g., beans, avocado), including in the core area, illegal selective logging for hardwoods, followed by clear-cutting along the same access routes (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). Another threat includes the construction of several small-scale hydroelectric dams (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). 

In Parque Nacional Pico Bonito, the area from which this species was recorded is subject to extensive landslides which often severely impact the species habitat. Additional major threats include deforestation as a result of agricultural and large-scale livestock encroachment, human settlements, selective logging of hardwoods, and human-induced fires (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). There is a proposal to shift the core parts both the Parque Nacional Pico Bonito and Texiguat, which may create a much larger buffer zone where habitat conversion can progress unabated (C. Antúnez, J. Ramos Galdámez and J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019). 

In Campiro y Calentura, deforestation is a major threat in the northern part caused by increasing urbanisation (M. Solís pers. comm. March 2019). In Río Yaguala, within the area this species is found, it has been cleared for accessibility for a dam development (M. Solís pers. comm. March 2019). This subpopulation appears to be stable at present, however the area is currently unprotected (J.M. Solís pers. comm. March 2019). The reform to the Ley de Protección de la Actividad Caficultora y Cacaotera (Decreto 37-2016; Artículos I, V, VI) has incentivised the cultivation of coffee in national lands, including the core zones of protected areas, which is also increasing the alteration of primary forest (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). 

By 1996 that most, if not all, streamside Craugastor known to occur above 900 m asl were thought to have disappeared in Honduras (Wilson and McCranie 1998). The reasons for the disappearances of this species at higher elevations remains unproven, although infection with chytridiomycosis together with the alteration of its habitat due to extensive landslides is a strong possibility (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). Species of the Craugastor rugulosus group appear to have undergone dramatic declines between mid 1980s to early 1990s across Honduras, including within undisturbed habitat which is a strong indicator of chytrid-related declines (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). Chytridiomycosis has been confirmed in this species (Puschendorf et al. 2006), and is associated with their population declines.

Climate change is also considered to be a threat. Highland amphibians are adapted to inhabitat a narrow climatic envelope. Changes in climate are expected to reduce the available suitable habitat and required microclimates. Rapid shifts in the climate conditions required by these species would not allow sufficient opportunity for adaptation, especially in light of the limited possibility for elevational migration. Tropical Montane Cloud Forest (>1,000 m asl) has been demonstrated to be negatively affected by climatic changes to a greater extent than other habitats (Foden et al. 2013, Wicaksono et al. 2017, Lyra et al. 2017, Neate-Clegg et al. 2018). An increase in high rainfall events are being observed throughout its range, as well as an increase in the frequency of extreme weather events (hurricanes and droughts) in the Caribbean, destroying the riparian habitat required by stream-dwelling and stream-associated amphibian species (Honduras Amphibian Red List Workshop March 2019). Climate change is therefore considered to be both a current and future threat to all amphibian species in this habitat type. Furthermore, amphibians globally are at an increased risk of disease (e.g. chytridiomycosis) and a decline in fecundity due to such changes (Pounds et al. 2006, Blaustein et al. 2010).
population: The lowland subpopulations appear to be common, but higher elevation subpopulations (above 900 m asl) have been noted to be severely reduced, as have all streamside Craugastor species above this elevation. A dying individual was observed with a high chytrid infection at 150 m asl in northern Parque Nacional Pico Bonito (Puschendorf et al. 2006). Multiple surveys in 2010, 2011, 2017-2019 have not recorded this species in the higher elevations, apart from eight individuals in Nombre de Dios National Park at 1,400 m asl in 2013 (J. Ramos Galdámez pers. comm. March 2019). It is common and frequently encountered below 900 m asl (J. Townsend, M. Solís and F. Castañeda pers. comm. March 2019). Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species was formerly only known from the Cordillera Nombre de Dios, Montaña La Muralla, and Montaña Texiguat in the departments of Atlántida, Colón, Yoro and Olancho in north-central Honduras, between 50-1,550 m asl. It is now also known from Parque Nacional Pico Bonito and Capiro y Calenturo in Honduras (Townsend and Wilson 2016). It has also been recorded in Río Yaguala in 2017-2018, between 50-500 m asl (M. Solís pers. comm. March 2019). It could be found in the remaining habitat patches between known localities, but it is endemic to the Cordillera Nombre de Dios (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019). It occurs in fewer than 10 threat-defined locations, and its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 12,012 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs in several protected areas, including Parque Nacional Pico Bonito, Capiro Calenturo, and Parque Nacional Texiguat.

Conservation Needed
Improved enforcement and management of the national parks and the elimination of incentives to convert forest (e.g., Decreto 37-2016) is urgently needed to halt anthropogenic land use change in the national parks and reserves of Honduras (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). Habitat protection is required for its unprotected locality. An ex situ conservation programme is recommended to this species (J. Kolby and L. Herrera pers. comm. March 2019), and an outreach program to promote the protection of riparian forest would also be useful for this species (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019). 

Research Needed
Research is necessary to establish the connectivity between streams throughout its habitat (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019). Taxonomic research is also required (J. Townsend and M. Solís pers. comm. March 2019).

rationale:
Anguilla bengalensis is a catadromous, semelparous species with multiple life stages. These life history traits, coupled with the limited information available to infer abundance trends, pose particular challenges in applying the IUCN Red List Categories and Criteria (Jacoby et al. 2015).

Anguilla bengalensis is widely distributed from east and southeast African water systems, across the Indian Ocean to mainland India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, Indonesia and Malaysia, and is an occasional vagrant to the Arabian Peninsula. Although there is some evidence to suggest its range may have declined as a result of barriers to migration in various localities (Matiza and Crafter 1994, Attaala and Rubaia 2005, Tamatamah 2012, Mafuca and Bills 2012, Freyhof et al. 2015, Mzuza et al. 2017). For example, two large dams in the Zambezi (Kariba and Cahora Bassa) block the migration of elvers, posing a threat to future escapement and the spawning stock (Matiza and Crafter 1994, Mafuca and Bills 2012). Throughout India too, declines have been observed in the area of occupancy possibly as a result threats such as reduced habitat availability (Shrestha 2003, Islam 2015). The species is reported as almost absent from some regions, such as the Western Ghats (J. Freyhof pers. comm. 2014). Anguilla bengalensis is exploited for consumption and is being offered for sale on business-to-business (B2B) trade platforms, however, metrics of catch or effort are not available.

While there areno quantitative time-series data relating to declines in the species, there is some evidence indicating that both range and abundance of the species are shrinking. The species has been assessed as Near Threatened (NT); it is suspected that a reduction of close to 30% is likely to have occurred over the last 3 generations (36 years), based on reports of declines across its range. It is strongly advised that monitoring for this species be conducted to better determine population status. As with all anguillids, co-ordination of the management across this species’ range will also be pivotal for conservation.

Assessment of this species was carried out during a workshop held at the Zoological Society of London from the 5th–9th of November 2018.
habitat:
There are a number of phases in an eel’s life that have specific terminology; the leaf-shaped marine larval stage is referred to as leptocephalus; these become glass eels as they reach continental waters, before developing into pigmented elvers and then the growth phase: the yellow eel. The final stage is the marine-migratory silver eel which is characterised by silvery counter-shading and large eyes.

Anguilla bengalensis juveniles feed on insects and other aquatic invertebrates while adults feed on fishes (including trout in the streams of the eastern highlands of Zimbabwe) and crabs (Okeyo 1998). This species inhabits various niches in river systems from quiet undisturbed areas containing mud substrate to deep water, fast-flowing rock pools of rivers (Bell-Cross and Minshull 1988). In Malaysia A. bengalensis has been found to reside in upper/mid-stream areas at higher elevation with cooler water temperatures (Arai and Kadir 2017a). Length estimates for this species range between 80–200 cm (Shrestha 2003) and Pantulu (1957) found there to be strong positive length/weight relationships. Further, a close linear relationship between fecundity and total length has been observed (Kadir et al. 2017). Total length and body weight at silvering has been found to range from 487 to 1295 mm, and 257 to 5100 g, and age at silvering has been found to range from 5.5 to 10.5 years (Chai and Arai 2018). In a study of 47 specimens from Malaysia, seaward spawning migration occurred in individuals displaying high gonadosomatic indices between April and September (Arai and Kadir 2017b). This suggests their spawning season may extend for at least six months of the year (Arai and Kadir 2017b).

Note: Within the IUCN Habitat Classification Scheme table, most listed habitats are considered important for eels. The Marine Oceanic habitats were listed as ‘Major Importance’ due to there likely being a discrete spawning area.
threats:
Anguilla bengalensis, like all anguillid eels, is susceptible to a number of, primarily anthropogenic, threats. These threats include but are not limited to; barriers to migration, climate change, habitat degradation, invasive species, parasitism, pollution, predation and unsustainable exploitation. The significance of any single threat, or the synergy it may have with other threats is still poorly understood (Jacoby et al. 2015). It is therefore important to highlight that management measures focusing on a single threat, in isolation of other identified pressures, are potentially less likely to have a significant positive effect on eel abundance. All anguillids are catadromous and semelparous, migrating from continental waters to the ocean to breed, and spawning only once before death. These traits arguably increase the impact of threats, through the terminal nature of reproduction and exposing them to pressures in both freshwater and marine environments.

In India and Bangladesh in particular, harvesting of this species occurs, but it is not known what impact fishing is having on the overall population. As a mottled species, A. bengalensis is perhaps less desirable to the East Asian market, where plain coloured eels are generally preferred. There is, however, a growing market for mottled eels, although to date this is mainly for A. marmorata (Shiraishi and Crook 2015). 

The Conservation Assessment and Management Plan (CAMP) report on the freshwater fishes of India (Molur and Walker 1998) declared A. bengalensis as ‘Endangered’ according to IUCN criteria. In Bangladesh, A. bengalensis was assessed as ‘Vulnerable’ resulting from population decline attributable to “habitat loss and perceived over-exploitation for export” (Islam 2015). Threats reported to be affecting this species in both localities, were damming, fishing, loss of habitat, invasive species, disease, pollution, climate change, overexploitation and domestic trade (Molur and Walker 1998, Shrestha 2003, IUCN Bangladesh 2015). In Nepal specifically, most dams do not have fish and/or eel ladders, and loss of freshwater habitat is a significant problem (Shrestha 2003).

Barriers to migration appear to be problematic in Mozambique and Zimbabwe with dams such as the Cabora Bassa and Kariba dams preventing migration (Matiza and Crafter 1994, Mafuca and Bills 2012). A study investigating fish diversity in the Cahora Bassa Lake, found eels (A. marmorata, A. mossambica, and A. bengalensis) to be absent (Mafuca and Bills 2012). Historic studies had previously reported these species in this area prior to the construction of the Cahora Bassa Dam (Mafuca and Bills 2012). In Malawi, Nkula Dam is located on the Shire River (Mzuza et al. 2017), which may limit available habitat and movement. In Tanzania, the construction of large dams is also thought to have contributed to eel declines (Tamatamah 2012) Within the Arabian region, vagrant individuals of this species are known from a single location in the Wadi Hajr river, which is dammed 3–4 km from the mouth, possibly blocking upstream access for eels (Attaala and Rubaia 2005, Freyhof et al. 2015).

In South Africa, poor water quality is anecdotally suggested to have caused eel species to become rare in some localities, such as the False Bay catchments, and few specimens remaining in this area have been observed to have severe skin lesions (S. Lamberth pers. comm. 2019). Non-native species now found in many systems in South Africa, such as the predatory bass (Micropterus spp.) and catfish (Clarias spp.), may also have contributed to the decline (S. Lamberth pers. comm. 2019).

In 2012 a new species of parasitic nematode was discovered in the intestines of A. bengalensis collected from the freshwater bodies of Kerala State in southern Indian (Moravec et al. 2012). In some parts of India, this species has also been found to contain levels of pollutants that could be toxic to humans. In the Ganges River, West Bengal for example, A. bengalensis specimens that were caught contained methyl mercury concentrations that were higher than the limits set by the PFA (Provention of Food Adulteration Act) for human consumption (Pal et al. 2012). 

Climate change has been proposed to play a role in fluctuations of abundance in anguillid species – particularly larval transport and glass eel recruitment – however, our understanding of these processes, and the scale of their influence, if any, is very limited (Jacoby et al. 2015).
population:
There is little quantitative information available to infer the population status of Anguilla bengalensis. It is reasonable to assume that there will have been some effects as a result of the identified threats, although considerably more information would be necessary to determine accurate estimates and associated changes.

Anguilla bengalensis is the most common eel in Indian freshwater systems, and in particular in Nagaland and Assam. In 1998, this species was classified as ‘Endangered’ in India in accordance with a decline in AOO (area of occupancy) and a decline in the extent and/or quality of habitat (Molur and Walker 1998). During a systematic sampling survey carried out between 2004 and 2006 in the Periyar Tiger Reserve (a large river system in Kerala), its relative abundance was deemed 'rare' across the ten sampling locations (Radhakrishnan and Kurup 2010). The IUCN Red List of Bangladesh assessed A. bengalensis as ‘Vulnerable’ within its regional assessment (Islam 2015). This is due to a suspected population decline of 30% over the last ten years, resulting from habitat-loss and unsustainable exploitation (Islam 2015).

For other localities, there is limited information. There is some anecdotal evidence for localised extirpation in Africa, for example in Lake Kariba, Zimbabwe where fisherman, in 1998, reported no freshwater eel had been found since the construction of a large hydroelectric dam in 1959 (S. Watanabe pers. comm. 2014). In Manyame River, Zimbabwe, A. bengalensis was described as “formerly more numerous”, with individuals having not been collected or caught more recently, possibly indicating decline as a result of dams (Gratwicke et al. 2003). In Tanzania, the decline in native eels (A. bengalensis and A. mossambica) is thought to have begun in the 1980s, also as a result of dam construction (Tamatamah 2012). Fishing trials carried out over the past decade have only found a few individual eels in comparison to pre-impoundment fish studies (Tamatamah 2012).

In some areas in South Africa, such as the Eerste River catchment in False Bay, eels were historically considered a problem species, and recruiting elvers caused blockages in irrigation pumps (S. Lamberth pers. comm. 2019). Since the 1970s, eels are no longer common in False Bay catchments; this has been suggested to be due to poor water quality (S. Lamberth pers. comm. 2019). In KwaZulu-Natal, South Africa, river surveys for anguillid eels combined with historical distribution data found A. bengalensis not to be present in areas where they were previously extant (C. Hanzen unpub. data). Since 2000, A. marmorata and A. bengalensis have disappeared from longline sample catches in some catchments in Western Cape. One example is the Breede River, home to the invasive catfish (Clarias spp.), and so this may be a result of predation (S. Lamberth pers. comm. 2019). Similar to A. marmorata and A. mossambica, A. bengalensis may have once occurred in the Rietvlei-Diep system in Table Bay, although recent records have been of dead A. marmorata individuals with visible lesions (S. Lamberth pers. comm. 2019).

In Réunion, A. bengalensis (listed under the redundant synonym A. labiata), as well as other recruiting anguillid eels (A. bicolor, A. marmorata and A. mossambica), are classified as ‘Critically Endangered’ under the regional Red List (Fricke et al. 2009). Listed threats include fisheries (target species and bycatch), habitat loss, construction of barriers to migration, and parasites (Fricke et al. 2009).
range:
Anguilla bengalensis is found in Pakistan, India (Kerala, Andhra Pradesh, Arunanchal Pradesh, Manipur, Meghalaya, Orissa, Tamil Nadu, Assam, and Nagaland (Tsurang River)), Bangladesh, Nepal (Gandaki, Koshi, Karnali, Mahakali), Sri Lanka, Myanmar, South Africa (Sympatric with A. marmorata in the Western Cape), Kenya, Mozambique, Tanzania, Eswatini (Komati river system), Lake Kariba, Middle Zambezi and its larger tributaries on the plateau, Limpopo (Umzingwane River and Inyankuni Dam), Pungwe, Buzi, Upper and Lower Save/Runde systems in Zimbabwe. It is also found in Lake Malawi and its catchment area as well as the Shire River and its tributaries and the eastward flowing Athi and Tana drainages (Seegers et al. 2003). In Ethiopia A. bengalensis has been reported from the middle reaches of the Genale River catchment in the southwest of the country and is currently the only anguillid species found in the country (Golubtsov et al. 2012). An electrofishing study conducted in upper estuaries of the Seychelles, Mayotte, Mauritius, Reunion and the east coast of Madagascar recorded no A. bengalensis out of 4,172 collected eels (Robinet et al. 2008). Most recently, this species’ range has been extended to Aceh in Indonesia (Muchlisin et al. 2017), and north-western Peninsular Malaysia (Arai 2014, Arai et al. 2015, Arai and Wong 2016, Arai and Kadir 2017a,b). There are also occasional records of vagrant individuals in the Arabian Peninsula (Wadi Haj in Yemen; Ataala and Rubaia 2005).

There remains some uncertainty surrounding where freshwater eels including A. bengalensis spawn in the Indian Ocean. Indeed, compared to other species, very few leptocephali have been gathered for A. bengalensis and it is still not known whether this species has a single, or multiple spawning locations, or whether spawning location overlaps with other anguillids (see Robinet et al. 2008, Watanabe et al. 2014 for discussion).
useTrade:
The various life stages, ranging from glass to silver, of all anguillid species are harvested and traded on a global scale for farming and consumption, with current demand predominantly driven by East Asian markets, in particular Japan, the Republic of Korea (also known as South Korea) and mainland China (hereafter China). A concerning pattern of exploitation is already apparent – when one Anguilla species or population becomes over-exploited, industry moves to the next in order to fulfil demand (Gollock et al. 2018).

According to FAO data, annual global Anguilla production has steadily increased since the 1950s, mainly due to the expansion of farming in East Asia. In 2016, eel farming accounted for 98% of total eel production (over 290,000 tonnes (t)), with China responsible for nearly 86% (FAO 2018). Eel farming is reliant on wild-caught juvenile eels (glass eels/elvers) as “seed” as breeding in captivity is not yet commercially viable. Although the preferred species for farming in East Asia is A. japonica, which is native to the region, declines in availability and ongoing demand has led to increase in harvest and trade in juveniles of other Anguilla spp. in recent years (Shiraishi and Crook 2015, Gollock et al. 2018). According to East Asian Customs data, between 2008 and 2017 East Asian countries/territories imported ~14 t of live eel fry for farming (glass eels and larger juveniles) from Africa (99% from Madagascar) and 7.6 t from Bangladesh (all in 2014). There is, however, no information suggesting that A. bengalensis is currently used (or there are plans to use it) in eel farms in East Asia.

Live eels and meat are traded globally for consumption and to a much smaller extent Anguilla skins and leather products are also in international trade. Global Customs trade data for live, fresh, frozen and prepared/preserved eel (non-species-specific) are available for the last 40 years.  According to FAO and UN Comtrade, global annual exports of Anguilla averaged around 20,000 t in the late 1970s, after which annual exports showed a steady increase to a maximum of over 130,000 t in 2001. Since then annual exports have been declining, to just over 80,000 t in 2008–2011, increasing again slightly to ~90,000 t in 2013–2015. The export value of these commodities has steadily increased over the past 40 years, reaching USD ~1.6 billion in 2012. Over the last decade, of the four commodity types, live and prepared/preserved eel accounted for nearly 80% of total exports by weight, and China has been the main eel exporter and Japan the main importer. As noted above, a high percentage of eel in international trade is derived from eels having been grown out in farms. 

Anguilla bengalensis is found in subsistence and commercial fisheries and in international trade, however as its range overlaps with many other anguillids, species specific data is very limited and no catch data has been reported to FAO by any of its main African or Asian range States. Anguilla bengalensis is the most common eel in Indian inland waters and is of considerable commercial value in India and the Andaman Islands. On local markets in both India and Bangladesh A. bengalensis is only sold during the yellow or silver eel stage; live eels (greater than 100 g) of this species, originating in Bangladesh, are being offered for sale on B2B marketplaces/trade platforms. Anguilla bengalensis is harvested in small quantities (on average between one and six specimens a day per fisherman) in the Ganale Dawa river basin in Ethiopia (Abelti et al. 2014). Yellow eel bycatch in Myanmar was reported as 12 t in 2017 with 10% of this believed to be A. marmorata or A. bengalensis (SEAFDEC 2018). Other uses of the species include treatment of arthritis, piles and meningitis in India (Talwar and Jhingran 1991, Chanu et al. 2014). In addition, A. bengalensis is considered a 'pristine rare ornamental species of the Himalayan drainage' often being preserved in temple ponds for religious purposes (Shrestha 2003).

International trade in Anguilla commodities is reported from much of A. bengalensis’s range, however, the species composition of shipments is unknown and could contain many different Anguilla species including A. bicolor, A. marmorata and A. mossambica. According to UN Comtrade, exports of eel commodities (live, fresh, frozen and prepared eel) from south Asian countries increased from ~1,330 t in 2008 to ~5,170 t in 2015 (however, data is incomplete and this may be an underestimate), with live (from Bangladesh) and frozen eels (from India) being the main commodities for export. Myanmar reported exports live eels in 2010, 2014 and 2016, totalling ~10,900 t, however, live eel exports in the region are known to include other non-Anguilla eel species such as Monopterus albus (Swamp Eels). Madagascar, South Africa, Tanzania and Mauritius also exported Anguilla commodities between 2008 and 2017, with most exports being live and frozen eels from Madagascar (273 t) and South Africa (129 t). Exports of live eels (all life stages) from Madagascar increased gradually from 4.6 t in 2004 to 8.8 t in 2009 and then in 2010 there was a dramatic increase in exports to over 45 t. From 2011 to 2015 annual exports fluctuated between 16t and 26 t, and in 2016 and 2017 they declined again to ~11 t. Companies trading in the southern and east Africa region declare that their glass and adult live eels are A. mossambica and that they are able to differentiate between species and control harvesting as glass eel recruitment is asynchronous, however exports to East Asia of live eels caught in Madagascar, Mozambique and South Africa have been reported to include other species (S. Lamberth pers. comm. 2019).
conservationActions:
There are no known species-specific policies in place for Anguilla bengalensis. In South Africa in 1994, the River Health Programme (RHP) was established to monitor the health and ecosystem services provided by riverine habitats and, where necessary, establish protected areas to rejuvenate ecosystems and minimise human impacts (River Health Programme 2003). There are also plans to try and increase upstream and downstream river connectivity in South Africa, by linking adjoining sub-catchments in an attempt to aid migration (Rivers-Moore et al. 2011). Eels and eel pathways / migratory routes are also implicit in the Environmental Water Requirement (EWR) and Resource Directed Measures (RDM) methods in South Africa. Native Anguilla spp. are to be included within the South African National Biodiversity Institute (SANBI) National Biodiversity Assessment (NBA) 2018 (Skowno et al. 2019).

The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) member states (AMSs) have, since 2015, established management initiatives for anguillid eels, which includes developing policy and research (SEAFDEC 2018). In 2016, a workshop was held by the Inland Fishery Resources Development and Management Department/South Asian Fisheries Development Center (IFRDMD/SEAFDEC). This was held to address issues on data collection for eels in Southeast Asia, exchange existing fisheries information, and discuss recommendations to improve the sustainability of anguillid eel fisheries across this range (SEAFDEC 2016). A number of recommendations were suggested, which included harmonising data collection methods, and strengthening regulations on eel trade (SEAFDEC 2016). More recent workshops held by SEAFDEC have taken place in 2019, on both “Statistics of Tropical Anguillid Eels in Southeast Asia” and “Aquaculture of Tropical Anguillid Eels in Southeast Asia” (SEAFDEC 2019).

A scientific meeting on the “3rd International Symposium on the Tropical Eels Genus Anguilla (ISTEGA)” was held in Manado, North Sulawesi, Indonesia, from 1–3 August 2019. The international symposium held by the Indonesian Society of Tropical Eels (ISTES) and supported by the Indonesian Institute of Science as Indonesian Scientific Authority, and two national universities: Sam Ratulangi University of North Sulaewesi, and Tadulako University of Central Sulawesi. The theme of the 3rd ISTEGA 2019 was “science, conservation, and management of the tropical eel genus Anguilla for sustainable use”.

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 61 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in one threat-defined location, and there is a continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: This species is found in Hepatic Forest and Broadleaf Cloud Forest forest in the Lower Montane Wet Forest formation (Townsend et al. 2011, Townsend 2014). It is not considered to tolerate habitat disturbance (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019). Although there is limited ecological information, it is expected to reproduce by direct development, as with other congeners.
threats:
The main threats to the species are forest fires, especially during extended dry seasons. The fires are normally in the surrounding cloud forest, but still represent a threat to the species. The elfin forest is still intact, however the surrounding cloud forest is being destroyed and fragmented by subsistence agricultural use and coffee plantations. The reform to the Ley de Protección de la Actividad Caficultora y Cacaotera (Decreto 37-2016; Artículos I, V, VI) has incentivised the cultivation of coffee in national lands, including the core zones of protected areas, which is increasing the alteration of primary forest (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). Hydroelectric dam development is also a problem in this area (J. Townsend and L. Herrera pers. comm. March 2019).

Climate change is also considered to be a threat. Highland amphibians are adapted to inhabit a narrow climatic envelope. Changes in climate are expected to reduce the available suitable habitat and required microclimates. Rapid shifts in the climatic conditions required by these species would not allow sufficient opportunity for adaptation, especially in light of the limited possibility for elevational migration. Tropical Montane Cloud Forest (>1,000 m asl) has been demonstrated to be negatively affected by climatic changes to a greater extent than other habitats (Foden et al. 2013, Wicaksono et al. 2017, Lyra et al. 2017, Neate-Clegg et al. 2018). An increase in high rainfall events is being observed throughout its range, as well as an increase in the frequency of extreme weather events (hurricanes and droughts) in the Caribbean, destroying the riparian habitat required by stream-dwelling and stream-associated amphibian species (Honduras Amphibian Red List Workshop March 2019). Climate change is therefore considered to be both a current and future threat to all amphibian species in this habitat type. Furthermore, amphibians globally are at an increased risk of disease (e.g. chytridiomycosis) and a decline in fecundity due to such changes (Pounds et al. 2006, Blaustein et al. 2010).

The emergence of the salamander chytrid fungus (Batrachochytrium salamandrivorans, “Bsal”) as an amphibian pathogen has caused dramatic declines in European salamanders since its arrival in 2010 through the international pet trade (Feldmeier et al. 2016). While the presence of the fungus has not been confirmed in the Americas, it is spreading in Europe and risks spreading further. The threat of infection and population declines in salamanders is thought to be highly likely and detrimental to the majority of native species, should the fungus arrive in Honduras (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).
population: It is only known from three specimens (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019). Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species is only known from the immediate vicinity of its type locality, which is the northwestern slope of Cerro La Picucha, Parque Nacional Sierra de Agalta, Olancho Department, Honduras, between 1,890-1,920 m asl (Townsend et al. 2011). It is endemic to Cerro La Picucha, and is not expected to be found elsewhere (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019). It occurs in a single threat-defined location. It has been mapped to suitable elevation around its known locality, which has provided an extent of occurrence (EOO) of 61 km2.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs in Parque Nacional Sierra de Agalta.

Conservation Needed
Improved enforcement and management of the national parks and the elimination of incentives to convert forest (e.g., Decreto 37-2016) is urgently needed to halt anthropogenic land use change in the national parks and reserves of Honduras (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). Parque Nacional Sierra de Agalta is managed by two regional ICF offices that are relatively well positioned for park management; additional resources should be directed to these offices to increase their effectiveness (J. Townsend and L. Herrera pers. comm. March 2019). 

Proactive, precautionary steps should be taken to detect the arrival of Bsal in Honduras and to establish a baseline by including the swabbing of salamanders encountered during routine amphibian monitoring activities in the country (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). In addition to regular monitoring, the general public can also support these efforts through reporting any dead salamanders to the iNaturalist global project: Saving Salamanders with Citizen Science (J. Kolby pers. comm. March 2019).

Research Needed
Research on population and life history is required (J. Townsend and L. Herrera pers. comm. March 2019).

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 10 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in one threat-defined location, and there is a continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: The single specimen of this species was collected from leaf litter packed onto a rock ledge, alongside a small creek in the Lower Montane Wet Forest formation (Townsend et al. 2010). It is not likely to tolerate habitat disturbance (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019). Although there is limited ecological information, it is expected to reproduce by direct development, as with other congeners.
threats:
In Texiguat, the major threats to this species include high rates of deforestation and encroachment in the wildlife refuge for extensive cattle ranching and coffee plantations, agricultural crops (e.g., beans, avocado), including in the core area, illegal selective logging for hardwoods, followed by clear-cutting along the same access routes (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). Another threat includes the construction of several small-scale hydroelectric dams (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). The reform to the Ley de Protección de la Actividad Caficultora y Cacaotera (Decreto 37-2016; Artículos I, V, VI) has incentivised the cultivation of coffee in national lands, including the core zones of protected areas, which is increasing the alteration of primary forest (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). There is a proposal to shift the core part of the refuge (which currently is at 1,250 m asl) upslope, which would create a much larger buffer zone where habitat conversion can progress unabated (C. Antúnez and J. Ramos Galdámez pers. comm. March 2019).

Climate change is also considered to be a threat. Highland amphibians are adapted to inhabit a narrow climatic envelope. Changes in climate are expected to reduce the available suitable habitat and required microclimates. Rapid shifts in the climatic conditions required by these species would not allow sufficient opportunity for adaptation, especially in light of the limited possibility for elevational migration. Tropical Montane Cloud Forest (>1,000 m asl) has been demonstrated to be negatively affected by climatic changes to a greater extent than other habitats (Foden et al. 2013, Wicaksono et al. 2017, Lyra et al. 2017, Neate-Clegg et al. 2018). An increase in high rainfall events is being observed throughout its range, as well as an increase in the frequency of extreme weather events (hurricanes and droughts) in the Caribbean, destroying the riparian habitat required by stream-dwelling and stream-associated amphibian species (Honduras Amphibian Red List Workshop March 2019). Climate change is therefore considered to be both a current and future threat to all amphibian species in this habitat type. Furthermore, amphibians globally are at an increased risk of disease (e.g. chytridiomycosis) and a decline in fecundity due to such changes (Pounds et al. 2006, Blaustein et al. 2010).

The emergence of the salamander chytrid fungus (Batrachochytrium salamandrivorans, “Bsal”) as an amphibian pathogen has caused dramatic declines in European salamanders since its arrival in 2010 through the international pet trade (Feldmeier et al. 2016). While the presence of the fungus has not been confirmed in the Americas, it is spreading in Europe and risks spreading further. The threat of infection and population declines in salamanders is thought to be highly likely and detrimental to the majority of native species, should the fungus arrive in Honduras (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).
population: It is only known from its holotype. The population trend is unknown, but due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species is only known from its type locality of Refugio de Vida Silvestre Texíguat, Atlántida Department, Honduras, at 1,550 m asl (Townsend et al. 2010). It is endemic to Texiguat, and is not likely to be found elsewhere (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019). It occurs in a single threat-defined location, and its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 10 km2.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs in Refugio de Vida Silvestre Texíguat.

Conservation Needed
Improved enforcement and management of the national parks and the elimination of incentives to convert forest (e.g., Decreto 37-2016) is urgently needed to halt anthropogenic land use change in the national parks and reserves of Honduras (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). Parque Nacional Sierra de Agalta is managed by two regional ICF offices that are relatively well positioned for park management; additional resources should be directed to these offices to increase their effectiveness (J. Townsend and L. Herrera pers. comm. March 2019). 

Proactive, precautionary steps should be taken to detect the arrival of Bsal in Honduras and to establish a baseline by including the swabbing of salamanders encountered during routine amphibian monitoring activities in the country (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). In addition to regular monitoring, the general public can also support these efforts through reporting any dead salamanders to the iNaturalist global project: Saving Salamanders with Citizen Science (J. Kolby pers. comm. March 2019).

Research Needed
Intensive field studies are required to found out more about its ecology, population and distribution (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019).

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 22 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in one threat-defined location, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
habitat: This species lives inside and under rotten logs on the ground and in the soil, in lower montane wet forest. One of the type specimens was found under an illegally cut mahogany plank (McCranie et al. 1993). It is not believed to be tolerant to habitat disturbance (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019). It breeds by direct development and is not dependent upon water.
threats:
In Texiguat, the major threats to this species include high rates of deforestation and encroachment in the wildlife refuge  for extensive cattle ranching and coffee plantations, agricultural crops (e.g., beans, avocado), including in the core area, illegal selective logging for hardwoods, followed by clear-cutting along the same access routes (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). Another threat includes the construction of several small-scale hydroelectric dams (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). While the presence of the fungus has not been confirmed in the Americas, it is spreading in Europe and risks spreading further. The threat of infection and population declines in salamanders is thought to be highly likely and detrimental to the majority of native species, should the fungus arrive in Honduras (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019).
population: It is an uncommon fossorial species, that is not frequently encountered (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019). It is only known from five specimens (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019). Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
range: This species was previously reported from Cerro Bufalo in Parque Nacional Pico Bonito, Atlantida Department, and from near La Fortuna in Yoro Department, north-central Honduras, between 1,580-1,810 m asl. However, this species has now been restricted to Refugio de Vida Silvestre Texiguat, between 1,690-1,810 m asl (McCranie and Townsend 2011). The subpopulation from Parque Nacional Pico Bonito has now been assigned to Oedipina petiola (McCranie and Townsend 2011), and has been removed from the concept of this species. It is not thought to occur more widely, and is endemic to Texiguat (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019). It occurs in a single threat-defined location and its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 22 km2.
useTrade: There are no records of this species being utilized.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs in the Refugio de Vida Silvestre Texiguat.

Conservation Needed
Improved enforcement and management of the national parks and the elimination of incentives to convert forest (e.g., Decreto 37-2016) is urgently needed to halt anthropogenic land use change in the national parks and reserves of Honduras (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). Parque Nacional Sierra de Agalta is managed by two regional ICF offices that are relatively well positioned for park management; additional resources should be directed to these offices to increase their effectiveness (J. Townsend and L. Herrera pers. comm. March 2019). 

Proactive, precautionary steps should be taken to detect the arrival of Bsal in Honduras and to establish a baseline by including the swabbing of salamanders encountered during routine amphibian monitoring activities in the country (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). In addition to regular monitoring, the general public can also support these efforts through reporting any dead salamanders to the iNaturalist global project: Saving Salamanders with Citizen Science (J. Kolby pers. comm. March 2019).

Research Needed
Populations surveys and research to determine the full extent of its distribution are required (J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019).

rationale: Listed as Critically Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 55 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in one threat-defined location, and there is ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat and in the number of mature individuals due to chytridiomycosis.
habitat: This stream-breeding amphibian is found on low vegetation up to 5 m from the ground, along streams, and in arboreal bromeliads in lower montane wet forest and premontane wet forest. It is not tolerant of habitat disturbance (J. Kolby pers. comm. March 2019).
threats:
Chytridiomycosis is a threat to this species, and declines have been observed. In 2007, the overall prevalence of Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Bd) in sampled individuals of this species was found to be 78%. Larvae of this species which are infected with Bd commonly develop oral defects including disrupted tooth rows and eroded jaw sheaths (especially the upper jaw sheath) (Kolby et al. 2010). In 2013, Kolby studied the terrestrial dispersion and environmental transmission potential of Bd, where 24 of 29 metamorphs tested positive for Bd infection, at a prevalence of 86.2% (Kolby et al. 2015).

Habitat loss and degradation is also a major threat. The reform to the Ley de Protección de la Actividad Caficultora y Cacaotera (Decreto 37-2016; Artículos I, V, VI) has incentivised the cultivation of coffee in national lands, including the core zones of protected areas, which is increasing the alteration of primary forest (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). The cultivation of cardamom, coffee, and flowers is taking place within the boundaries of Parque Nacional Cusuco (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019), and associated pollution from herbicide and pesticide use, and water pollution from coffee harvesting processes [aguas mieles] (L. Herrera pers. comm. March 2019). Another major threat is an increase in intentional human-induced fires for clearing of habitat for agriculture (J. Kolby pers. comm. March 2019). The building of roads in view of increasing hydroelectric development, increasing human settlements, and selective logging are causing habitat loss within the park (J. Kolby, F. Castañeda, M. Solis and L. Herrera pers. comm. March 2019). The trampling of leaf-litter, erosion of trails, and physical disturbance caused by high numbers of people through tourism activities and international research groups is an additional issue (J. Kolby pers. comm. March 2019).

Climate change is also considered to be a threat. Highland amphibians are adapted to inhabit a narrow climatic envelope. Changes in climate are expected to reduce the available suitable habitat and required microclimates. Rapid shifts in the climate conditions required by these species would not allow sufficient opportunity for adaptation, especially in light of the limited possibility for elevational migration. Tropical Montane Cloud Forest (>1,000 m asl) has been demonstrated to be negatively affected by climatic changes to a greater extent than other habitats (Foden et al. 2013, Wicaksono et al. 2017, Lyra et al. 2017, Neate-Clegg et al. 2018). An increase in high rainfall events are being observed throughout its range, as well as an increase in the frequency of extreme weather events (hurricanes and droughts) in the Caribbean, destroying the riparian habitat required by stream-dwelling and stream-associated amphibian species (Honduras Amphibian Red List Workshop March 2019). Climate change is therefore considered to be both a current and future threat to all amphibian species in this habitat type. Furthermore, amphibians globally are at an increased risk of disease (e.g. chytridiomycosis) and a decline in fecundity due to such changes (Pounds et al. 2006, Blaustein et al. 2010).
population: It is considered moderately common within its very restricted range, but the observed abundance of individuals has varied considerably between surveys (J. Kolby per. comm. March 2019). On some occasions, five to seven individuals have been found in one evening whereas on other nights, in the same suitable habitat, there have been none observed (J. Kolby pers. comm. March 2019). This species is considered to be more abundant than Plectrohyla exquisita, and metamorphs are found with greater frequency (J. Kolby pers. comm. March 2019). Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of habitat and the threat of chytridiomycosis, the population and the number of mature individuals are decreasing.
range: This species is found in Parque Nacional Cusuco on the Sierra de Omoa, Department of Cortés, north-western Honduras, between 1,400-1,990 m asl. It is likely to be restricted to the park, but it might be found in other areas of the park which have not yet been surveyed (J. Kolby pers. comm. March 2019). It occurs in a single threat-defined location, and its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 55 km<sup>2</sup>.
useTrade: This species previously appeared in the international pet trade, however this has not been the case in recent years so it is not considered to be a threat (J. Kolby and J. Townsend pers. comm. March 2019).
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
The species occurs wholly within the Parque Nacional Cusuco, which has been declared a national park since 1987. It occupies the core zone of the park, but a greater proportion of the population is found in the western side where the habitat is under greater threat (J. Kolby pers. comm. March 2019).

Conservation Needed
Improved enforcement and management of the national parks and the elimination of incentives to convert forest (e.g., Decreto 37-2016) is urgently needed to halt anthropogenic land use change in the national parks and reserves of Honduras (Honduras Red List Assessment Workshop March 2019). Ex situ populations should also be established (J. Kolby pers. comm. March 2019). 

Research Needed
In view of the threat of chytridiomycosis, the status of this species should be closely monitored. Research into Ranavirus is required, as symptoms resembling the disease have been observed in amphibians throughout the park (J. Kolby pers. comm. March 2019).

rationale: Inconsistencies and a lack of transparency in the methods used to census the population in the past have meant that it is difficult to assess changes in this species's population size. Some past analyses have indicated a rapid decline, but a more recent analysis concluded that it is unlikely to have undergone a severe decline over recent decades, and is probably slightly declining or stable. Therefore, although the species is unlikely to have undergone a large population reduction over the past three generations, there is a large amount of uncertainty. For this reason, the species is listed as Near Threatened.
habitat: It breeds in colonies, mainly on sparsely-vegetated gravels on riverbeds, often in braided river systems (Higgins and Davies 1996, Taylor 2000). It appears to favour rivers adjacent to high-producing pasture (McClellan and Smith 2015). It will also nest on sand-spits, shellbanks, lake margins, swamps, harbours and sandy coasts (Higgins  and  Davies 1996, Taylor 2000). It often roosts and feeds on farmland, and scavenges in urban areas where refuse is available (Higgins and Davies 1996). Some birds remain at colonies throughout the year, but most move from inland breeding sites to the coasts (Higgins and Davies 1996). It has a varied diet of terrestrial, freshwater and marine invertebrates, fish and shellfish (Higgins and Davies 1996, Heather and Robertson 1997). Breeding can begin after two years (Heather and Robertson 1997), but many individuals do not start until six years old, and adults may live over 30 years (R. Hitchmough in litt. 2005).
threats: The main threat is predation by introduced mammals. Brown Rats Rattus norvegicus take eggs and chicks in the North Island. Remote video cameras have shown that Stoats (Mustela erminea), Ferrets (Mustela furo) and feral cats (Felis catus) are major predators on South Island colonies, often taking hundreds of chicks in a season (Biswell 2006). Hedgehogs (Erinaceus europaeus) may also take eggs. Increased populations of the native Swamp Harrier (Circus approximans) and Kelp Gull (Larus dominicanus) also exert significant predation (Mischler 2018a). The recreational use of riverbeds and coastal areas is increasing, causing greater disturbance of nesting colonies (Taylor 2000). There have been incidents of vehicles being driven through colonies and large numbers of birds being shot (McClellanan and Habraken 2019). River modification, including hydroelectric development, channelisation and water and gravel extraction, also has a significant impact. The spread of invasive alien plant species such as Russell Lupin (Lupinus polyphyllus) and Broom (Cytisus scoparius) is a major threat, reducing suitable nesting habitat on riverbeds, providing cover for predators and forcing birds to nest closer to the water where they are more vulnerable to flooding (Maloney 1999, Taylor 2000). Intensification of agricultural practices, such as the increased use of pesticides, may reduce the availability of invertebrates. Extreme weather events such as droughts and heavy snowfall can kill thousands of individuals (McClellanan and Habraken 2019). Although the species is adapted to flooding at nesting colonies, an increased frequency of flooding may impact on productivity (McClellan 2009).
population:
A nationwide census was carried out by the Ornithological Society of New Zealand in 1995-1998 (G. A. Taylor per R. Coumbe in litt. 2000), and counted 48,000 nests (Powlesland 1998), thus the number of mature individuals was estimated to be 96,000. The methods used for these surveys are poorly-documented, but appear to have involved ground counts on the North Island, and a combination of ground and aerial surveys on the South Island (Hawkins and Powlesland 1995, in Mischler 2018b). The omission of some known current breeding colonies and sites from this census indicates that the population size may have been underestimated (Mischler 2018a).

Following a series of ground counts made across four river systems in Southland from 2004 to 2006, calibrated with aerial photography, the total population size in New Zealand was estimated at approximately 90,000 mature individuals (McClellan 2009). However, it has been suggested that gaps between the timing of some of the ground counts and aerial photographs, together with the application of inaccurate conversion factors for nests and individuals, could have led to inaccuracies in the population estimate, resulting in an overestimate (Mischler 2018a,b).

A further nationwide census took place from 2014-2017. Aerial surveys were used to locate, photograph and count nests, and ground surveys were used to determine a correction factor to apply to the nest counts. A total of 60,256 nests were recorded (Mischler 2018a,b), which is here assumed to equate to 120,512 mature individuals.

The population size is here placed in the band 90,000 - 121,000 mature individuals.

A genetic analysis showed that the species has two distinct genetic groups, with individuals in the Rotorua region on the North Island being distinct from those in the rest of New Zealand (Mischler et al. 2018). The species is therefore likely to have at least two subpopulations.
range: Larus bulleri is endemic to New Zealand. It is mainly found in the South Island, with a small percentage of the population inhabiting the North Island (Mischler 2018a,b). The region of Southland supports the majority of the population (Powlesland 1998, Taylor 2000, Mischler 2018a,b), with 55.9% of the total population in 2016/7 (Mischler 2018a,b). Other regions with breeding populations include Canterbury (34.3%), Otago (4.6%), West Coast (2.6%), North Island (1.6%), Marlborough (0.6%) and Tasman (0.3%; Mischler 2018a,b). The species has expanded its breeding range in the North Island in the last few decades, with the largest breeding populations found in the Auckland region, the Bay of Plenty and Hawke's Bay (Mischler 2018a,b). South Island rivers with large populations include the Ashburton in Canterbury, and the Aparima, Eyre Creek, Mataura and Oreti in Southland (Mischler 2018a,b).
conservationActions:
Conservation and Research Actions Underway
It is legally protected in New Zealand.
Studies of population size, survey methods, breeding biology, genetics, habitat, threats, movements and dispersal have been undertaken.
Habitat restoration and protection in the MacKenzie Basin is undertaken as part of Project River Recovery, including predator research and a public awareness campaign (Taylor 2000). In Southland, invasive plant species and ferrets are extensively controlled in the main riverbeds. Other invasive mammal species are occasionally trapped. Invasive mammals have also been trapped at the Ashburton Ricer and Hawke's Bay (Mischler 2018a). Kelp Gulls have been controlled in the lower Waimakariri River, and information boards have been installed to alert the public to their presence (Thierry et al. 2016).

Conservation and Research Actions Proposed
Repeat nationwide censuses at regular intervals to improve knowledge of population trends. Research the species's demography and movements.
Trap introduced predators at key colonies. Control invasive plants on riverbeds. Assess the possible impacts of further hydroelectric dam projects, and gravel and water extraction proposals (Taylor 2000). Carry out advocacy and education to discourage people from disturbing the species and to raise support for conservation work on privately-owned land (McClellan 2009).

rationale: Listed as Least Concern in view of its relatively wide distribution, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a more threatened category.
habitat: This species occurs in forests in low hills along small streams (Sparreboom 2014). It breeds in small, permanent streams, small temporary pools, and ponds (Takahashi and Iwasawa 1990, Matsui 2014), as well as ditches around rice-paddies, springs and marshes. Breeding season is from January to June, earlier in lowlands, with the peak between April to May. Most larvae metamorphose in Autumn of the same year, but some of them reach metamorphosis the following year. It is not able to adapt to disturbed habitats.
threats: At present, no threat is significantly affecting this species and its habitat is generally in good condition in most part of its range. However, some local subpopulations are threatened by habitat destruction due to clearing of forest (for logging, housing, solar power plant etc.), desiccation of ponds, ditches and marshes, construction of dams and forest roads. Serious parasitic disease by a trematode Euryhelmis costaricensis is reported to be increasing in subpopulations of the Abukuma mountains, eastern Fukushima Prefecture, and it is presumed that the introduced raccoon (Procyon lotor) or American mink (Neovison vison) are the source of the infection (Ihara et al. 2010).
population: This species is abundant and common in the Tohoku region, particularly in hilly lowlands to montane areas. It is relatively rare in the southern part of its range in the Kanto region, and is restricted to higher parts of the mountains. Subpopulations seem to be stable in montane regions, but are likely to be declining in lowlands near human habitations.
range: This species is widespread in the montane regions of northeastern Honshu, Japan (Aoki et al. 2013). It occurs throughout the Tohoku region, the Gunma, Ibaraki and Tochigi Prefectures in the Kanto region, and Niigata Prefecture in the Hokuriku region. It occurs from coastal areas (20 m asl) to higher than 1,500 m asl (Iwasawa 1982). Its range is known to be fragmented (Aoki et al. 2013).
useTrade: There is no use or trade of this species.
conservationActions:
Conservation Actions In-Place
The species has been designated as Near Threatened in the Japanese Red List. This species occurs in protected areas; Towada-Hachimantai, Bandai-Asahi, Nikko, Oze, and Joshinetsu National Parks and Shimokita-Hanto, Tsugaru, Kurikoma, Zao, Oga, Chokai, Echigo-Sanzan-Tadami, and Sado-Yahiko-Yoneyama Quasi-National Parks. There is no conservation programme in place for this species.

Research Needed
This is probably a complex of more than one species. Population genetics and ecological studies are needed.

rationale: Listed as Near Threatened because its estimated extent of occurrence is 19,916 km<sup>2</sup>, and there is an ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat in eastern Honshu, Japan, but likely more than 10 threat-defined locations making it close to qualifying for Vulnerable.
habitat: This species inhabits cool and humid forest-floors near streams in well-forested mountains (Yoshikawa and Matsui 2014). At the beginning of the breeding season they congregate around the headwaters of underground streams, and egg sacs are attached to the bottom of stones in the underground section of the stream (Yoshikawa and Matsui 2014).
